summary: Held captive for years in an enclosed space, a woman (Brie Larson) and her young son (Jacob Tremblay) finally gain their freedom, allowing the boy to experience the outside world for the first time.

reviews.content: Fantastic film. Great plot, some might find it slow or boring at parts it depends what kind of films you enjoy! It's not full of action but has a very interesting and deep, moving story line which made me cry. Definitely worth a watch.

Everyone should give this a watch once. The acting by Tremblay & Larson are phenomenal. Filled with amazing chemistry and heartfelt performances the whole way. the cinematography is filled with shaky cam, close ups and intimate shots for the first half and does a great job of making you feel like your there in the room with them, not just an observer. Than the second half feels much more refined with its shots and you feel more like an observer which works perfectly. The music is very good used at the right times and builds emotion very well. The editing is phenomenal as this feels like a thriller in the first half and drama in the second which is such a unique combination that works perfectly. The pacing is very well done, the only complain is sometimes in the second half shots can drag a little bit longer than they should it feels like sometimes. But besides that, this is without a question an All Time Classic.

Haunting performances. This movie is a must-see, if for no other reason than to fall in absolute love with Jacob Tremblay, who is mesmerizing in every single scene. It has some extremely heavy subject matter, but ROOM is one of the most rewarding movies I've experienced as a viewer. Well worth the emotional toll.
All around good movie, Jacob Tremblay with some really good acting.
Excellent, haunting, a must-see.
Intensely disturbing, but mesmerizing. Jacob Tremblay is amazing!
Child actor Tremblay is remarkable.  The book by Emma Donoghue is excellent as well.
A bit slow, obvious, indoorsy, and lacking in love, joy and feeling.
Great movie seen it 10 times
The best acting performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay! With the best movie screenplay ever adapted!

This movie is really screwed up in many ways. It’s upsetting, depressing, and sickening. It’s really sad and reminds of those girls in Ohio that were held captive for 9 years and one of them having the captors child. I can’t even imagine but this film is a way to try and understand I guess is the only good purpose to this movie

Movies like Room also remind me why I love films. Overall, the film provides one serious emotional roller coaster while we watch our main leads go through many ups and downs. I even found myself thinking about what it would be like to be in Jack's shoes without even realizing it; what would you think of the world if you have never seen it and lived in a Room?

I legit thought that kid was a girl till I read the description. Fuming when the ma swatted the mouse. Why was she breastfeeding a 5 year old?
Not my cuppa tea sorry

6 years ago- Well constructed pacing, a fantastic turn from Brie Larsen, and a dark story being handled well works to elevate a movie that struggles in the second half and an unbelievably annoying child actor.

A fantastic tear-jerking modern day masterpiece, "Room" is a hard to watch but ultimately satisfying watch that proves the talent of its cast and showcases the horrors of real life abuse. An absolute must-see, though I don't think it's a movie that everyone will be able to sit through.
The greatest drama ever, LOL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oh boy get ready to cry if you are watching.
A passiote story slightly based on a real case. Room gets you inside a very tough subject in a beautiful way.

That review summary may sound very oxymoronic, but to me it applies to a film such as 'Room'. A film with a difficult subject, that is the stuff of nightmares, but tells it so beautifully with an interesting approach that works better than all the potential traps that films of its genre could fall under.

What could have easily have been told in a lurid, gratuitous way (being inspired by the true-life case of Josef Fritzl) is instead told in a careful and restrained way. There is even an innocence in 'Room', due to its very fascinating decision to tell it from the viewpoint of a five year old, in this case Jack, one that comes off very movingly and gives a sense that there is a little ray of hope in a seemingly hopeless situation. The source material, equally brilliant, is to be thanked here, its author Emily Donoghue adapts it to screen here and none of its power is lost.

Really appreciated the careful and restrained approach to the storytelling in 'Room', and for me and many others it was something different considering the subject. It does though affect some of the pacing in the middle act, where a little of the tension seen in especially the first part is lost a little.

For my tastes too, though it probably did fit the film's younger and more innocent viewpoint it's told from, the music score does lay it on too thick with the treacle.

However, loved how the story was told and its approach. What 'Room' also strongly benefitted from being told this way was that the mother and son relationship was able to shine through and really resonate, which it may not have done as effectively with a heavier tone. And shine through it does, with great charm and poignancy. Also appreciated that none of the characters were painted too black and white, even Old Nick.

Production values are effectively claustrophobic and the nocturnal parts chillingly nightmarish. 'Room' is beautifully directed by someone who understood how claustrophobic thrillers worked, how mother and son bonds do in dire situations do and the ability to combine both to ensure a powerful experience. A directing job that's both unsettling and empathetic. Similarly 'Room' is written with effortless skill and deft thoughtfulness.

Can't find anything to fault the performances. The superb one of Brie Larson, that was a very worthy Oscar (Golden Globe and Bafta too) win in her category, is an obvious starting point, but one mustn't overlook the beyond-his-years turn of young Jacob Tremblay, one of the best child acting performances in recent years, and William H Macy and Joan Allen both giving some of their best work in years. Sean Bridgers also gives much more to what could have been a standard cliché role.

Overall, great powerful film but the somewhat fascinatingly unconventional (for the genre) way the story was told won't work for some. 9/10 Bethany Cox
an excellent movie performance was a very good performance by brie larson you can feel that moment of fear that jack was going through

Room es una película que no te saca una sola lágrima, rompe con los estándares propuesto por este tipo de cine algo conmovedor obsequiándonos momentos que juegan con nuestras emociones en todo momento, NO es una cinta perfecta y al verla puedes darte cuenta de algunos errores, pero al mismo tiempo ves como estos son opacados por la magistral dirección y las maravillosas y sentidas actuaciones del reparto en general, mismas que son las que prácticamente hacen la película. Brie Larson y Jacob Tremblay hacen una excelente química como dúo en pantalla y sus potentes trabajos tocan tus fibras emocionales mas sensibles haciendo de esta una de las películas mas emotivas e intensas de la historia y el imponente trabajo de un reparto. para mí es un 8,2/10

Intense
This film tells the story of a five year old boy who has never left his room, because he and his mother are held captive for years by a man.

The synopsis doesn't give me an idea of the unimaginable horror that is depicted in the film. Such unspeakable crime can be committed only by the most perverted individuals. As a result of this highly emotionally charged issue, "Room" is highly engaging. Towards the middle of the film, I find every cell in me wants the woman's plan to succeed. I held my breath, I welled up and I sincerely hope there would be some humanity left in the world. Another very emotional scene is the brief TV interview. The interviewer seems so caring and empathic, but asks very biased questions which leads to another emotional zenith. This film depicts the horror of captivity, which I am sure doesn't even match the true abuse and desperation that the victims face.

I hope the victims can recover and lead fulfilling lives.

A highly acclaimed film by both audiences and critics that tells a very challenging story very well in a profound and flawless way throughout its duration. But there is something wrong with this film and it bothers me deeply that it fails to make me fully enjoy it
Never ceasing to make me emotional (with every re-watch), Lenny Abrahamson's Room (2015) is a touching story! Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are outstanding! It's a must-see!
Just rewatched this beautiful movie as the Netflix show Maid reminded me of it. What an amazing performance by both Larson and Jacob! This movie deserved all of the awards it won and then some!
TIf they had cut one hour it would be a great movie.

Whilst the premise was unique, the plot didn't feel believable and was largely predictable. The main character was kept in a glorified garden shed in the suburbs rather than some remote location and somehow nobody heard her screaming at any point, she only attempted to escape once, none of the neighbours thought it was weird that the house owner regularly slept in his shed, and neither of the main characters ever got ill enough that they needed medical attention despite living in a tiny room with mice and no sunlight. Furthermore, the guy fell for the 'my son's dead' trick and didn't check that he actually was dead, allowing him to escape. Why would he risk that? The other issue with the plot and pacing was that the second half felt a bit lost. However, the main characters, especially the boy, were quite well thought out. The rest of the characters never got that much development. For example, the main character's dad could have had more of a role in the film. The acting was solid, with a very impressive performance from Jacob Tremblay, even if his voice was frankly annoying. There was also a decent amount of emotion, although the suicide attempt was predictable. Then the cinematography, visual effects, and soundtrack were well executed.

Certainly sticks with you because the scenario is so horrific but it seems like a 2-hour movie is impossible for the scope attempted.  10 hours, maybe.  It ends up a combination of too clean resolutions and unexplored threads.

It takes a lot to make me cry but this one hit me hard. Emotional gold in this story. I'd thought it would have just been the escape (action) side of the story.  But when it covers the drama and after effects of it all. It reduces you to tears. Thats where it beats out the others of the genre.
"Room" is a dramatic and incredibly serious story which spins its tone from dark and horrific to uplifting on a dime.
9.5/10 A brilliant movie that I may never bring myself to watch again. A real tear jerker and an emotional roller coaster.
Everything about this movie is great. 10/10 acting, even the kid is great!!
Haunting, tense, and devastating. "Room" delivers in all categories, even if it is hard to watch at some points.

From ‘Room' to the outside world 

Room is a movie directed by Lenny Abrahamson. The film is based on a book written by Emma Donoghue. The lead roles are portrayed by Jacob Tremblay Brie Larson, Sean Bridgers, Joan Allen and William H. Macy. The author is inspired by a true story related to Elisabeth Fritzl. She was locked up in a cellar for 24 years by his father, Jozef Fritzl. She was sexually assaulted and gave birth to seven children. The movie differs slightly from the true story. In the film, the relationship of the kidnapper with the main character namely Joy is not clear. This film really impressed me literally and figuratively speaking. I can compare this film with the other film namely "3096 years (also based on true story)" which also had to do with kidnapping. 

The whole story revolves around two people, Jack and Joy. Joy, the mother who lives in a room with her son. She had been kidnapped by a man named Old Nick seven years ago and locked up in a room ever since. Joy is regularly sexually abused by him. She gives birth to a child namely Jack. For him the room is the world and outside the room the space. His mother tells him all kinds of stories, stories that have nothing to do with the real world. Which later causes a problem, because when Jack is 5 years old, she wants to tell him what happened to her but he doesn't believe her mother. Finally, she can convince Jack that behind these walls lies another world that is much more beautiful than this one. And so she tries to convince him to escape from this room. 

 
Jacob Tremblay's acting as Jack was impressive, enchanting and nice to see. How he acts as someone for whom the room is the world. The material such as chairs, sink, .. etc was real and the world behind the TV screen was not real. How he looks at the world he doesn't know. That was done so perfectly by him. Brie Larson as a mother / victim, her acting was so realistic. When they consider his child's upset as something normal. She tries to keep Jack in touch with the outside world when they are liberated. 

 
In the film I was looking for certain elements such as flashback and the relationship between the kidnapper and the victim, Joy Newsome. Why flashback? When the mother tells his child how she got into this room, I would have liked a flashback to get a better picture of the happening. It's still not clear to me who Old Nick, the kidnapper was. Was he a stranger, neighbor, or someone from the victim's family? Why I am now asking this question is because the film is based on a true story where the abductor and the victim clearly had a relationship. 

The film has a heartbreaking story, the story that is not a fantasy but is the truth, which is almost unbelievable. In this peaceful world, there are also monsters that cause unrest. In this film, there are also messages that convey the following, never give up, and there is always an end to evil. The film is a must for those who find true stories interesting or films based on the true story. 

 "Closed in a room, my imagination becomes the universe, and the rest of the world is missing out" (Criss Jami).
The best book-to-film adaptation I've ever seen, and based on one of the best books I've ever read, ROOM is flawless in every possible aspect.
Interesting plot and well acted. I didn't know what would happen next at any point in the movie. A realistic take on the topic.

unique story line.  first part of movie where the characters are in " ROOM " are riveting .  Brie Larson and Jacob Trembla are excellent actors.  
Brie Larson deserved her Oscar.  A must see movie

when it comes to reality situations, this movie doesn't fail. not even on the ingenuity of jack above the situation. about the nucle where his mother is centered. this movie shows us a reality of kidnapping and rape and get us stuck on what it got of worse. you don't see the movie you live it.
This is one of the best films I have ever seen. Highly recommend watching it. Brie and Jacob did a stellar job. I felt so many emotions while watching it.
I can't recommend this movie more highly.  The doctor in this movie mentioned that the boy, Jack, was "plastic" at age 5, and I wish the film had gone into greater depth about this angle.

The movie tells the story of Jack and his mom Joy who live in a 10 by 10 ft. shed they call "Room". Joy has been held captive for seven years by an abductor named Old Nick, also known as Jack's biological father. Joy takes care of Jack alone and never lets Old Nick come close to him. Joy hides Jack inside the wardrobe every time Old Nick comes to the shed to sexually assault her. She teaches Jack that only the things inside "Room" are real, and the rest happens only on television. Not long after Jack's fifth birthday, Joy learns that Old Nick has lost his job and is unable to provide for them. She decides to teach Jack about the real world. However, Jack cannot understand and becomes frustrated towards Joy. After a while, he eventually begins to learn and identify what is real and what is not. After having the electricity and heat cut off one night, Joy takes the opportunity and helps Jack to fake a fever but Old Nick refuses to take him to the hospital. Joy tries once again by faking Jack's death and folds him in a rug. Old Nick reluctantly agrees to bury him somewhere. While Old Nick drives, Jack follows the instructions given by Joy and successfully jumps out of the truck and calls for help from a passerby. The police come to the rescue soon after and figure out the location of "Room". Joy finally gets out of the shed and reunites with Jack and her parents whom she hasn't seen for years. She then finds out about her parents' divorce and struggles with depression. Joy attempts to commit suicide but is sent to the hospital when Jack discovers her in the bathroom. During Joy's absence, Jack becomes adjusted to the new world as he slowly comes out of his shell. He decides to cut his hair (which he considers his "strong") and sends it to his mom so that she can have strength to overcome her struggles. Joy finally returns home and Jack suggests that they revisit "Room". They return to the shed and Jack says goodbye to each object in "Room". They walk out and smile as they begin their new journey.  

While it may be difficult for the audience to relate to the actual situation, there exist several themes and meanings behind the story of Joy and Jack that each can learn from. By looking at Joy, one can recognize the beautiful qualities of a mother. In several scenes, we sense Joy's great despair and hopelessness, but she always hides them in front of her son. She tries to stay optimistic for Jack and does her best to protect him from Old Nick. Her sacrifices, unconditional love and care for Jack are perfect symbols of motherhood. 

Even though Joy takes care of Jack and protects him, Jack, in a different sense, also protects Joy and gives her the strength and hope she needs in order to survive. Moreover, Jack is the one that makes the escape possible. There is a famous quote by John Donne, "No man is an island, entire of itself." The movie supports this quote perfectly and shows that we are never alone and that we are meant to help one another along the way in life.

There also exist two interesting themes that contrast with each other: freedom and exploration. Leaving "Room" has a completely different meaning to Joy and to Jack. To Joy, it means to be free and to be back into her comfort zone while to Jack, who knows nothing outside "Room", leaving it means to step out of his comfort zone to explore the unknown. Though we may not be physically stuck inside a room, there may come a time in our life when we feel stuck in a situation or in a relationship. Regardless of what "Room" may be to us, the film teaches us to let ourselves be free and to explore for the world is so big and there is so much to see. 

I strongly recommend this movie as it is one that makes you ponder and reflect on your own life. It gives hope and comfort to all those who are going through difficult times. From the beginning to the very end, we can witness the changes and the growth of each character. It is not just a fairy tale with a superhero coming to the rescue, but a realistic portrayal of all the ups and downs we go through in life and the emotions and feelings that we may experience when facing fears and challenges. The film touches hearts and gives strength. It motivates the audience to set themselves free from fear or past pains and to explore the big world out there.

Five-year old Jack lives in a small room with his mother, where he was born and is being held captive.  His finite universe extends as far as the four walls, the ceiling, and the floor, the only view of the outside world coming from a small skylight in the ceiling.  He is taught that all things in the natural world outside of the room are fictions created by the television.  To say more would be to say too much.  The film is disorienting, suspenseful, tragic, thought-provoking and, ultimately, inspirational.  Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are outstanding as mother and son.  Watch this movie.

I'm planning to post a video on YouTube explaining how I feel about this movie. But if you want a quick summary, I'll put this it this way: this film is......a miracle. Nothing I say can possibly do this movie justice. It is my favorite movie of all time, and I could not possibly recommend it enough to anyone reading this review.

With inspiration taken from the harrowing story of Elisabeth Fritzl, Lenny Abrahamson propels you on an emotional roller-coaster of not only the raw, gritty sorrow of human emotion but also highlights the happiness in which we can find in the smallest of things. Sentimentality is the key to this film. A trait we all hold dear in our day to day lives, a theme we can all personally relate to which I think is the films strongest point as we can all feel a deep sense of empathy for each character within each scene. This film moved me in ways few others have, and I promise it will move you, regardless of who you are or if you're heartless this film will imprint itself. Struggling to find a flaw within the film itself, stellar acting from Brie Larson, I look forward to her future projects.

A powerful, tender, and ultimately life-arrirming story of a mother and her son, victims of a disturbed kidnapper who keeps them captive in a garden shed, and their return, for the mother, to the life she knew before her captivity, and her son, fathered by her captor, going into the world for the first time. Although in the end they adjust a little too quickly to normal life. In a real case, the lasting scars would probably have far more after-effects.

Even the idea of this actually happening shreds me to the core; yes somewhere, sometime this could have happened :(

I love that the movie was completely from the perspective of the child... the story doesn't shift even in the 3rd act, Ma faints and goes to hospital, we still stay with the kid.

The performance, my god was Brie astounding in every single frame with a wide range of emotions, where was this Brie in Captain Marvel. Her acting felt so real that I could relate so much of a similar person with similar emotions of distress.

The shooting done is the Room was very smart, they captured the essence pretty well. Even in later house, the close door cinematography was done with great angles of stairs.

Its the little things that I loved, learning to walk down the stairs, world outside being TV, the attention to details. Movie starts with Goodmorning and ends with Bye Bye.
The thrill that was involved in the escape sequence was perfect.

I love that they didn't waste time on things that I thought they would, 'oh whole 2hr movie is ganna take place in a Room... nope' , 'oh the other half will be about finding the Ma... nope' realistic use of Satallite to find the truck, fabulous writing of 3 Stop Sign. The movie was grounded in reality, hence I love it so much.

The characters had great progression, she would definitely have this kind of reaction given the trauma of being 'Thankful' to others. Her trying her best for the child, breastfeeding till 5 years and understanding she isn't a good Ma, but still HIS Ma.

Idea of long hair being Strength and the whole outside World being TV, beauty of storytelling.
Really good! The acting is incredible!  The story was well written.  We didnt expect much but my wife and I really were pulled in from the start to the end.

me dejó verdaderamente perplejo, porque su arco argumental y en si toda su aura es muy tensionante para la persona que la esté viendo. Desde que empieza la película te estás preguntando qué es lo que pasará y te sientes sofocado por el poco espacio y por el diseño de producción. (Que es muy bueno)
Transcurriendo el primer acto yo ya me había estresado y por poco la dejaba de ver de lo buena que está filmada esta y de lo envolvente que es. Las actuaciones son impecables,  Brie Larson se merece el Oscar de mejor actriz porque en ningún momento se sale de su personaje y puedes sentir empatía por lo que le está pasando y de la culpabilidad que ella siente al recordar lo que hiso en el cuarto. La actuación de Jacob Tremblay es increíble también; son los actores los que hacen que esperes el "basado en hechos reales" al final, porque te hacen ver que esto pudo haber sido es real, y cuando no ves ese letrero al final te quedas con la satisfacción de que viste una buena película con muy buenas actuaciones. 
 Esta película me destruía me soltaba y me volvía a destruir con cada giro que daba, y eso fue lo que hiso que no la disfrutara del todo, el estar preocupado por lo que pasará, tanto así que no me pude concentrar en el presente, y esa sensación de solo poder relajarme cuando empezaran los créditos no es placentera. 
Cerca de la mitad del segundo acto, me estaba preguntando porque la película no había acabado ya, si ya habían cerrado todas las tramas, pero no, tenían que seguir haciéndome sufrir con una segunda trama que se desencadenaba de la primera. (Aclaro que no estoy diciendo que fue innecesaria, al contrario, está fue lo que necesitaba para finalizar con la película por completo. La razón por la que sufrí fue por el aura tan tensionante que ya explique antes)
En conclusión esta película está hecha para sacar los peores pensamientos de la gente (así fue conmigo y ninguna otra película lo había logrado hasta ahora), el diseño de producción y las actuaciones son impecables.
I put this movie on the shelf for a long time. I really slept on this one because it instantly became one of my favorite movies of all time.
Excellent acting and story
Excellent. Heart breaking and realistic look at a case involving kidnapping.

Update : I just watched the trailer and about 2/3 of it are not in the movie! I changed my review to 2 1/2 stars
It is a very good movie but the payoff is a little weak… Who else is with me when I say that I wanted to see the perpetrator get any kind of punishment or justice? And although the mother was imprisoned for seven years, she not only could have devised Way more plans of escaping the shed, but also didn't do a great job raising a kid with hopes of one day getting away! Obviously being raped and imprisoned for that amount Or any time would drive you completely insane.... .... ...

Amazing, Sad and Incredible. It tells the story of a mom who been locked in a shed with her young son who never saw the world what’s it like for 5 years. They escape and the boy experiences what the outside look like to see the nature and family. It’s a great drama that we could watch. Super tearjerking.

This movie deserves five stars for the first half of the movie. The second half is a bit slow and parts seem unneeded and other parts seemed like they could've been explored more, but all in all the first half of the movie is excellent. The story is heart wrenching, but still uplifting and the work done by Brie Larsen is incredible. Jacob Tremblay may be the best child actor we've seen this generation, but what puts the movie over the top for me is the writing. The writing is so realistic and sometimes even funny. This is a movie where somebody had a vision and just executed it perfectly every step of the process. It deserves a 91%.

This movie had a good storyline, good acting, and great potential. I enjoyed the idea of the movie, but it really lacked more. It lacked more action, it lacked more audience-grabbing scenes. Sure, it was moving and emotional but the bad part of this movie is that the action occurred WAY too early. After the climax of the movie, nothing interesting happened. I felt as if I wasted my time waiting for something interesting to happen, because nothing ever came. It was honestly disappointing, and I'd only watch it if you're a fan of being bored out of your mind.

A look at the guilt and shame that trauma brings and how we can adapt.  Deeply disturbing, but fantastic at the same time.  Cinematography was excellent too-- made good use of the small space in the beginning.
Amazing,from background score to acting to the screenplay,its a must watch
Caused a strong emotional response
Good movie. Great performances.
I just can't explain but it feels good after watching the movie.

Excellent film. The first half is difficult to watch, but well worth the effort. The second half which shows how the family piece their lives back together is superb. Normally with films in this genre they cut off once the situation is resolved, which seems daft to me... I'm much more interested in what happens afterwards. I was also happy that they didn't dwell on what happened to the kidnapper, I'm glad the film focused on the victims, not the perpetrator.

Still fresh. I've watched this film three or four times and find new things each time. Larson's performance will stand the test of time. I think it's a shame Tremblay did not receive more accolades as he is the heart and soul of this movie. An emotional treat.
Touching movie. Brie Larson's performance shows she is much better than Captain Marvel. Real emotional roller coaster

Good pacing, skilled actors (Jacob Tremblay is incredible.) Suspenseful and involving moments despite what one may think reading the description. Main climax happens mid-movie, so I wasn't expecting much after, however, it still managed intensity as good as the first half. Literally kept adding more until the last few mins. Well written, great dialogue. There are many themes in this movie, and all come together effortlessly, unlike a lot of films out there at the moment.
Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are a pure delight in their performances, which will make Room one of the greatest inspirations of the decade and will give an unforgettable experience in film history.

Except for two critical flaws, this would be a perfect film. Larson and Tremblay are perfect and Larson deserved the Oscar and perhaps Tremblay even more recogniton. 
Supporting cast, Allen and McManus were excellent. But ... first flaw, to interview a woman so quickly after she's been caged and raped every day for 7 years is ridiculous!! And then take the mother(who's just tried to kill herself after said interview) and 5 year old (who's healing) back to 'Room' just ruins everything .

Room is such a tense and cathartic movie. The movie is so immersive. You feel the pain in room right there with them. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are both amazing here. The movie is so emotional. There is so much going on here and the director make sure you feel all of it. It's like that from start to finish.

بعدما تمكن مغتصب مهووس من احتجاز فتاة لمدة ٥ أعوام كسجينة في "غرفة" ولدت فيها طفلها لتنشأ بينهما علاقة من نوع خاص حيث تكون هي كل حياته وتكون الغرفة هي كل عالمه، ليتمكن من الهروب بمساعدة من أمه وتختلط فيه مشاعر الخوف والإثارة والاكتشاف للعالم الخارجي يكل ما يحتوي من مفاجئات وتناقضات.
Brilliantly done, original and engrossing.
A captivating and suspenseful story with emotional depth.
Pretty good. Pretty good.
Beautiful movie! I wish it was PG-13 so kids could experience it.
I've never seen a script as different as this, a film very well done

This movie is amazing. It wants you to understand the situations of the characters. At first, we all have the same thoughts about what is going to happen during the movie, but there is a surprising twist in between that is unexpected and then you want to finish the movie. It makes you think about future situations and scenarios. It's truly a beautiful and sentimental movie. A definite must-watch.

The room was a movie that caught me off gaurd, it was an amazing story of the bound between a mother and her son. There were some tense scenes in it and the story was perfecly brought to live by the amazing acting! Awesome movie!
Was emotional and beautiful.

Room is a superbly constructed heartwrencher with despair, hope and love. Larson and Tremblay are on top form, without outstanding performances as young Mum and son. A film that thinks outside the box while being in the box.
the film is boring at first, but then it becomes compelling and in the end it was pleasant to see
100000000% chance of heart break

This is a brilliant film, it makes you feel for the characters and actually care for what happens. For over an hour film I did believe it would be set in one place but very pleased you got too see the whole story. It's was very moving and makes you understand what people in these situations could/do go through 10/10

Undeniably stunning performances from both Brie Larson & Jacob Tremblay.
Deeply moving
It was very good acting with good camera angles. I like how it made me cry and happy at the same time

Room is a claustrophobic, intense and sometimes upsetting film. This film combines these elements to make a worthwhile film about social issues, like kidnapping, rape, teenage mothers and in some scenes family drama.

"to see the world within four walls"

Director: Lenny Abrahamson
Writers: Emma Donoghue (screenplay by), Emma Donoghue (based on the novel by)
Stars: Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, Sean Bridgers | See full cast & crew »
Genres: Drama | Thriller
Release Date: 3 March 2015
Runtime: 118 min

Storyline
ROOM tells the extraordinary story of Jack, a spirited 5-year-old who is looked after by his loving and devoted mother. Like any good mother, Ma dedicates herself to keeping Jack happy and safe, nurturing him with warmth and love and doing typical things like playing games and telling stories. Their life, however, is anything but typical--they are trapped--confined to a 10-by-10-foot space that Ma has euphemistically named Room. Ma has created a whole universe for Jack within Room, and she will stop at nothing to ensure that, even in this treacherous environment, Jack is able to live a complete and fulfilling life. But as Jack's curiosity about their situation grows, and Ma's resilience reaches its breaking point, they enact a risky plan to escape, ultimately bringing them face-to-face with what may turn out to be the scariest thing yet: the real world. 


Analysis of the caracters 

1)
Jack's 5th birthdayall takes place within 'Room' where he lives since he Washington born: a confined space with only a single skylight for daylight and no means of escape. For the mother, Joy, was abducted as a teen and locked away for sex in the style of the dreadful real-life . Jack is the (presumably) unintended result: a boy with no perception of the real world beyond his four single-sided walls and with the staunchly-held view that the things he sees on a flickering TV screen are in 'TV land' unreal.
2)
Ma is a young woman in her mid-twenties. She has a son named Jack, who is the result of a forced sexual encounter with Old Nick. While in "Room," Ma provides a relatively safe atmosphere for her son, Jack, putting his well-being before her own. As a result, Ma has a painful, rotting tooth for which she can get no treatment. She sometimes becomes quiet and retreats into herself, though most of the time she is able to put on a brave face for her son. However, Ma suffers from depression and suicidal thoughts and even tries to kill herself. She is clearly and understandably psychologically damaged by her trauma, but her love for Jack is strong and unbreakable.

I'm not the biggest fan of Brie Larson so I am not thrilled with the fact that she has a Best Actress Academy Award when the far more talented Judy Davis, Barbara Hershey and Eleanor Parker do not. I was pleasantly surprised by her performance in this film, although I do not think she is a patch on Charlotte Rampling in 45 Years (2015). The film as a whole is a decent little film that focuses on an emotionally heart wrenching experience and it's effect on the lives of what seem like very natural, realistic characters but it was hardly one of the best of 2015 and there are unfortunate weaknesses that the film's screenplay gives into.

In a small locked shed, Joy Newsome, Brie Larson, lives with her son Jack, Jacob Tremblay, because she is trapped by Old Nick, Sean Bridgers, the man who kidnapped her seven years previously and is the father of her son. When conditions begin to significantly worsen and Joy realizes her son is becoming more mature she begins to look for ways to escape. After devising a clever scheme involving her son faking his own death she is able to escape the room and is reunited with her mother Nancy, Joan Allen, who now lives with a new partner Leo, Tom McCamus. Joy struggles to adapt to normal life in the outside and after being asked an invasive question during an interview she attempts suicide. Eventually she is able to move past her trauma as her son becomes more comfortable with his new lifestyle and the two say goodbye to the room forever.

The opening scenes of the film are very good at setting up the abject horror of the situation that this very regular woman and her sweet young son are trapped in. It is hard not to feel sympathy for these people as you watch an innocent little boy struggle to comprehend what a man who is the closest thing he has to a father figure is doing to his mother. The film loses me slightly when the two leave the room as while I think Allen and McCamus are two fine actors I found that their characters were not used very well and the use of suicide just seemed a tad too much in a film that benefited from it's restraint in telling a difficult story. I felt a little sad as the film began to lose me because it set up such great expectations from it's beginnings but it struggles to smoothly transition to an uneven second half.

We see interviews that turn into interrogations, Joy's suicide attempt and her son trying to acclimate to his new environment with the help of his stepfather. I didn't need all of this to be thrown at me immediately and I think that Larson's performance erred the most here as she failed to carry a lesser screenplay through the end of the film. I wanted to see more of Allen and McCamus although their use in small doses probably benefits them because they feel like the realest characters in the film. Tremblay was grating at certain points for me and I could have used less of his voice over which seemed like a very obvious attempt to emotionally manipulate the audience. The best scenes come when Allen and Larson argue, they feel very Terms of Endearment (1983) and yet they were the most appealing and relatable moments in the film because they borrow some of the warmth and intelligence that the 1983 film has in spades.

I am rather shocked that this film managed to get a Best Picture nomination in a year that boasted The Lobster (2015), Carol (2015) and of course 45 Years. I can see why Larson received recognition and the screenplay has some bright spots but overall it's hardly a great film and certainly not one of the best of the year. The film is worth a viewing but it may not be emotionally effecting enough for the crowd looking for a decent weepie and it's not intelligent enough in it's examination of it's subject matter for a more cynical audience. On the whole a mediocre effort from a group of fairly talented people.

Room provides harrowing trauma and cathartic release.

Lenny Abrahamson's Room (2015) is a indie drama of massive heart and daunting terror. It is a bottle film with the majority shot in a single room, but Room creates an endlessly imaginative space for its actors and actresses to perform. Emma Donaghue's writing is adapted from her own novel with a stylish realism and incomparable thoughtfulness.

Director Lenny Abrahamson uses tight spaces to build suspense with a sense of frustration, anger, fear, and claustrophobia. He effortlessly invents new ways to shoot in a single set to constantly keep things interesting for the viewer. Room is beautifully directed and shot with intimate close-ups of tender moments between a captive mother and her son. Danny Cohen's cinematography ranges from creepy and horrifying to frightened and loving. The use of blue is quite affecting and magical in Room.

Every emotion is captured within Room as this film takes the world out of you trapping you in this tiny space with the cast and characters. With a run time of less than two hours, the film is not that long, but it feels like 3 hours. This is actually a fantastic thing for 2 reasons.

First, Room takes the time to flesh out its characters with tremendous depth and agony alike. You are witnessing their elongated captivity and innovative coping methods.

Secondly, Room bravely goes a step further than a story of captives, but dives into the perilous uncertain waters of survival after trauma. Room continues into their rehabilitation and into their reintegration back into society and the eternal struggle of those attempting to reclaim their lives and happiness after traumatic events.

Abrahamson crafted a dynamic of trust through his use of tender quiet space is impressive. Stephen Rennicks composed an astonishingly lovely score that just mesmerized me throughout Room's entire running time. I was not expecting such a stunning sympathy of empathy and understanding.

Room gifted us with dual magnificent acting roles for Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. 

Notably, Brie Larson is resplendent as Joy "Ma" Newsome. Her leading actress role is a true tour de force of human emotional range. Larson portrays a kidnapped woman with a clear understanding and respect for the female victims of sexual assault and rape. Her depiction of motherhood with all its joys, frustrations, fears, rage, patience, and kindness is remarkable unto itself. But, when you pit parenting against forced confinement, Larson evolves the role into a complex display of brave resistance that I found profoundly moving. Brie Larson encapsulated a brilliant dramatic performance for the ages in Room. I hope to see more affecting dramatic roles from Larson in the near future.

Similarly, Jacob Tremblay gives one of the finest performances from a child actor as Jack in Room. His nervous and indignant reactions to his constraint against his will is gripping. Tremblay displays a fervor for acting that I anticipate seeing again in his upcoming roles.

Lastly, Room features a few neat supporting roles. Sean Bridgers is creepy, unsettling, and disgusting as the rapist kidnapper Old Nick. William H. Macy has a heartfelt infuriating role as a disappointed and awkward father to Larson. On the other hand, Tom McCamus is excellent as the kindly father figure to Joy and the gentle grandfather figure to Jack. Finally, Joan Allen delivers a shocking performance as Joy's mother with a surprising level of authenticity and brutal honesty.

In all, Room is a harrowing experience to endure, but rewarding with its hopeful ending. The catharsis I felt by the finale of Room is something akin to euphoria and relief. Room is easily one of the greatest films ever made.

Warning:  This film and article contain references to explicit sexual content

As a young woman, a very present fear, often in the back of my mind, is of being abducted, molested or snatched from the safety of what I know and to be raped and murdered in a back alley.  I carry mace in my pocket when I walk down an unfamiliar street at night in New York City, where I live. Brie Larson (Trainwreck), in Room, is that girl our mothers feared we might become.

She encountered that strange man our fathers warned us about. By the time the film opens, she's been living as a captive in a single room for seven years, and every week she suffers nightly visits from her captor. She is so young, so painfully young. It's heart wrenching to know that her sufferings extend -even beyond rape- to being forced into a mockery of companionship with the man who stole her life.

Larson, Oscar winner for this role, does not play a majestic, longsuffering young mother in Room -- a character type we so often see in literature and film. Emma Donoghue, author of the original novel and the film's screenplay, has not given us a soft-spoken damsel. This woman does not have it all together, pressing on cheerfully despite her circumstances. She has sallow skin, bad teeth, and vitamin deficiency. She screams at the skylight and snaps at her son.

Larson's performance is noteworthy for how normal and unheroic she is. She didn't make me feel like I was watching a legendary role on the silver screen. She made me curl up in my seat, aching for this nameless young woman who is probably not so different from me.

Act One of Room lets that premise really soak in as we learn about "Ma" through the eyes of her newly-five-year-old son Jack (Jacob Tremblay, The Smurfs 2). This room, with its stove, single bed, and ancient TV, is the only world Jack has ever known. It's not "a" room or simply "this" room for him -- it is Room. Beyond Room is "outer space," and beyond that, "heaven" (where Jack came from, he explains).  

It was captivating to watch Jack, in the true spirit of childhood, go about his cramped routines in relative contentment. After all, he had no outside world to compare his life to. I wondered, in that situation, what would I have taught my son about the world? Would I have told him -- a child, who only understands by seeing and touching -- anything different?

As we get to know the routine of this tiny family, it's impossible not to feel gutted at the full life this young mother has somehow created for her son despite their prison. The "mom" part of my own brain immediately worried about how this boy could thrive on canned food -- but she makes sure their captor brings him vitamins and fresh fruit. She oversees exercise routines so that Jack's muscles grow strong. They do laundry together in the bathtub. She tucks him to sleep in the wardrobe on nights when "Old Nick" comes to stay in Ma's bed.

In a way, it was delightful and encouraging to see how innovative and committed she has been to raising her son to be strong and joyful. But only delightful like watching a flower bloom from wreckage of a nuclear disaster: so much agony underscores every smile, every sign of life.

The first half of the film shows Ma continuing in survival mode: concessions, abuse, frustrations, and failed escape attempts. But Jack is five now, Ma explains to him. She has reached her breaking point, and he is finally big enough to help them find their freedom.

As hard-hitting as Act One is, the film's latter half is a reminder that life can't be compartmentalized. Pain, ache, and regret doesn't just live in one room. So many escape films end with elation -- with that tearful moment of freedom and embrace. Room shows us how hard it is to build life after trauma and abuse. When everything is broken, it can't be fixed overnight.

Tremblay as Jack is an absolute light in this film. He's precocious and adorable, but also a raging ball of too many feelings for his tiny body (as all children are, at five years old). At one point, his Ma tries to explain to him the brutal reality of their situation, and the largeness of the world outside that he just can't comprehend. He looks into her face and protests, "I wanna be four again."

Oh, my heart. I know, Jack. Me too.

It feels hard to write the right kind of review for a movie like this. Maybe it's because Donoghue's story and script is not pretty, it's brutal. It's a terrifying glimpse into the rotten core of humanity, of what it looks like when we reach the end of ourselves. I've never reached anything like that kind of breaking point in my own life -- but I've still felt the sharp, needling sting of regret.

Room isn't all heartbreak and despair. It's also a testament to how we make each other stronger, how we aren't meant to go at it alone.

"I'm not a good enough Ma," she admits to Jack, running over all the could have, should have's in her mind.

"But you're Ma," he responds simply.

That small moment summed up the whole emotional experience of watching Room, in a way. We all deal with rotten luck and our own failures. There's no escaping either. But through it all, we're in it together. Healing hurts, but hope might be the most resilient player in the human story.

----------

I was beginning to lose faith in the Academy's selection capability considering I've only really liked 2 of the Best Pic nominees so far, or consider them worthy. "Room" is a traditional Academy darling, and rightfully so. It's dramatic, emotional, suspenseful and a phenomenal film. The story is intense and heartbreaking (times 4 or 5). The acting performances of Brie Larson and young Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscar recognition. While I haven't seen all the performances nominated thus far, young Jacob Tremblay is jaw-dropping. I was excited to see Brie Larson, one of my favorites, finally show her stuff, and that she did. I hope she gets the win. However, Jacob blew me away. There were no words to describe how incredible his performance is for someone so young. Better than any adult actor I've seen this year. I'm serious. There is an incredible career in the making there. The screenplay, based on the novel of the same name, is beautiful. Aside from one scene that bugged me a little, the dialogue is so real. The director did a masterful job pulling the screenplay, performances and the perspective of "Room" against the much larger world Brie and Jacob are denied for so long. I'm so glad at least 3 of the 8 Best Pic nominees are worthy.

I believe two of the best performances of the year were captured in Room. (Sorry, pun sort of intended) Jacob Tremblay should have been nominated for best actor and I think Brie Larson is a shoe in for best actress. Hell, I think even Joan Allen should have been considered. Room is about a woman who was abducted and held for seven years, and how she copes on a daily basis while taking care of her 5-year-old son. With this premise I thought the movie would surely be dark and grim, but on the contrary I think *hopeful* is the best way to describe it. There are plenty of instances of levity, especially from Tremblay, and even some parts to smile and cheer at. Make no mistake it does have tension. There is a scene in the back of a truck where I dared not take a breath. Of course a part of the movie focuses on dealing with post-traumatic stress and the effects it has on people around you. Remember, all Jacob's character has ever known in life was "Room" and I thought the director and actor both did a marvelous job showcasing what kind of impact that has.

Room (2015) delivers a captivating mother-son relationship, thanks to outstanding performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, that is genuine and emotionally powerful. Despite its bleak and shockingly tragic story, the film flourishes with its incredibly touching moments of optimism and heart. Stephen Rennick's score is a gem. A must-watch.
Perfectly well constructed, this masterpiece represents all the values like freedom and love perfectly well mixed with a nice performance.

My all-time favorite movie. I was hit with raw emotion and reality that I wasn’t prepared for. Wonderfully shot, incredible acting, Room is a movie that will make you thankful for the life that you have as matters could be much much worse. I also recommend reading the book-the adaptation is incredible. I read the book after I saw the movie and I thought it was better as I didn’t know what was in store for me watching the movie. Room is now my fav movie, HIGHLY recommend:)

No me la esperaba como es, y me ha sorprendido gratamente. Al principio desconcertante, se va volviendo poco a poco más interesante, hasta que te engancha. Ahora, el tercio final es algo flojo en comparación con el resto de la película, y esa parte se hace un pelín larga

I didn't find this film all that realistic. If a mouse can find its way in, seems that a woman and a boy could have found their way out easily. It just didn't work for me. Escaping from bad parents though, that is hard. They keep bringing you back!

20 minutes in I was bored, literally was about to turn the movie off and something finally started to happen and ended up being one of the best movies I have seen in a while, Brie Larson gives one of the best all time performances in movie history. Marvel is lucky to have her
Amazing and beautiful story superbly acted. Deep. Emotional. Powerful. Authentic.

ROOM is not a movie for the faint of heart; although it isn't as difficult as it needs to be, it's still an emotional rollercoaster with great performances throughout. But Brie Larson is the star here- such a committed and convincing performance with so many ups and downs in emotion is awesome to watch; she thoroughly deserved her Best Leading Actress Oscar and cements her position as one of the finest actors of my generation.
This movie is just heartbreaking.  I get why Brie Larson won an Academy award but it is a shame that Jacob Tremblay didnt win one as well.  He carried the movie for me.
Both Brie and Jacob were amazing in this film.

a very good movie that could've been great with the right director.  While abrahamson does a fine job with very hard material, i wonder what this movie what have looked like in the hands of danny boyle or the like
Excellent, intimate, storytelling.
Phenomenal performance from the two leads.
A compelling tale between a mother and child lost from society only found into nowhere.

Strengths: This was quite the harrowing film. Seeing how Joy (Brie Larson) lives in a tiny room for years with her son is rough enough, but when we see that Old Nick (Sean Bridgers), their captor, returns almost nightly to continue raping Joy, it hits another level. Add in that Jack (Jake Tremblay) is in the closet when these things happen and it becomes extra rough to sit through. The story and script are both high points, but the real success of the movie comes from the performances of Larson and Tremblay. Tremblay does very well for someone his age. Meanwhile, Larson absolutely deserved that Oscar she won for this. She looked the part of someone who had experienced these things. The buildup to their escape was exceptionally done, as was the escape itself. The cinematography and direction are both tremendous. They give this film a unique feel that perfectly matches the story.

Weaknesses: As much as I enjoyed the back half of the film, it lacks the tense and gripping feel of the first half. You're on the edge of your seat as they try to escape the room and overjoyed when they do. Watching them adapt to the world around them is interesting, but doesn't hold you as well as the first half. The storyline surrounding Joy's father (William H. Macy) had potential, but disappeared. He's happy his daughter returned, but won't even look at Jack, most likely because he was conceived through rape. There was some good tension in the second half with that scene and I'd have loved to see more of Macy and Larson going at it. Instead, once he leaves that scene, he never returns and it feels like a missed opportunity. 

Overall: An emotionally gripping story led by phenomenal performances from the leads. The survival aspects of the first half are the best part. A second half with more of a battle between Joy and her father would've been ideal. However, the post-room stuff is still very good, making for a great all around film.

Puntaje Original: 8.5

Room es una obra maestra, de las mejores películas del 2015, una historia tan atrapante como conmovedora, hermosa en todo sentido, con una actuación impecable de Brie Larson, Room alcanza la cúspide de la excelencia de éste año.

More Room to Love
	Room is a stunning and heart-wrenching drama about a young mother trying to raise her 5-year-old son in a traumatic situation. Ma (Brie Larson) and her son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) endure unimaginable trials together, proving how strong the bond between a mother and her child can be.
	Ma and Jack's situation is slowly revealed to us in pieces through Jack's perspective. As we gain more information about Room, the tiny space Jack and his Ma are confined to, we discover they are being held captive by a man called "Old Nick". He kidnapped Ma long ago, and she has matured into an adult and a mother in Room. Old Nick is a typical abusive kidnapper type, but his violence toward Ma is devastating from Jack's perspective.
Ma does everything in her power to keep Jack safe. When Old Nick moves to touch Jack, Ma fights fiercely to protect Jack, showing how strong her love for him is. She does whatever she can to shield Jack from the realities of their captivity, including telling him stories to explain away their horrible situation. It works to keep Jack safe and satisfied until she realizes their survival depends on their escape. It then proves to be more difficult than she expected to get Jack to give up the cozy stories she told him. When Ma finally convinces him that there is a world outside of Room, the movie reaches a pivotal climax. The fate of Ma and Jack rests on Jack's shoulders, relying on the strength of their bond to save them.
The second half of the movie is very different. They escape from Old Nick, but adjusting to freedom proves to be more difficult than attaining it. This is where the strength of their bond is truly tested. Jack has never been exposed to anything in the real world, and Ma desperately wants to go back to the way things were before she was kidnapped. Devastatingly, they begin to drift apart as their individual challenges divide them. It isn't clear if their tight-knit bond will remain outside of Room. Jack sees Ma is struggling and asks Ma's mother, "Can my strong be her strong too?" She responds with what I think defines the central theme of the film, saying "Of course it can. We all help each other be strong."
Some might say that Room's second act is unnecessary. I would argue that Room's second act is the most important, and the film would lose a crucial part of the story without it. Often a kidnap drama is resolved as soon as the protagonist goes free. They rarely go beyond that to tell us what happens next. Room provides a deep and critical exploration of what happens to Ma and Jack in the second act. It suggests that the most important challenge for them to overcome isn't the kidnapping at all; it's figuring out how to be normal again. This leads to meaningful discoveries for both characters, and through their growth, the audience grows too.
As heartbreaking as much of the film is, the ending is intensely satisfying. It is more rewarding because of how Ma and Jack are challenged. By exemplifying the strength of love, Room reminds us to be thankful for what we have and love a little more fiercely.

Deeply moving without false sentiment -- I sobbed uncontrollably several times. The connection between Ma and Jake is, of course, deep, and it comes off as totally believable. The second half of the film explores the complex emotions which come from the resolution of such an ordeal. It isn't all ice cream and rainbows.

Larson and Tremblay are remarkable. It's a good thing the producers found Tremblay, because this movie would've fallen flat without a believable child in a difficult-to-portray role. And Larson was just masterful.

The overwhelming majority of us will never endure what Room's protagonists endured, but I think Room helps us ponder what it means to be human in the face of such depravity and isolation.

1. Best Movie of 2015 
2. One of the Best movies of All Time

Fantastic acting and a great script make this one of the most unusual films of recent years. One shouldn't spoil too much about the plot, but it says a lot that a film can easily have its climax in the middle of the story and still lose no intensity in the second half, easily keeping the audience's attention for the aftermath. Engaging, moving and honest.

Jack, a little boy, has only ever lived in a small shed with his Ma and to him it's his whole universe. When they finally manage to escape their confinement Jack finally learns about the world outside of his small room. 
This is a truly fantastic film and a lot of it rests on the 2 main actors performances. Brie Larson is simply amazing as Ma/Joy, who is a captive and mother who manages to protect her son from the horrors of the world around him. Larson's performance has a great deal of intensity, strength and vulnerability and really draws you into the plot and emotion of the film. Jacob Tremblay is also fantastic as Jack, capturing the fantasy of his little world and the fear and intrigue outside it. The two also have excellent chemistry together and form a really strong but somewhat complex Mother Son relationship that is very captivating.
This is a film about captivity like no other, rather than exploiting its characters or focussing on the horror aspect of its narrative, the main focus of the film is the bond between Mother and Son and how their realities shift inside and outside of the room. 
The cinematography in this film is excellent. We, the audience, experience a lot of the narrative through Jack's eyes and the camera work reflects this through its use of tight close ups and steady cam shots and in how it manages to make a tiny shed seem expansive and not at all claustrophobic. The juxtaposition of sound, colour and light between the room and the outside world is also excellent and really highlights Jack's otherworldly experience. The musical score also adds a lot to the film in its more emotional moments.
The plot is also well told, initially only showing and not telling and leaving the interpretation to the viewer and later filling in the blanks with some exposition. However there are some scenes where the dialogue is too expository and there is a bit too much of an information dump. 
This is a very well told, immersive film that focuses on its characters, their emotions and their relationships with one another and is very moving experience overall.

5/5.  The first half of Room is pure nightmare fuel, and the second half is about coming back from the nightmare.  Both halves are incredibly compelling, thanks the phenomenal performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay.  Together, they make this harrowing tale one of the best films of 2015.

This was exceptional.  To see someone's reality like this is powerful.  Both Brie and Jacob did a fantastic job.  I don't know how anyone could survive something like that.  It is very unnerving to think that things like this actually happen.
Just sad in a good way
Powerfully acted and moving; Room is an emotionally satisfying experience.

An emotional and heartwarming story of a mom and her son. I loved every bit of this film! Not only is the story itself simple and genius, but the execution was flawless. It could have been so easy to turn this film into misery porn. But instead the filmmakers made the right choice and coated the movie with a blanket of hope. It was sad when it needed to be sad, happy when it needed to be happy, and even funny at some points. The performances from Brie L. and Jacob T. were phenomenal! The two of them really held this film together. I couldnt love this movie more! A+!
