If there's any way you can see this film without knowing a single thing about it, I think you could have a truly amazing experience.  Unfortunately, I was aware of some of the things that were happening, which would have been a delightful surprise to discover.  I open with this because I want to urge you all, if you know nothing about Room, then make sure you stay that way and go see this film. The less you know when you walk in on that day will make the movie that much more exciting.  Spoilers from here on:  I loved the performances from all the actors in this film.  The 2 leads (mother and son) were particularly amazing.  The first half of the film was gut-wrenching and left me in despair, as is intended.  This also made the transition point in the middle of the film, the escape, one of the most heart-pounding and intense things I've ever sat through in a theater.  It was one of those scenes where I almost couldn't contain myself and wanted to shout at the character on screen.  It's after this point that I had the most difficulty with Room.  The pace, and intensity dropped off precipitously when they left Room.  While everything felt very genuine and realistic, and I totally cared about the characters still, the dramatic change in tone was hard to adjust to that quickly.  It basically walks you through how, despite physically being free, they were still mentally trapped in Room.  It's so tough because, like the main character, I assumed freedom would mean an instant big happy ending to the film, but that's not reality.  Room is a superb film that has dark events and themes, and yet manages to hold an underlying message of hope despite devastating circumstances.

It mirrors the real-life abduction stories such as Joseph Fritzel who kept a lady captive for several years.
In this film the setting is the United States. A woman called Joy Newsome (Brie Larson) and her son live the best way they can in a metal shed with just a single skylight being their only contact with the outside world. To them it is simply called 'room'.
The cast give excellent performances to make what could be a simple television drama into a major film.
William H. Macy makes an appearance as the woman's father. 
The second and third acts of the film show the Newsome's adjustment  to life outside the room after an audacious escape.

An emotionally touching experience, Room is a demanding but completely rewarding drama describing the endless love between a mother and a child. Dark, frustratingly depressing at moments and capable of making you feel uncomfortable, this movie offers a formidable dramatic challenge which grows into a thoughtful character study.

The story of a young kidnapped girl (Brie Larson) and her young boy kept in captivity could not be less than uncomfortable and hart-to-chew. From the first moments, the audience will be compelled to follow how Joy managed to survive so many years being locked in a room and to raise a boy. The slow, detailed revelation of the true situation works formidably on the audience as it meticulously builds-up the story into the second part of the movie. The second half might be a less thrilling one, but if offers an intriguing character study of how Joy and Jack cope with the freedom and the return to the society. That is also the most polarizing part of Lenny Abrahamson's movie. If you are impressed with the first half, then the second one will certainly feel less satisfying. Personally, I would have preferred to have the whole movie focused on the "Room" rather than part of it.

The weaker second half is, however, compensated by the wonderful performances of Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. Both of them were worthy of receiving Oscar nominations, and the young Larson even snapped the Best Actress Award. Her extremely believable performance, her struggle to get used to freedom and her almost aggressive and uncontrollable love for her boy are contributing greatly to the overall high emotional load in the movie. On the hand, Jacob Tremblay's performance is outstanding as well. His young age probably deprived him from obtaining a nomination but his fascinating presence as Jack certainly puts him among the list of top kids-actors to be followed.

In conclusion, Room is a must see delivery. Not only because of the Oscar-winning performance of Brie Larson, but also because of the compelling and uneasy story , and wonderful screenplay.

Electrifying, gut-wrenching, yet deeply satisfying with subtleties. Easily the best drama of 2015.

The subtleties of this film are twofold: one is maternal love based on instinct, not reasons, and the inseparable connection between the two souls. Through Room, I particularly loved how the maternal love was portrayed more than just how a mother can be protective of her son, but it also shapes her into what she is: I just couldn't imagine how Joy's life, and identity for that matter, would look like without Jack in that room. The second layer of subtleties is our well familiar "world" but as seen from a uniquely fresh perspective of a five-year-old who didn't know it "existed." All these were achieved by the genius adaptation of the namesake novel and the incredibly visceral performance of Brie and Jacob.

Brie, I honestly didn't believe that you were just 26 (or even younger at the time of shooting)! How could a woman your age portray this complex character with such deep emotions and subtleties? Just brilliant, very brilliant, indeed. I'd be disappointed if you don't get the Oscar."

There isn't much action in the film, and the first part (which all takes place in the room) is pretty hard to watch. However, once we enter the world, things get significantly better. In Room, Ma (Brie Larson) and her 5 year old son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) escape from a room where they had been held captive for a long time (Jack  for his whole life and Ma for seven years). We follow them as Jack discovers, explores, and has to adapt to a world he didn't even know existed till now, and Ma struggles with her increasingly fragile mental state. Brie Larson does a great job, Joan Allen as her mother was fantastic, but Jacob Tremblay easily steals the entire show. I'd go so far as to say he was the best performance I've seen this year (It's a joy to watch him discover this new world for the first time). We also spend the most time with Jack as he is our eyes and ears into the movie, and he is the main character here. Room is a gentle, loving, sad, and life affirming film. It's easily one of the year's best (It's also easily the most emotional film of the year), and while it is super slow I will say it is most definitely worth a watch.

Touching movie about young mother and her 5 years old son that being kept for 7 years in the shed. How innocent the boy is when he first came out and realize that his space is bigger than his room, called the world.

The film's thematic elements may be dark. But that is all balanced out by the electrifying performances of Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay as it also portrays the resilience of the human spirit in the midst of a horrifying human condition. Confined in a room for seven years, the film tells the loving story between a mother and her 5-year-old son and their desire for freedom. (Much more happens in the film. But in the interest of not giving out any spoilers, I will leave it at that.)

This is the first feature film for child actor Jacob Tremblay. His performance is magnificent and one of the best in recent years for someone of his age.

The film beautifully captures the family dynamics of not only between mother and son but also the immediate family when a child is suddenly abducted. Thankfully, many of us will never be in this situation. But what gives this film its weight is the striking enactment of the aftermath and emotions when placed in such a situation, which are engrossing and deeply moving.

"Room" is captivating as it tells its daunting story through the eyes of a five-year-old as much as it does from its adult victim.

How strong is a mother's bond with her child? In the worst circumstances a mother will do her best to make a child's life as fulfilling as possible. Brie Larsen plays a mother who is held captive with her son for many years and one day she wonders what it would mean to find their lives outside their myopic world. Yet to Jason Tremblay the resilience of youth expands the world to meet his imagination. It is a double tour de force out of two people fully connected in performance. Room takes you places you will find cringeworthy yet the story is about resilience and the power love has to give. You could not ask for a better motion picture experience. I will definitely need to read the book at some point. And the next time your see your mother, give her a big hug!

Movies that aim to garner empathy often come up short because the stories are not believable or the narrative is off the mark. Room, however, never tries to dig deeper than the trenches our main characters find themselves in. It's a small-scale landscape both in form and structure, one that is very effective due to leads Brie Larson and nine-year-old Jacob Tremblay. It's a touching story that will no doubt leave an impression on the viewer.

Absolutely gut-wrenchingly full of emotive feelings not only given from the extremely harsh plot, but more from both Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. Incredible performances in such a small place that it makes your heart both hurt and beat quicker than ever.

How many times in your life have you been forced to finish a bad movie, book, or story, all the while just wishing it would end? Rarely is that longing as desperate in our reality as it is for the characters in Room. When Jack screams at his Ma, "I want a different story!", you know there's more to it than just a hunger for a different bedtime yarn. Her response, "No! This is the story you get!", punctuates their situation, and ultimately our own desires, with such force it nearly knocked me out. Room, a powerhouse of horrifying drama and real-life suspense, breaks out from its confining premise with enough gentle moments of love to make it one of the year's best.
If you can't tell, I'm being careful with the details of the plot. However, know that it's a setup that's about as bleak as one can imagine. Director Abrahamson (maker of the criminally underrated Frank) creates an atmosphere of intensely palpable desperation in his small sets. In lesser hands, Room could've been either an oppressively gloomy downer or dishonestly optimistic hack-job. Instead, it's both strikingly candid and beautifully grace-filled
This compassion for its subjects is thanks in no small part to the much-deserved-Oscar-nominated Larson, and young actor Tremblay. His character, in particular, presents such a powerful look at childish naïveté, he gives us one of the most amazing examples childhood trauma and perseverance I've ever seen. That theme (determination through suffering) creates an experience that harbors as much exhilaration as it does tears. Piercing and gut-wrenching, Room is a film you may want to escape, but will be glad you endured.

At this point, I believe Room is the best film of 2015. It's emotionally jarring, and anxiety ridden. Jacob Tremblay gives arguably the greatest performance from a child actor that I have ever witnessed. This kid deserves his accolades, and truly should have been nominated for an Oscar. His performance was so mind boggling honest, it left me in awe.

What would you do if you were kidnapped at 17, enslaved for the next 7 years, repeatedly raped and had a child as a consequence? How would it feel if the only world you have ever known in your short five years of life was contained in a single room? And how would the world look if you ever found your way out? This story is one of extraordinary bravery, survival and coming to terms with the only reality you are allowed to have. The performances are truly brilliant, especially from young Jacob whose performance reminds me of young Anna Paquin when she won her Oscar for The Piano.
Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give phenomenal performances and the story is brilliant.

Based on a bestselling Emma Donnaghue novel, Room (not to be confused with the cult B-movie THE Room) tells the morbid story of a young woman who was kidnapped, held inside a small, soundproof dungeon of a room, raped, and gave birth to her captor's child.  The film opens up in medias res with this young mother in her seventh year of captivity, trying to survive in squalid conditions with her young son and teach him about a world he has never seen.  The first act shows some of the most claustrophobic and focused filmmaking this year.  We are stuck with these characters in this doomed situation, with only hints of the outside world.  Brie Larson impresses us as the young woman who was denied years of her life and we see how her imprisonment and its aftermath have worn on her.  Jacob Tremblay also deserves some recognition for convincingly playing a boy who has never traveled more than five feet from where he was born and never met a person other than his mother.  Room loses steam toward the end and fails to recapture the engrossing magic that had us at the edge of our seat for the first 35 minutes, but it still has a simple and definitive end that most awards season fare denies the audience.  A must see.

ROOM Review - Jack Fitzpatrick

Simply put, "Room" is an emotional film. And it seems as though half the time you do not even know what you're feeling. Seamlessly the film manages to portray happiness in a tragic way, depressingly dark situations yet also present some optimism and make you feel genuinely scared and/or worried about its fictional characters. Room is emotional in a very real sense; it's not just another movie where a romance falls apart, or where a loved one gets a terminal illness and it doesn't tug on your heart strings with cheap bullshit. Room doesn't try to trick you into feeling things, its realistic tone and grim story is enough. Not to make light of the cinematography, music or any of anything else which made the film, these are all good too, however we are really in this one for the writing and acting; the story and characters. 
The film follows its protagonists as they live their day to day lives trapped inside a small dirty room with no way out. Locked in by a nameless man that they call 'Old Nick,' (Who by the way totally looks like Will Ferrell's cousin or something...) The characters are a mother and son 'Jack,' 'Ma' has been inside this room for seven years and her son has never experienced anything beyond the room in his life. For around half of the movie we stay in the room with these characters, we as an audience never leave the room until the characters do. Personally I was beginning to feel the claustrophobia myself, the movie makes you feel as trapped as the characters are. The room feels hopeless as it does small and the atmosphere is actually quite haunting. 
Now though, that Jack is five years old, Ma believes that it's now time and that he is finally old enough to help her make their escape. Through a series of events, the two do make it out of the room, however we are still only about half way through the film as we follow their lives after leaving 'room.' 
The films point of no return; leaving 'room' is both scary and cheerful for both us and the characters in the film. The juxtaposition of being stuck in the room and the freedoms of such an open and unknown world is mind blowing. Yet, before they leave and it is uncertain whether they will succeed or not, you almost don't want them to try. Jack pleads his mother to wait till he is six years old and this is a terrifying theme throughout the film; Comfort and security over freedom. Jack's life and world may have been horrible, however the thought of leaving was frightening and almost made no sense to Jack. 
The movie manages to portray a horrible situation without feeling like a cheap horror movie, this is to be taken seriously and manages to portray despicable acts and conditions of the characters, without reverting to gross out moments or cartoonish dark villains. The villain of the film, is definitely disgusting and hateable, but ultimately is not the point of the film. The maturity of the film dealing with a sickening character and subject is appreciated. 
Another running theme of this film was the experience - or really inexperience of five-year-old Jack. He'd never known anything beyond this one room his entire life, basically; 'room' was his world. And this is such an interesting concept to me. Jack's concepts of fiction and reality blur and at such an age he is vulnerable to information. It's important to learn the truth however almost incomprehensible due to his extremely limited knowledge. 

Possibly my favourite shot of the film, has Jack creating shadows with his hands in the partial sunlight that comes through via sunlight. This shot has obvious relation to 'The Allegory of the Cave' philosophical theory. Put simply, if a caveman never leaves his cave, and all he ever sees are shadows, this is what he believes in, this becomes his reality. And the same goes for the child in the film. 'Room' is all he knows, and beyond stories he's told or what he sees on their television, Jack's sense of reality is inaccurate. He knows about animals such as dogs and cats, he knows about grass and trees and he knows about general bits of information, however due to his isolation he cannot separate reality from fiction and therefore will not know which things are real and which are not. A dragon for example is as real or fake as a dog in his mind. 
The themes throughout the film and the emotion that these themes bring are all portrayed through the actors; who all did a fine job, but the performance that really stood out was child actor Jacob Tremblay as Jack. Children are often not the best actors, they're still young; still learning, but this kid is ahead of his time, ahead of his age really. For such a thematically complex film as well as a mature and grim one, Tremblay did an amazing job making me believe in his character, as well as his collaboration with Brie Larson as mother and son, their relationship is strong and convincing. This would also be thanks to upcoming director Lenny Abrahamson whom I've never seen any works by, however this seems to be an early work of a promising career. (He also directed "Frank," and "What Richard Did."
The film gave me chills when it needed to in moments of pure intensity the beautiful moments were made that much nicer in comparison to the dreary and depressing ones. It even gave me a new perspective on the world and the way we might look at it. What if we are all experiencing some version of Jack and Ma's 'room?' But, this is just a movie review, I don't want to get too philosophical. 

"Room" is saddening yet uplifting. It may be hard to watch for some yet I'd think also hard to stop watching, and overall the film has the ability to change ones' perspective. "Room" is shocking, yet beautiful and most of all unforgettable.  This is Drama at its' best.             10/10

I remember seeing a trailer for "Room" months back in 2015 and being almost entirely mystified; it looked like a strange, almost ethereal mix of drama and science-fiction that even the trailer couldn't adequately communicate. Not until seeing it, I realized that this is a film that isn't easy to summarize in a brief two minute trailer, and I'll undoubtedly struggle to illustrate the film's genius with its review. This is the kind of film one needs to experience and feel; a film where words often feel either exaggerating or shortchanging in attempting to illustrate the film's emotional power and exceptional narrative.

Simply put, "Room" is the emotional moviegoing experience of the season. A deeply moving film that combines the aforementioned genres of drama and science-fiction, "Room" is the kind of film that hits you with its most powerful shot after you walk out of the theater or turn off the TV. It lingers in your mind and the characters, their motivations, their conversations, their struggles, and their thoughts don't escape you, unlike most dramas, where character names are probably not even remembered by most following the end credits.

The film opens with a young mother named Joy (Brie Larson) and her small child named Jack (Jacob Tremblay), who live their life in an enclosed garden shed of about one-hundred square feet and their only available sunlight is a skylight. They eat, sleep, bathe, and cook in there, and for Jack, it's the only life he has come to know. At first, their routine actions and close relationship lead one to believe that they've chosen this life in order to free themselves from the constraints of society. However, we see the horror of their reality soon enough. 

Seven years ago, Joy was tricked and kidnapped by a man known as "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers), who raped her and had her give birth to Jack. Since then, she has lived inside this closed space; it isn't until their escape-plan is successful that Joy goes back to her mother and father and Jack finally experiences the outside world. Previously, Jack believed, largely in part of his mother, who tried to make their life seem a lot less hellish, that outside of the four walls of "room," as they referred to it, was outer space. The people on TV were just flat, and nothing else besides them and Old Nick existed. 

Upon finally escaping and trying to return to a life that seems brand new to them, Joy struggles to get Jack to assimilate to the world. His entire life was predicated upon just him and his "Ma," as he was largely kept hidden in the closet whenever Old Nick would come pay them a visit. Now, he must be socialized into the world at age five, and learn that there is not only a larger life, but a larger world outside of "room." His mother, on the other hand, must grapple with her demons that have haunted her since she was captured.

If you look at "Room" from the perspective of Joy, you find a drama about being re-socialized into the world after living your entire life in captivity. It's a familiar story, but one that is truly sad and potent, and Brie Larson brings such life and emotion to the role for a woman so young (her precocious acting reminds me quite a bit of Jennifer Lawrence). However, if you look at the film through Jack's perspective, you see a film that plays with the realm of science-fiction. While nothing about "Room" deals with supernatural or "the unknown" in a grandiose sense, we do have a character who has never experienced life first-hand and sees everything around him not only as foreign but, for lack of a better term, alien. 

This results in a film that's very lucid and ethereal, largely in part because of Lenny Abrahamson's (who directed 2014's "Frank," a strong film dealing with mental illness) unique direction and cinematographer Danny Cohen's dreamlike grasp on reality. These beautiful and immersive aesthetic choices make the world and everything we take for granted and overlook on a daily basis look as if it's an unearthly object, with extreme close-ups and high-contrast depictions employed by Abrahamson. 

"Room" is a film largely bent on repetition; everything from Joy and Jack's daily actions in "room," Jack's attempts to socialize with other adults, Joy's attempt to come to terms with returning to her old life, and more are all showcased as recurring events in the film. This slowburn narrative tactic allows character motivations and interest to rise and boil accordingly, creating a film that turns impacting and even emotional when bigger, more elaborate events occur (the truck scene may be one of the best sequences I've seen in film last year). With all that and more considered, "Room" is a wonderful treat of a film; one that will hit everyone differently in a sense that it's not a matter of if it will resonate with you but how it will eventually manage to do so.

Beautiful story telling.  Both this film and The Revenant are about resilience and the power of the human spirit to overcome, but the way that theme is portrayed here is a polar opposite of how it is dealt with in The Revenant.  Brie Larson gives a performance that encompasses the intensity of her character's trauma, but does so with admirable subtlety rather than scenery chewing grand moments and demonstrates remarkable dignity and a sad sort of maturity that seems to be ingrained in the character due to the terrible events she lived with for seven years.  The character and Larsen's performance reminded me very much of the kind of work we have seen from Mary Louise Parker.  Jacob Trembley is brilliant as her five year old son.  I do not know if the child was just that amazing an actor or if it involved excellent directorial and editing skills, but his performance is flawless.  He carries the same sense of quiet about him that Larson does as his Mother, which demonstrates a detailed consistency that is spot on considering he only knew her and one place for the first five years of his life.  The score is also perfectly subtle and reflects the feeling of the film brilliantly.  The supporting cast of Joan Allen, William H. Macy, and Tom McCamus were also strong and their performances are consistent with the subdued intensity that characterizes the entire movie.  This across the board consistency in all aspects of the film, from the colors, to the music, to the performances is what makes this such a standout work of movie making.  It would have been easy to fall into soapy territory, but it never goes there.  It is just pure storytelling with a director who very clearly had a vision of how he wanted this story told and carried out his vision down to even the smallest details.  Excellent work.

I was beginning to lose faith in the Academy's selection capability considering I've only really liked 2 of the Best Pic nominees so far, or consider them worthy.  "Room" is a traditional Academy darling, and rightfully so.  It's dramatic, emotional, suspenseful and a phenomenal film.  The story is intense and heartbreaking (times 4 or 5).  The acting performances of Brie Larson and young Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscar recognition.  While I haven't seen all the performances nominated thus far, young Jacob Tremblay is jaw-dropping.  I was excited to see Brie Larson, one of my favorites, finally show her stuff, and that she did.  I hope she gets the win.  However, Jacob blew me away.  There were no words to describe how incredible his performance is for someone so young.  Better than any adult actor I've seen this year.  I'm serious.  There is an incredible career in the making there.  The screenplay, based on the novel of the same name, is beautiful.  Aside from one scene that bugged me a little, the dialogue is so real.  The director did a masterful job pulling the screenplay, performances and the perspective of "Room" against the much larger world Brie and Jacob are denied for so long.  I'm so glad at least 3 of the 8 Best Pic nominees are worthy.

Powerful & inspiring drama thanks to two brilliant lead performances & Lenny Abrahamson's direction that takes you into the horror of both living inside & out of such a situation.  Larson is extraordinary as Joy, and wisely doesn't play her as a saint but a young woman doing the best she can in a hellish situation.  She's paired wonderfully with Jacob Tremblay as her son, who convey's a wonderful mix of terror & wonder as a young boy experiencing the world for the first time.  Honestly, you want to talk about an Oscar snub, Tremblay should be on that list.  Behind the camera, Abrahamson does a superb job putting you into Joy & Jack's world, both inside the room and then later when they escape, especially by focusing on the perspective of Jack (simple things like the sky & trees never looked so strange & wondrous).  The filmmakers also don't shy away from hard questions, including decisions Joy makes, which may seem cruel but do make some points.  Overall, a truly inspiring film of survival and one of the best of the 2015.

If I had not read a true story similar to the content of this movie, I would be incapable of thinking this type of story could be true this day and age. The acting is superb and believeable and the story is told with much attention to real life and void of political goals that many films desire to exploit. 

Although the content is emotionally draining, I found myself pulled into the reality and the feeling of relief with mixed emotions that come in real-life. Thanks to the director and actors for their realistic portrayal of a story that needs to be told. Who knows how seeing this movie may spark someone to have the courage to question strange behavior  near their own home?
Unbelievably difficult to watch but I recommend that everyone does.  What a story.

Golden Globes (and surely Oscar) winner Brie Larson gives a career-making performance in a movie that I will never, ever, forget. I can't remember the last time a film literally took my breath away. I couldn't even talk about this movie for about a half hour after it ended.
Newcomer Jacob Tremblay is also fantastic in a performance worthy of a grizzled, seasoned veteran. Add in some solid supporting work from William H. Macy and Joan Allen, pitch-perfect direction from Lenny Abrahamson and a perfectly written screenplay, and you have the makings of the best film of 2015. Given the subject matter, Room manages to do the near-impossible: create an uplifting movie going experience without in any way minimizing the horror that is the basis for the plot. A tour de force.

Not sure how to rate this one. It's the opposite of my go-to example of Wolverwine--a terrible movie that I genuinely loved. This movie was really well made, but I wanted to stop watching it very soon into the film because of the disturbing subject matter. I've never seen a movie like this. Spotlight is disturbing on a less personal level, even though it happened in real life. Of course, this could have easily happened and similar stories have happened.
I did have a few problems with the movie--mostly the pacing and the structure. It felt like the movie could have ended multiple times--which I guess might have been intentional, but the real ending was powerful and moving.
The film certainly tries to inspire and have meaning, but for me it's just too overwhelming in how disturbing it is.
Emotions run high during and after the film, greatness all around.
A moving story that skirts the maudlin...the necessarily drab, ugly tones are a bummer, man.

I will admit that I was not very enthusiastic about seeing this film; I was worried that the story was gimmicky and sensationalistic.  However, I'm happy to admit that I was wrong.  The subject matter was handled very delicately and skilfully.  The acting was exceptionally good.  The pacing and dialogue were also very good.  It's worth noting that the author of the original novel is also credited with writing/ adapting the screenplay, something that doesn't happen all too often.  I can sincerely recommend this film to most viewers.

A genuinely moving & touching drama about a young mum & daughter that are basically kidnapped & held by force by their captor in a small room. The daughter Jack is 5 and her life has been confined in the room.

The most engaging scenes in my opinion is when Jack exits the room & comes to grip with life & the world out there.

It's an intense film & very simply put together but an effective drama. Performances are terrific especially Jack. It's a unique film that emotes much & draws you into their world.

Why Jacob Tremblay did not get an Oscar nod for this performance I have no idea. I have seen almost all of the movies nominated this year and this is by far the best of them. Amazingly powerful film. Go see it.

Absolutely riveting in a very gentle, non-sensationalist way. Jacob Tremblay, who plays Jack, is only 10 years old and is absolutely brilliant in his role in a beautiful natural performance. Brie Larson (21 Jump Street) is also perfect as Jack's mother. The minimal soundtrack means that we are immersed in the story without distraction and Lenny Abrahamson, the director, has done an excellent job in conveying the claustrophobic nature of Room and the fear of freedom within the short time of a movie making us feel the emotions of the characters. ROOM is a profound exploration of the challenges of parenting, the relationship between mother and child, social expectations that undermine parents, the formation and modification of world view, acceptance, freedom - so much to think about. Don't miss this harrowing, completely believable,  rewarding movie.

Holy shit, what an incredible movie. Larson is absolutely breathtaking here but the breakout is young Jacob Tremblay. That SAG nomination is well deserved. The film throws every emotion at you: joy, fear, love, despair, and hope. It hits all these with such a grand impact for such a small movie. The two actors make this a believable but very bumpy ride. Their characters earn their freedom and the actors earn our trust. A Masterpiece!

An intense and intriguingly original story about survival and learning about the world for the very first time through the eyes of a five-year-old boy. Extremely well acted, it's as emotional as you expect it to be. It's certainly a film that makes you think. Worth seeing.

Missed this movie last year and wanted to catch it before the oscars and I'm glad I did. This movie is incredible. Its a sometimes depressing story about a young girl and her 5 year old son who have been held captive in a shed for almost 7 years. The son has never seen the outside world. The two lead performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are spectacular. Brie Larson may get the Oscar this year and she totally deserves it. Hidden in this moving, dark story is a message of hope. A must see. One of my favorite movies of last year!

A masterpiece of film making. It's an emotional rollercoaster that doesn't seek to shock, but boy is it thought provoking. The less you know before going in the better. The pace and tension are remarkable. The two leads are amazing. Potentially the best child actor I've ever witnessed in a film. Absolutely fantastic.

One of the most beautiful films I have ever had the good fortune to see; cannot recommend enough. Incredible performances from everyone involved; particularly of course from Jacob Tremblay (the best child actor you're likely to see in anything) and Brie Larson who is great in anything she's been in and truly astounding in this. Full of absolutely heart-wrenching moments and yet ultimately positively life-affirming, Lenny Abrahamson and Emma Donoghue have written and directed a true masterpiece. There is a certain sequence in the middle of the film that left me breathless and an emotional wreck! Cried the first time watching and as soon as I started watching the film again, started tearing up as soon as it started. A beautiful film about a mother and a son that will be cherished!

Room is a touchy story about Jack and his mother that was kept isolated in a "Room" by a man who kidnapped her, raped her and got her pregnant and is using her as sexual slave for more than seven years. While Jack now five years old, spent the whole life in that "Room", not knowing that there is a life outside the "Room".

I started to watch every movie nominated for Best Picture, and Room is the second one after Spotlight. I had a feeling that there weren't a lot of great movies this year, but I'm happy to say that I was wrong.

Room is another pure drama that will be stuck in my head for a long time. A masterpiece story by novelist Emma Donoghue directed by Lenny Abrahamson in perfection. Very touching, with great characters and great acting job.

Jacob Tremblay is so young, I don't know if this kind of story would be a good idea for someone of his age, I mean psychologically. However, he was great and one of the things that I enjoyed most about the film. It felt like reality show. I feel sorry that he wasn't nominated for Oscar.

One of the part that I liked the most was when Jack narrates his feeling inside and outside the "Room". I always enjoy the narration in movies.

Story, dialogs, acting, directing and narration is great. A worth watching movie without a doubt. Different story, very well made.

A brilliant film that has had a profound effect on me. Much of that is to do with the superb acting from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, who has somehow been overlooked by the major awards this year. The best film of the awards season for me - without question.

Overrated waste of time!
How the heck do you allow yourself to be trapped in a shed for 7 years? The conditions of her capture was her being in a shed with a door that has an electronic lock on it. When he enters and exits she is suppose to stay on the far wall with her back turned so she won't see the code or try to escape.Â  After he goes through the door with the code on it he just pushes the outer door open. After a few days you should have devised a very good plan to escape. You should have seen that there was only one door that had an electronic lock while the other you can just simply push open. The way he entered and treated her was very odd. He would provide her with food and necessities. The "room" had a bathtub, toilet, sink, bed, table, toaster oven, shelves, a closet, a skylight and a tv with cable. He would then come in and lay in the bed with her until morning and repeat this same thing over and over for years. What??? Her idea of escaping was to have her son who just turned 5 play dead while wrapped up in a rug so the kidnapper can take the boy (Jack) out the "room" and bury him. Once Jack feels the truck stop 3 times he is suppose to jump out and run to someone. How the heck are you going to tell your 5yr. old son who has never been out in the world to do this ridiculous plan? He actually successfully does this and a guy calls the cops while the kidnapper drives off. Jack says to the cops that the truck made three stops from where they came and tells them he and his mom was in a shed. The cops find the shed and now the mom (Joy) and Jack are reunited and on the way to the hospital to start the new drama between her and her family. How the heck is that the best plan you can come up with? After 7 years where 2 of them you were by yourself, that was the best you could do? What were you doing with all that time? You have wonder why you didn't have the captor take the kid to the hospital after he was born. Did you have the kid in the shed? Wait a minute, something isn't adding up. Why would the capture keep you and the kid and willingly supply you with food, power and cable? He even does this after admitting he had been laid off for several months. This story is so off and seemingly pointless. You stay watching, hoping more details will emerge about Joy and why her mom and especially her dad are distant from her while they stay in her old house but you get nothing. The movie really does hold your attention but it's just a very odd and overrrated movie with a concept that is very implausible. The hype and surprisingly good reviews this movie gets are just unnecessary and unworthy. Sure the performances from Brie Laurson and the kid are great but the story is garbage. Its great to see Jack becoming acclimated to the world around him and the progression of the family but it's such a worthless journey without the understanding of why and how this happened. And that's how it ends. They visit the "room" one more time with the police to let it go from their lives but never find the captor. This was a worthless production that did not need to be done. Should have kept this a book on a shelf left unread.

Room is a masterwork that tells a story of captivity and the wonders of the real world.  Its a very sad story, but also a hopeful one.  Brie Larson gives one of the best performances I have seen in quite a long time.  She is a revelation.  Her dark, truthful, scared and emotional performance is something truly fascinating.  She puts her soul into this character, and it pays off in spades.  A few months ago I honestly didn't know much of her, but now I see her as one of the most promising new actresses in the business.  Jacob Tremblay further proves my belief that child actors can truly make our jaws drop.  Tremblay deserves all the praise in the world for his heartwarming and complex performance, completely capturing the mindset of a young boy being introduced to the world for the first time.  Its something truly spectacular, and I kept going back and forth trying to decide if he or Larson stole the show.  They both really worked perfectly together.  Joan Allen is another underrated performance, as she gives a sweet and loving performance as the grandmother.  Her giving a brilliant performance as a mother who lost her daughter and attempts to have a relationship with her grandson is heartwarming.  The script from Emma Donoghue is something truly spectacular.  She gives us a terrifying real look into the minds of these characters and bringing life to their situation.  There was a moment halfway through the film that had me in tears and cheering.  Its amazing that a fictional  story could feel so much like a true story.  Director Lenny Abrahamson

A worthwhile watch, featuring two great central performances. Somehow manages to tackle some pretty heavy issues while still being fairly uplifting. The end result is a film that's frequently compelling (particularly in the first half), but a little prone to emotional and plot related shortcuts as it progresses.

'Room' Review: Heart-Tugging Experience, a Young Boy's First View of the Real World - 8ish

It's fascinating to listen to a child's take on the world. It brings laughter to hear what they believe certain things represent and what those objects actually do. The adults would then correct the child and explain what it really is and what's really out there. Normally, adults don't have to do this twice - in two different worlds.

In "Room," well, it is a different world. Young Jack (Jacob Tremblay) is locked up in a shed, known as "Room," with his mother, or Ma (Brie Larson). They survive with the necessities, basic food, plumbing, a bed, but have no contact with the outside world. Old Nick (Sean Bridgers), who is responsible for locking them away, brings supplies through a password-protected door. The only natural light comes through a skylight atop the shed.

Jack believes everything on TV is magic and doesn't truly exist. He believes there is only Room, like it's on its very own planet. Voice-overs are provided by Jack explaining what's going on inside his head, and what everything means to him. He has a fear of ever going outside, but must if he and Ma plan on escaping to a better life. Jack is almost born twice, and experiences the world twice - once in his own and then the real one. A bond between a mother and her child can never be broken.

Both Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay shine so brightly in "Room." Larson is emotional, understanding and at the same time expresses the exhaustion of raising a child, especially one who has never had exposure to the real world. She's genuinely authentic and outstanding. It's going to be a real competition for Best Actress between her and Saoirse Ronan.

Tremblay shows his bright future as an exceptionally talented young actor. You will fall in love with this boy and truly feel for him and what he undergoes during the film. His voice-overs are hilarious, but saddening at the same time. The writing was superb for his character. There are no flaws with the rest of the cast, as well.

"Room" does such a fabulous job with letting us see a child grow up in this unfortunate, but unique circumstance. We have no idea how we would coup with such an experience and the psychology behind it. Being in that situation would be ever so frustrating, but Larson handles and deals with it the only way it could be dealt with. It's another beautiful film from A24.

A heartbreaking, powerful work of art that emotionally broke me in two. This is a film that might not have worked as well as it did without these performances, because my GOD, the acting here blew me away. Here is a phenomenal emotional thriller. The content is pretty original. On top of that you have two powerhouse performances, one by Brie Larson, as Ma, who is truly exceptional. The other is by Jacob Tremblay, the young boy in the film. My concern is, Tremblay carried the entire film more than Larson, but Tremblay doesn't have an Oscar Nomination?!?!?!?! Seriously, this kid could have been the Best Actor of the year, seeing as his contribution to the movie is beyond recognition.

A mother and her son, which looks like a girl, live in a room that has no windows, a locked door, and no light other than that coming through an overhead skylight. Jack (Jacob Tremblay), a bright five-year old boy with hair down to his shoulders wakes up every morning saying hello to his universe. He does not greet the sun, the grass, the trees outside, where he could run and laugh and play like a normal five-year old but only to the objects he knows for five years as being "the real world", his world: the lamp, the sink, the plant, the refrigerator. His only friend is a mouse that he feeds, thinking that the mouse also lives in that little world, the only one real for him. Sometimes a man comes over, during the night, and then Jack must sleep in the wardrobe, not to be seen. The relationship mother-son appears to be normal: they cook, dance, laugh, stretch out, read about Alice, mother tells the tale of Monte Cristo. The poverty that surrounds them is not painful. The real pain and anger I felt when Jack could not believe that outside "the room" exists a real world, with real people, and trees, grass, leaves, seasons, snow. Then the reality strikes: captivity. A child born in captivity, because of a madman, a rapist. A story of a child whose life started in a cage having as a talisman his mother love and her tooth, thinking that "his strong" is in his long hair. Real world proves to be scarier than "the room". A movie that should be seen, a story that must be known, a boy that deserves all the awards: Jacob Tremblay.

My Grade:  A (97%),...Both highly suspenseful and deeply emotional, ROOM is a unique and touching exploration of the boundless love between a mother and her child. After 5-year-old Jack (Jacob Tremblay) and his Ma (Brie Larson) escape from the enclosed surroundings that Jack has known his entire life, the boy makes a thrilling discovery: the outside world. As he experiences all the joy, excitement, and fear that this new adventure brings, he holds tight to the one thing that matters most of all--his special bond with his loving and devoted Ma.

Though hard to watch at times, this is an incredible film. Jacob Tremblay is really impressive in such a difficult role, and I love how his perspective on the world is constantly changing throughout the course of the movie. Brie Larson is also very powerful in her role, showing all sorts of emotional range and gives a performance I didn't know she had in her.

Director Lenny Abrahamson continues an interesting filmography with this engrossing thriller/drama featuring two incredible displays of acting. In some ways this is reminiscent of 'The Shawshank Redemption' but here we explore further into the damage and recovery after a metaphorical crawl through a river of filth.

"Room" is one of the most vivid movies that you will ever see.  The concept is fascinating: A woman is inexplicably trapped in a room with her five-year-old son.  That's all.  As the story unfolds, we learn details of how long they have been there and where their food comes from; however, the mystery continues to be preserved as we are left to fill in the rest with our imaginations.  There are so many things that I would love to say but I want everybody to be just as surprised and on the edge of your seat as I was.  In fact, this film contains ten of the most intense minutes that you will ever see in any movie.  I swear, there came a point where I had to remind myself to breath.  The story is an endless series of emotional highs and lows that create a deep connection between the characters and the audience.  These emotional moments are enhance by a powerful musical score by Stephen Rennicks.  Its absence reinforces the hopelessness and isolation of being trapped in the room, but then the score soars when it needs to enhance the joyous and devastating moments.  I find that the most poetic piece of the film stems from one of the darkest psychological implications:  The mental well-being of this young boy is completely dependent upon his mother but, when everything turns, he suddenly needs to become her strength in a time of need.  Again, I'm doing my best to avoid any spoilers so you will just have to see it for yourself.  The acting is astounding.  Brie Larson will take home an Oscar for the endless number of emotions that she vividly portrays throughout the film.  Her character is simply known as "Ma," a constant reminder that she has been stripped of her identity and her entire world is her son.  She doesn't need a cape to turn her character into a hero.  Jacob Tremblay was equally amazing.  It is rare that I believe that a child performance deserved an Oscar nomination but his acting is highly refined and brings out a lot of our emotions.  He holds his own against Larson's Oscar-nominated performance and isn't merely along for the ride.  The realism of this story is further enhanced by its supporting cast.  Joan Allen has been out of vogue for awhile but she delivers her best performance in years.  It took a lot to steal the spotlight from Larson and Tremblay, but she definitely had her moment.  Also, the very presence of William H. Macy adds a brief but necessary complication to this story.  There comes a point where you start dreading that the ending will spoil the entire story.  Dreading that, no matter what the ending, it won't live up to the rest of the film.  But Emma Donoghue creates the perfect conclusion that allows this story to come full circle.  One of the best pieces of advice that I can give is that you should NOT watch the trailer!  Just take my word for it and blindly walk into this film.  "Room" will keep you intrigued, emotional, and on the edge of your seat from start until finish.  More importantly, you will walk away from the film a changed person.

Oh my... Brie Larson and that kid destroyed me... This film manages to be heartbreaking and emotionally draining yet hopeful and uplifting at the same time. Perfect, perfect film.

Brie Larson showed how good she is in Short Term 12, but she brought it to another level here. And the kid, my God, is he good!

At its heart, '#Room' is a movie about survival. Not against the elements but survival of one's mind against insanity when faced with overwhelming and insidious conditions. It's also a movie that proves that #BrieLarson deserves her Oscar nomination. Her co-star Jacob Tremblay, who plays her five year old son, also gives one of the most spellbinding and believable performances of the year. It never gets too heavy. Instead, it shifts between being uncomfortable to being heartwarming and loving. It doesn't end in the typical Hollywood crescendo. Instead, it gives much needed closure to the characters as well as the audience. It is well worth the 1 hour 23 minute runtime.

This is great.  If you're looking for a tense, emotionally satisfying, character driven film, this is the one for you.  

I wasn't familiar with Brie Larson before I saw this, but she's a frigging brilliant actress.  I wouldn't be surprised if she becomes the "next big thing" in the near future, because the power of this movie is almost totally dependent on her and her performance.  It reminded me a little of 'Joy' actually (And it's just a weird coincidence that her character's name in 'Room' is Joy too) because the story is essentially about a mother who has to overcome seemingly impossible odds in order to save her own life.  This is obviously a much darker story than 'Joy', but I was struck my the similarity in theme.  Moving onto the kid, Jacob Tremblay, he's excellent too.  Now, good child actors are a rarity to say the very least, but this one has the right chops.  We see the world and events of the narrative through his eyes, and not once did his performance grate on me or make me wince, like most child actors do with such a huge role.  He was pivotal to the success of the movie and it really works.

I had a concern before seeing this that the entire film would be set in the one room that the characters are being kept prisoner in.  Not that I didn't think the film could work if it was, but just because I feel the material would get a little overdrawn if that was the case.  I'm happy to say though that the protagonists escape the dungeon halfway through the movie.  I don't feel this is a spoiler because this was hinted at in the trailer.  But the reason why this is such a positive aspect for me is because I'm interested in similar real life cases and how captives manage to reintegrate into the world after being out of it for so long.  This film deals with that very well and it satisfied me.  

There were a few things that disappointed me, but I don't think they're detrimental to the film or particularly harm it in any way.  Brie Larson's father had a small role and I wish they'd expanded on some of the issues he was having with the whole ordeal, but they just wrote him out rather suddenly.  I also would have liked more closer with the antagonist, the man who captured Brie Larson in the first place.  

Other than that, I don't have a negative thing to say about this.  It's the sort of film that will stay with you.

The best movie I've ever seen automatically top 5 of all time. Acting amazing, screenplay top notch. Every emotion wrapped up in one. I very rarely cry at movies get emotional, but this had me as a blubbering idiot. Amazing!

An engrossing story with equally captivating performances, this is one of the most compelling original films of 2015. It's all the more refreshing in a year full of reboots, sequels and continuations.

Once you get over some of the incredulous details the director seems to have glossed over (e.g. no one heard the two of them screaming at the top of their lungs from a shed in a suburban neighborhood? The kid was able to grow to be 5 without getting sick once?), you begin to see the world from the child's PoV and you begin to feel the way he does about the outside world, outside "the room". I dont see how the Oscar could be given to Brie Larson while Jacob Tremblay is passed over for best actor, and perhaps the youngest ever. The movie needs some editing from the halfway mark, but watch the movie for Jack.

Seeing this story through the eyes of a five year (played by should-be-Oscar-nominated Jacob  Tremblay) serves this movie right as "Room" is hands down one of the best films of 2015. it's haunting, touching, never wracking, pure courage storytelling. It's psychologically complex, and veers more into the realm of realist filmmaking than any other film of its kind (that I've seen).

Could have delved more into the hard living conditions and the psychological affects of this sort of traumatic experience. I kind of feel they skirted around it all a bit much presumably to protect the audience. It was an emotionally draining cinema trip.

Brie Larson give an absolutely heartbreaking performance, she's utterly incredible in her role and definitely deserves the attention, respect and an Oscar for this role. Jacob Trembled is also spectacular in his role. The movie really shines with its performances. Now as for some of the other characters I wanted a little bit more from them, particularly the father, I feel like he could've had a bigger role in the story. Also the fact of Brie Larson losing her childhood was only explored briefly. After watching this movie I was aching for more drama as if there wasn't already. All in all the story itself is heartbreaking and uplifting at the same time and is really demonstrated thanks to the performces and the direction.

I won't spoil the 2nd Act but things become less stressful and take a turn, and the world isn't what everyone thought. Director Leonard Abrahamson (Frank) is piecing it together and never lets the world blow up in our faces, and leaves it to the actors how it should be.

It says a lot about the quiet yet assured power of Room that despite
the fact half of Lenny Abrahamson's film takes place in the titular and
small "room" or really prison that Brie Larsons Ma and her son Jack
played by impressive newcomer Jacob Tremblay are kept in, scenes in the
film constantly engage the viewer through terrific performances, a
taught and sharp script by Emma Donaghue (who here adapts her own book)
and there's an emotional resonance that will catch many viewers off
guard.

Room is not by any means of the word an easy sell or even a typical
cinematic piece of entertainment but Abrahamson who showed promise with
the sporadically brilliant Michael Fassbender starrer Frank has a clear
affiliation for the tricky material that Donaghue created.

Focusing on telling the dark and in more ways than one horrific story
through the eyes of Tremblay's innocent and impressionable Jack, who
never once has set foot outside the thin yet impenetrable walls of his
world that he and his mum inhabit, Abrahamson finds himself directing
many of Room's proceedings as though they were being seen through the
eyes of a 5 year old child just as Jack is. Utilising a sparring yet
effective voice over from the young boy that tells us all we need to
know about how he sees the life he lives and constructing impressive
visuals even in the films tight surrounds, this is Abrahamson's real
calling card after two commendable early efforts and the cast also join
Abrahamson in an reaching another level of success.

She may have just recently won a surprise Golden Globe for her
committed and believe able turn as a loving mother but Brie Larson has
been carving out a noteworthy collection of films over the last few
years so the true breakout of Room is young Tremblay.

Tremblay delivers a deep and beyond his young years turn as Jack and
it's thanks to this child actors success that Room becomes the film
that's been resonating with audiences the world over. While Larson will
be billed as the star here it is Tremblay that carries the film through
its sometimes murky middle half and whenever he and Larson share the
screen, Room is an often faultless exercise in dramatic filmmaking.
It's a stunning turn and one that will likely seeing the young
performer be an in demand presence in the years to come.

While it arguably loses some head of steam after a breathtaking opening
half in its exploration of the opportunities that lay outside the
prison walls, Room is a unique and emotionally strong tale of the bond
mothers and sons share and in a strange yet touching manner, a tale of
what it means to be alive in this great big beautiful world we call
home.

Absolutely phenomenal, I'm still recovering. Not being hyperbolic this was the best films of the year and one of the greatest films I've ever seen. The direction was superb, Brie Larson's performance was once-in-a-lifetime, and the writing was flawless. This movie will likely be in Spotlight's shadow at award time but the nominations will hopefully encourage more people to see it. Lenny Abrahamson proved for the third time he's one of the best directors on the planet. And Emma Donoghue's adaptation of her own novel brilliantly shifts the focus away from sad, somber, depression to inspirational love between mother and child in a cathartic experience. Praise all around. This movie will stick with me forever.

An absolute fantastic film that before I even jump into it I recommend everyone give this one a watch. Room is about a young lady referred to as Ma (Brie Larson) who lives in a shed with her son Jack (Jacob Tremblay). Ma was kidnapped when she was 17 by Old Nick (Sean Bridgers) and has been kept captive in the Room. Old Nick comes by to have his way with her and leaves her supplies. This has been going on for seven years and Ma has had enough. Ma weaves a story to Jack that there's only the Room and everything else is fake. It sort of places her in a position to think that this is life and to save her son from the horrific events happening to them. I don't want to spoil anymore, but the acting here is top notch. Brie Larson shines as Ma and the breakout star here is young Jacob Tremblay. Both really get you to care early on about them and some moments truly do get tense. Its a great film about the relationship between a mother and her child and the lengths that said mother will go to to protect her own. Only small gripe is that later in the film and by the ending there are still a few questions that never get answered! I can't recommend this one enough regardless!

Room is as emotionally affecting as one would expect based on the premise, features terrific performances from its two leads, and gives the world a second fully inhabited and fully believable depiction of depression given from Brie Larson (after Short Term 12, which you should go see right now).  Unfortunately, Room is a bit aimless structurally; the first act provides goals for the characters to achieve, while the second lumbers along, providing some excellent scenes along the way but no sense of purpose or climax.  If you're looking for a good, cathartic cry, Room does the trick, but unfortunately the film is somewhat less than the sum of its exceptional parts.

There are not many films you could say "I remember where I was the first time I saw that." Room is one of those films. 

Based on Emma Donoghue's novel of the same name, we see the harrowing existence of five-year-old Jack and his mother Joy as they are kept locked away in a garden shed. The eponymous room is both their prison and Jack's entire world. There is only heaven, which he sees through the skylight, the space within Room and the fictional world of TV. Their escape unveils the true wonders of the everyday world to Jack, as well as a difficult adjustment back to normality for Joy.

The two central performances are fantastic. Raw, heartfelt and utterly engaging, Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay emote the pain, grief and frustrations of their journey to profound levels. They're two of the finest performances of the last twelve months, so don't be surprised if both walk away with Oscars. That's right, Tremblay is that good!

Lenny Abrahamson treatment of Donoghue's script allows for a poignant slow-burner that never contrives to exploit. We're given a beautiful balance of pain and hope, anger and joy. A bleak tale of survival and discovery has never had so much warmth. 

An intimate and thoroughly rewarding film that will stay with you for a very long time. It deserves every award it's given.

As one of the top films of 2015, and even the decade, Room is an unforgettable and deeply emotional viewing experience. Excelled by the realistically powerful acting by Brie Larson (the obvious Best Actress winner) and Jacob Tremblay (snubbed of a best supporting actor nom). Room explores the human condition in the midst of a thrilling journey of a new world and experiences by a young boy. This all-time acting duo of mother and young son with the brilliant and sometimes suffocating directing by Lenny Abrahamson is well-deserving of its four Academy Award nominations. A

A very unique film coming as a Canadian and Irish co pro that really celebrates the connection of parent and child under very dire circumstances and their attempts to maintain hope for the chances of survival and recovery. The Room jumps right into Ma and Jack as they are entering their final days in a confined room where the are being held captive for unknown reasons by Old Jack, and do extremely well in showing them playing and trying to enstill the normal values and such while only receiving the most minimalist of care from their captors. A sort of fantasy story telling approach helps Ma keep Jack innocent despite everything going on around them until his fifth birthday when it comes time that she feels he can handle an escape attempt to help both of them come from underfoot and reunite with the outside world. Brie Larson and Jacob Trimbley are really note perfect in their roles as Ma and Jack, you really believe their connection and despair, and Jacob was really gradually discovering the outside world with his grandparents and gradually adjusting to everything around him almost like a newborn even though he is a 5 year old. A very deserving if unusual choice for the 2015 TIFF Audience Choice Award and I will be intrigued to see what hardware it picks up at the Oscars this year. Has a slight Beasts of the Sourthern Wild pull to it which was cool. And also best cameo of a Etobicoke landmark in the film with Apache Burger. A solid and surprising gem. .
No other film demonstrates the power of hope and the human spirit than Room. This is a haunting, unforgettable, yet inspiring film experience.

The only redeeming quality for this film is the performances of the main actors.  Both Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay present somewhat compelling depictions of a woman and child who are held for a long amount of time against their will.  However, as their predicaments change, the movie begins to hit the cliché 'notes' of a film that wants to play with your emotions, but without any insight on the suffering of its characters.  It's as if this film's downfall comes from the fact that it was written by the writer of the novel upon which it's based, Emma Donoghue; this film tries to fit so much drama into its second half, yet it still drags as it provides a shallow impression of the psyches of the characters in this tragic situation.  The film's flaccid ending seems like a halfhearted attempt at some sort resolution and relies on the viewer to imagine the changed-state of the principal characters--as it's not shown in any detail.  
  I'm sorry to say that this movie was ultimately unoriginal (at moments it felt like Peter Jackson's similarly-themed "Lovely Bones"), poorly written (laughable moments in the script "Needle in a haystack" etc.), and boring (zzzzzzzzz).  I feel as if this film would benefit immensely if it was shot/told in a similar fashion to that of the novel upon which it's based: from the viewpoint of the imprisoned child.  This is attempted in form of narration spread at different points throughout the film, but the somewhat precocious reflections are brief and, at times, inaudible.  While I have not read the novel, I would imagine that telling/shooting the film in a similar manner would add some much needed originality and insight.  
  I would have given this film 1.5 stars because of its compelling opening situation, but, much like the agonizingly cliché sex-offender glasses of the character who imprisons Larson and Tremblay,  its derivative nature is really quite ghastly.

Powerfully emotional and heavily dramatic on its conception and plot, Room founds Lenny Abrahamson adapting an intense story that relays its effectiveness on chemistry between characters, heavy hearted moments and superb direction, all to condense a great-but-simple story with the benefits of Brie Larson's terrific performance, and the addition of the potential rising-star Jacob Tremblay in what turned out to be one of the best mother-son relationship in modern cinema.

While Room hits on poignant ideas dealing with how mothers relate to their children and how children develop their sense of perspective from their parents, it's also built on a fundamental desire to make the audience cry that results in an incessantly maudlin score and some treacly, writerly flourishes that undermine the simple power derived from the premise. As Jack views the world for the first time and gains an understanding of what exists around him, it's beautiful and heartbreaking and succeeds in delivering the emotion Abrahamson so desperately wants to communicate, but it's underlined and reworked and restated so many times that the film begins to lose what initially made it so effective. Tremblay and Larson are both excellent; it's a shame they weren't given the vehicle they deserved.

¿La mejor película del año? Debatible. ¿La más hermosa? Sin duda.

Room cuenta la historia de Jack (Tremblay), un chico de cinco años que vive con su madre (Larson) en una pequeña habitación. Dentro de la habitación, la madre ha creado un verdadero mundo para Jack, siendo que ninguno de los dos tiene permitido salir de ella, para que el pequeño pueda vivir una vida alegre e imaginativa. Cuando ambos idean un plan para escapar, Jack y su madre se ven enfrentados a algo que no veían desde hacía mucho tiempo: el mundo real.

Mi canal se llama Blockbuster Movie Blog. Esto es porque a mí me gusta el cine ya que representa las cosas que no es posible ver en la realidad. Como he dicho miles de veces, el cine es el lugar donde los sueños son posible. Por esto, yo prefiero mil veces ver una película de gran presupuesto sobre un superhéroe que una película independiente sobre, digamos, un drama familiar. Los dramas familiares los ves todos los días en la vida diaria, un superhéroe no.
Eso no significa que no disfrute ver películas como La Habitación, una película sobre un evento que puedes encontrar al ver las noticias en tu rutina diaria, y que contiene una historia tan increíble que tomará tu corazón, lo partirá en miles de pedacitos y luego te lo devolverá parchado.

Este film inicia mostrándonos a un enternecedor Jacob Tremblay, quien interpreta a Jack. Con cinco años recién cumplidos, Jack se despierta y saluda al lavamanos, a la televisión, a la claraboya y a varios objetos inanimados que hay en la habitación. Cuando el pequeño despierta a su madre y ella le dice que harán una pastel de cumpleaños, Jack inicialmente no le cree. "¿Un pastel como los de la televisión?", pregunta Jack. Y ahí tenemos un vistazo claro de lo que va la película. Y es que el pequeño nunca ha estado fuera de esa habitación. Y somo suficientemente inteligentes para darnos cuenta que mientras Jack vive en su mundo rodeado de cuatro paredes, la mirada de su madre muestra en sus ojos la verdad: están encerrados ahí contra su voluntad. Son víctimas del viejo Nick (Bridgers).

Y la fuerza de la película, el poder emocional, se encuentra en esta primera mitad del film. Vemos que Ma, como le dice Jack a su madre, interpretada de forma excepcional por Brie Larson, ha creado un mundo entero para Jack en esa pequeña habitación. Room, como le dicen en inglés, es el mundo. Y todo lo que está más allá de esas paredes, es el espacio.

Y mientras que Tremblay hace un trabajo brillante al corporizar la inocencia, Larson hace lo propio al hacer presente la desesperación, la depresión, el sentimiento más horrendo que puede sentir una persona cuando lo menos terrible que pasa en su vida es estar privada de su libertad.
Porque, por si estar secuestrada fuera poco, el captor, el viejo Nick, aparece algunos días para demostrar su superioridad, y obviamente, para violarla.
¿Oscar para Larson? Probablemente. Digo, hablemos de una actuación poderosa y éso es lo que nos entrega la norteamericana. No sólo con sus expresiones, o con sus palabras; si no que, similar a lo que pasa con Cate Blanchett en Carol, con sus ojos. Es increíble la forma en que la mirada de Larson provee el sentido de depresión y desesperación con la emoción necesaria para hacerte sentirla al igual que ella.

Lo bueno, creo, es que el film no se queda dentro de la habitación durante todo el film. Alrededor de la mitad de la película, mediante una secuencia de escenas que son tan emocionantes como aterradoras como adrenalínicas, Ma y Jack logran escapar. Lamentablemente, la vida no se vuelve más fácil inmediatamente al encontrarse con el mundo real.
Y aquí sí que se luce Tremblay, si es que no lo había hecho ya, con su intepretación de Jack frente a un mundo que ve por primera vez. Abrahamson hace un trabajo perfecto al mostrarnos la forma en que este mundo normal al que estamos acostumbrados golpea a Jack la primera vez. Tenemos que recordar que cuando Ma le dice a Jack que existen otras personas, que los árboles existen, que hay autos, perros; él no le cree y le grita mentirosa. Por esto, se puede ver en la expresión de Tremblay el miedo, el profundo miedo hacia este mundo desconocido llamado Tierra.

Acompañada por un deleitosa y atormentada composición musical provista por Stephen Rennicks, la historia avanza a caminos más rocosos. Y la presencia de la increíblemente talentosa Joan Allen como la abuela y del correctamente alabado William H. Macy como el abuelo simplemente mejoran una ya excelente película. Ambos se entregan totalmente a sus roles en polos opuestos con respecto a su hija y nieto.

El film lidia con realismo y complejidad lo que significa el después de una serie de eventos tan traumatizantes como el secuestro, todo gracias a la brillante fluidez narrativa de la guionista Emma Donoghue, también autora de la novela en que está inspirada la película.
Y es que este es uno de los casos en que la película le añade algo más de sabor a la historia, gracias a elementos como la actuación o la música. Es increíble todo lo que puede sacar Abrahamson de un guión tan simple. Puedes lidiar aquí con la discriminación, la aceptación, la familia, la confianza, muchísimas cosas. Y todo se resume a la historia, y la forma en que está contada.

#Room #instareview #RoyalReview
#Carlosatthemovies Friday January 1
1 hour 53 minutes
 
This movie had been on my list for a while. The buzz was intense. And, wow, was it worth it. ROOM is, pun intended, captivating! #BrieLarson (seen earlier this year as #AmySchumerâ??s sister in #Trainwreck) stars as a mother being held (against her will) in a shed. As the film opens, we see Larsonâ??s #Ma â??playing houseâ?? with her 5 year old son, Jack (played by breakout star #JacobTremblay). We later come to learn that Ma has been held there for 7 years and that this room, the shed, is the only world Jack has ever known.
 
Recent events lead Ma to make a dramatic attempt to escape (Iâ??ll let you see for yourself what those events are). Eventually, Ma and Jack are rescued, which sets up the last act of the film: Ma and Jackâ??s reacclamation (or acclamation in Jackâ??s case) to the â??outside world.â?? To shield Jack from their confined surroundings of the room, Ma had recreated a very imaginative world for Jack. Although being held captive by another person, Ma was the only person Jack knew.
 
The post-escape is almost as thrilling as the presentation of life in the room. It was interesting to see how Ma and Jack are, ironically, held captive by their newfound freedom. The film is indeed great and a must-see. The only gripe is that there was a few plot elements that were left unresolved (or forgotten) all-together. Some plots went in a different direction than I expected (thatâ??s a good thing). But others were left hanging, but were initially presented with an air of importance.
 
#JoanAllen and #WilliamHMacy costar as Maâ??s parents. Their lives were turned upside down when Ma went missing. Now, they must piece things together while trying to comfort Ma and Jack, a grandchild they never knew they have.
 
Larson and Tremblayâ??s performances are rock solid. Larson will give #CateBlanchett (from #Carol) a run for her money come #Oscar night. ROOM is playing in limited release, but worth the effort to find it.
 
My score: #9outof10
