Again, I've entered this movie without having seen the trailer or the synopsis in order to experience it better and, again, I was not dissapointed. The story follows a mother, Joy, and her son, Jack, who have been living in one small room for the past 5 years. The reason is unknown until about half hour into the movie, so I won't spoil it. Anyways, at one point they get out and Jack hasn't been out of that room, ever. So, this is his first time seeing the outside world and it's really beautiful seeing that, I have to admit. How he is ignorant of everything and discovering everything for the first time. Joy has to deal with a lot of media and her parents and it's all very over-the-top dramatic. That's about the only problem I had with this movie. The overly dramatic plot revolving around Joy. It's interesting at first, but it just keeps going and going and it gets to the point where you're just tired of her character, albeit her actress is amazing. And so is everyone, really. There weren't any bad actors, not even the kid! The direction is great and the first 40 minutes of the movie which are entirely set in the small room look outstanding! I was always fascinated by the movies that are set in small spaces and how the directors manage to make them look bigger and more interesting. The soundtrack is great. All in all, Room is a movie deffinetely worth seeing as it is very emotional, the story is intriguing and the acting is brilliant. Not my best movie of the year, but near the top!
Beautiful. Close to perfect movie. Great acting, story, filming. Just fantastic.

A film I have found out through the power of YouTube and one where I most certainly agree with all the buzz surrounding the film because it was absolutely brilliant and is one of the best movies I have seen in 2015. This film shows the power that a simple story can bring to the viewer and is one that is told in such a heartbreaking and thought-provoking manner. Watching this film, I completely forgot at times that I was even watching a movie and I was completely captivated and effected by all the situations going on. The performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are truly incredible here and together have portrayed one of the best mother-son relationships I have ever seen in a long time in a movie. With Short Term 12 and this under Brie Larson's belt, I am going to look forward to everything she does in the future and I hope she gets a Oscar nomination for this performance because it was memorable and one of the best performances I have seen from an actress in 2015. Brie Larson did a fantastic job portraying a mother who cares deeply for her son and will do anything for him and when she started having mental problems toward the final hour of the film, I felt completely sad for her and her son. Jacob Tremblay as the son was fantastic as well and he gave one of the best performances I have seen from a child in a long time and I hope that he will be in many more great movies in the future. Being a kid raised in an enclosed environment, I completely understood him whenever he would feel a certain way towards life or towards his own mother and there were a lot of heartbreaking and touching moments with them together. The dialogue in the film was fantastic as well. The conversations that Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay had were completely engrossing and her telling him about the outside world was all the more memorable to watch and listen to. There were many times during the first half of the film where I was on the edge of my seat waiting to see how they would gain their freedom and I was left breathless when those scenes ended. Joan Allen as the grandma of Jacob Tremblay's Jack was really likable and she showed a great amount of emotion in the second half of the film and gave a better than average supporting performance. While William H. Macy was a great presence as the grandpa, I could have had more scenes with him dealing with these heartbreaking situations, but because everything else was so good, his limited amount of screen time only felt like a minor problem and didn't detract from the film.  Being from a small time director, Lenny Abrahamson shows here that he can get nothing but the best out of these actors and the simple premise, and I look forward to what he does next after this. In the end, I really had no major issues with this film and this was a movie that I was completely floored by and one that I can't wait to see again when it comes out on Blu-ray.

The film Room is the story of a mother - played by Brie Larson - and her five-year old son who are forced to live in a tiny square room. The viewer has no idea why they are living in this space but as clues are revealed as the movie progresses.

This movie is excellent and a must see - I can't say enough about it. The style choice can appeal to both the indie film buff and also the casual big blockbuster moviegoer. It does a great job of using every scene to advance the story forward and the screenplay is written in a way that is believable. In addition the dynamic of the way the mother and son interact is not over the top. Nor does it appear forced. 

In the first act, I was impressed with the mise-en-scene and the shallow space composition done entirely within a 10 foot by 10 foot room. In the second and third acts, the movie appears to go in particular direction, but then it surprises viewers. However, it is done in a way that is not unrealistic or cliche. 

This movie is easily a top five film of 2015. If someone says it is not, then they simply never saw the film or do not appreciate a drama that does not need fancy CGI in place of breathtaking shots, top notch cinematography, and flawless acting to go along with a well-written narrative. This film easily gets a 10 out of 10 rating.

Room is a marvelously directed, fantastically crafted and powerfully acted feat of cinema. The story begins in the titular Room, aka a shed in the backyard of a kidnapper. The film is split into two distinctive parts, Act 1 taking place primarily in Room, the shed, and focuses on a bit of the day-to-day life of its inhabitants, mother and son Joy and Jack. Captured when she was 17, Joy has been locked in Room for seven years and had her captor's, Old Nick as he is called, son. Jack is now a rambunctious, excited five-year-old who has only known Room for his entire life. Joy has made it her mission to protect her son and keep him innocent to the horror of their reality for most of his young life, but now must make him understand in order to get him on her side to escape. Their escape is a success, but leads into the next part: adjusting to life outside. Jack follows his mother through their journey to become part of the free world. Brie Larson embodies every instinct and insecurity of Joy in her performance, conveying a young mother's fears and connection with her child as well as a young woman's fears of having to be responsible for everything in her small uncontrolled world. Larson is complimented by her costar, Jacob Tremblay, a remarkably talented young actor who truly owns the screen.

This is one movie that might stick with you for a while.  This movie tells the tale of a young woman who is kidnapped as a teenager, held captive for seven years of her life, gives birth to her captor's son, raises the boy for the first five years of his life in a 10x10 garden shed, escapes, and that's when the real struggle begins.

Brie Larson is great as the film's heroine and young newcomer, Jacob Tremblay, brilliantly portrays the film's narrator.  The young child actor plays the heroine's son (Jack) well because he manages to exude innocence and resilience without appearing precocious.  I like that.  Joan Allen, William H. Macy, and Tom McCamus are great as Jack's grandmother, grandfather and step-grandfather respectively.  

This is a great follow-up to Lenny Abrahamson's 2014 film Frank.

Room: One Skylight, Two Great Performances, and Four Walls make one great film. 

"Room" starts in the middle of a horrifying tale of abduction with little back story and little history. And that works wonder. It places us right in the middle of the claustrophobia of the two main characters, Joy and her son Jack. The first third of the film made me almost as uncomfortable as I was during the whole masterpiece film, "The Act of Killing." 

There are so many times when this film could have gone awry, sappy and melodramatic. In fact, the sappiest thing about the film was the music, being far too uplifting and loud for the themes in the movie. 

The framing of each shot in the first-third of the movie augments the feeling of being trapped. The shots are as beautiful as they are terrifying. 

The acting of the two main characters is spot on, especially the five-year-old boy Jake, played by Jacob Tremblay. Brie Larson plays the complicated role of Joy, the mother, who goes through untold agony. We aren't told what happens in detail; we see it on her face, in her body.

There were so many times this film could have gone for cheap sentimentality; they could have gone for the easy reconciliation and happy ending, and it didn't. Put one in the win column for small, well writing, well directed and well acted cinema that doesn't involve stunts or explosions. 

Rating: Pay Full Price

Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay deserve Oscars nominations. ??

Heartbreaking, believable and deeply moving, "Room" is a spellbinding film that sticks with you long after you've left the theater. Although the story it tells is not for the faint of heart or impatient moviegoers, it is beautifully told, powerfully acted and impressively directed. It is unlikely that you will find an actress as committed as Brie Larson or a child-actor as convincing as Jacob Tremblay this year. Both deliver breathtaking performances that seem real and utterly believable. Perhaps, the greatest compliment they can be given is that at times you almost forget that they're 'acting'. Director Lenny Abrahamson uses these actors beautifully to tell a story with a universal message of hope. A message so powerful that it makes you appreciate your own life.
The performances of Larson and Tremblay: wow! Just ... wow!

Wow!  Jacob Tremblay is an amazingly talented young actor; he is stark, honest and innocent performance is central to this heartbreaking, yet uplifing film.  The connection between him and Larson IS the film's soul.  Dealing with a difficult subject matter, but being shown it through the eyes of the young boy, totally works.  Would definitely recommend this to all.
Brie Larson and newcomer Jacob Tremblay feature powerful performances that build up to a chemistry so extraordinary, it is almost heartbreaking to find that connection relatable.

I just saw the movie "Room" which is highly acclaimed and rated in the 90's on Rotten Tomatoes for both pros and us regular folk. It is a difficult one to recommend because the subject matter is so repulsive and difficult and the way it its told is a slow unfolding. This is a film, not a movie.The movie geek in me liked it a lot...brought me to tears a couple of times (but then I am in a weepy state right now so maybe it was just me). The intermittent voiceover throughout is the little boy, trying to describe the world through his own eyes. I will only share this: It is the story of a young woman who was kidnapped off the street at 17 and then locked in a room by a sicko man for 7 years, where she also gave birth to a little boy who turns 5 as the movie opens. The title is where they lived "Room" which was his only world until they escaped and a world that he often misses as he's trying to figure out what is real and not real and where his comfort lies. The performances are grade A. I give it a 4.5 as a film but don't recommend it for those of you who are looking for lighter  entertainment.

Some movies you watch. They may be touching, they may be entertaining, but sitting in the dark you are always aware that you are watching a movie that has been created to entertain you. Some movies sweep you along, caressing your empathy and tugging at your heart, enveloping you in the experience of the movie itself. So it is with Room, the new and exciting film that captures the wonder and joy of life's simplicities and celebrates the power of human resilience. With a unique voice from director Lenny Abrahamson, breathtaking, nuanced performances from Brie Larson and the young Jacob Tremblay and a rich visual world captured through the eyes of innocence, Room is not to be missed!

Room is spectacular. Ok, well, half spectacular. The first half admittedly flies by but it's such an interesting premise helmed by two excellent performances from the get-go. It's a movie I'd give an A+ up until the 1:10 mark (or so) but afterwards it starts a steady decline of mundaneness. It could have really benefited from a stretched out first half with more thrills OR maybe Terrence Malick assisting the second to try to actually capture the wonder of the world. Instead it's just a bumpy finish to an otherwise incredible race.
The movie is a must see.  It is excellent!

Such a story is hard to pull off on film. What works in the novel can't work here because film is a more objectified experience (and the limited view of the narrator can't really limit the scope of your own experience and the access to information through other channels). I loved the movie, but I have some issues with it, the main issue being that the second half never lives up to the thrills of the first half. Don't get me wrong - I still enjoyed it and the actors did some great work (even though there were some false moments, such as Jack's inability to handle a phone: Really?! That bright and adaptive kid who was so curious about everything and spent so much time observing people couldn't really get the chance to see others speak on the phone in the long weeks he spent in his grandmother's house?!) but the second half had a bit of a dragging problem, as if it they didn't know where to go with that story for a while. But I was immersed in it, mostly due to the unassuming visual flair. And the performances: wow, these performance by Jacob Tremblay and Brie Larson were hypnotic! I especially loved the craziness in the room, especially Brie's moments of clarity when she had to convince Jack of going through with her plan. There was something manic about her character and this ambiguity felt real to me. And Jacob Tremblay - I know this is such an extreme pitfall of a role and he makes it look so easy and there are so many layers and details to this experience of a performance. Go watch them.

"Room" is an emotive, powerfully acted and modest piece that refrains from cheap sentimentality

Exceptional performances as Jack (Jacob Tremblay) and Ma (Brie Larson) are the highlight here. You won't want to look away from them-not that director Lenny Abrahamson lets you. He never tries to distract you from the fact that there's two people on screen the whole time. He embraces it. It's a wise decision.

Abrahamson displays an unnerving knack for extracting emotion. The thinness of the plot is an issue with the source material, and what could have been a hokey feel-good or a crime thriller is instead a tribute to love, life, and human strength that (almosts) steers free of being overly sentimental.

The performances are delivered in expert hands that know just when to slow down and let them breathe, when to cut, when to jack up the intensity. We get familiar with closeups and extreme closeups, and it works. The minimalist soundtrack is gorgeously composed and holds our attention during the many diaglogue-free sequences. The same stands for set design and locations. They're inobstrusive and they complement the film's true strengths. The emotional complexity that stirs (or roars) in every scene. The flawless acting. The characters and relationships that are built with such care and attention to nuance that the film's few falters are easily forgivable.

A chance for a thriller moment is fumbled in the scene when Jack and Old Nick are approached by the first stranger with his dog. Perhaps Abrahamson felt that a more amped up exchange would have been an easy gimmick, but there was definitely something lost in choosing not to dial up the intensity here. The moment called for it.

Regardless, Abrahamson's intuition for storytelling is obvious and refreshing. I only ask that he trust himself more. The pacing is organic, the shots are thoughtfully structured, and he knows how to work within the confines of the story. The film connects. And it does that without the triter voiceovers from Jack and the spots of heavy-handed sappiness (especially in the haircut scene). The music supports the movie well, and so it reaches too-cheesy levels when the film does. We don't need to be cued so obviously as to what and when we're supposed to feel. If you've done the job well, and Abrahamson has, we'll get there on our own.

Based on the novel by Emma Donoghue tells the story of Ma and her 5 year old son Jack, who are living in the confines of  'Room'.  To give away anymore would be giving away too much of the plot.  If you've read the book you've obviously got an idea of what happens however, for those that are not aware of this film I beg you to go in with no preconceptions and for gods sake do not watch the trailer (unless you want the whole thing spoiled).

What you get from Room is a very powerful and emotive film with excellent performances from Ma (Brie Larson) and Jack (played by Jacob Tremblay, a relative newcomer whose only previous release was voicing a Smurf).  The supporting cast including Joan Allen and William H. Macy also put in good performances.  However it's the mother and son which deserve the plaudits.  Brie Larson, who up until now appears to have been in mostly supporting roles in films such as 21 Jump Street and Scott Pilgrim vs the World, however in Room she really displays her acting capabilities and from this performance she should be a contender for best actress when award season comes around.  

As you watch Room, the second half of the film feels like there isn't much happening however, this is a film about the experience and emotions of these two characters and how their confides mold their lives and the effects it has on them psychologically.  There are moments when seemingly innocent scenarios dispense a sense of fear, paranoia and tension which are caused as a result of the predicament they find themselves in.  There are also moments elation and unexpected humour.  But it's that sense of paranoia and fear especially with regards to children which is a reflection of today's society and is depicted here so well which makes this film both true and sad in equal measure.  Room can be tough and unpleasant viewing, I saw it as part of Odeon's Screen Unseen and I probably wouldn't have seen it otherwise but I've very glad that I did.

A very harrowing tale about a mother and her son being held captive in a very small room.
The movie starts out and we are introduced to young Jack and his mother.  They are in a tiny room, and have minimal space, resources and food.  We learn that she was abducted and has been held for 7 years in a desperate dire situation.  While there she has gave birth to a boy who is now 5.  All he knows is this room.

Let's get something straight here.  Bri Larson was unreal.  Her acting chops were off the charts. Jacob Tremblay however was just as good as her son.  
He did a phenomenal job with his emotions.  The bond felt genuine, and I really believed it happened to these two.

The first part of the movie deals with the captivity and how they interact with each other, how she tries to teach him of a world outside the room.
Part 2 deals with their escape.  How in the world could you deal mentally with the 7 years that you have suffered?  
Now free mother and son try their hardest to adjust. He learns of the world, and how to interact with others.  The trasnformation on display from Tremblay is just fantastic.  He grows bit by bit, and learns more of the world.  He just is awesome here.

Brie Larson also has a believable trasnformation on screen and she tries to cope with her life back in the real world, and tries to raise her son and get him to a normal place.

Just a fantastic movie fueled by a harrowing story that really had an affect on my emotions.   A great movie moves you and this one did just that.

The boy who plays her son is a superstar, I loved how he partly narrated. A must see, it will break your heart, make you laugh and make you cry.

It should be noted that Jacob Tremblay has perhaps the best performance by a child actor ever. And Brie Larson as his mother is mostly terrific. It's one of the most emotional films of the year, and I think that is mostly its saving grace, as it helps mask some flaws. But I also can think of few films that everyone should see. This is one for sure. I could honestly go for about 2 more hours of watching Tremblay experience "World" elements for the first time. I can completely understand the immense amount of love for this one, but at the moment, I'm lukewarm on the overall package.

Based on the novel by Emma Donoghue, this film is a small story driven independent harrowing dramatic thriller. And like many of its kind, the film has to rely on a great screenplay, solid acting, and moving character development for it to get wide recognition. The film delivers on all of these aspects. Director Lenny Abrahamson (Frank) has adapted the best-selling novel with grace and grandeur. Here is a film so artistically unique and deviant, chock full of genuine emotion thanks to two outstanding performances, that isn't afraid to take risks and surprise at every turn. The entire idea of 'room,' the abstract concept of space, is ever-present in the production. In their bubble of room, Ma and Jack are restricted, as evident by Abrahamson's close angles and tight shots. The small space allows for high concept filmmaking, and when they get out of room, it only gets better, with a new color palette and experimental camera angles through Jack's eyes. The entire film is seen through the eyes of this child, and it's genius. The title of the film makes the film about the space in our lives and in our selves and our need to escape whatever walls or restrictions that others  or we ourselves  have imposed on us. So our experience really is reflected in this freakish story. The film is about the vast room we have at our disposal not the small room to which we might accept restriction. This couldn't be further from Lenny Abrahamson's last film Frank, a bizarre music-orientated comedy. Gone are the idiosyncrasies that made Frank wild and, for many including myself, compelling, instead we have a moving drama that earns its sentiment. The concept of a mother having raised her son in confinement then finally breaking free has many avenues to explore. Having not read Emma Donoghue's book, of whom also wrote the screenplay, I mostly expected a small scale -getting out of the eponymous room then reuniting and resolving itself there. Instead, the film goes further than I expected, getting Ma  also known as Joy, which is becoming a familiar character's name this year  and Jack back to her teenage home with her own mother. The story follows twenty-something Joy aka Ma (Brie Larson) and five year-old Jack (Jacob Tremblay), inside a garden shed. We are, of course, unaware that this is a garden shed, but the size is what's immediately noticeable. Small, dark, and dank, with a single skylight. Jack, the product of Ma's kidnapping despite her insistence of his immaculate conception, is oblivious to the space of the room, or lack thereof, and equally of the world outside it. Most nights, a man called "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers) visits the room to have sex with Ma. But Jack doesn't understand this custom, instead letting his imagination dream up a world of wonderment, all existing neatly in the boundaries of the room  where a mouse joyfully nibbles on some scraps and where his imaginary dog Lucky can frolic. In Jack's mind, the only reality is inside the room, and everything on the other side of the wall is most certainly outer space. After one particularly traumatizing night, when Jack wanders out of his hiding spot to observe the sleeping adults and is frightened by both Nick and an instance of physical violence against Ma, the fatigued woman realizes that she must coach the young boy into aiding with an escape plan to finally rid them of the restrictive imprisonment of the room. Providing any more details would soften the impact of the film, and this is one that is meant to be felt  even if it's a true kick in the gut. For the first half of the film, we as viewers are held prisoners right along with Ma and Jack. We see what a patient and wonderful mother she is as she strives to provide some semblance of hope for her son, though in a nearly hopeless situation. When Jack turns 5, Ma begins to explain the outside world to him, as she knows they must try to escape in order for her son to have any semblance of a normal life. During this time, we are in awe of this 10 x 10 environment and how it is every bit the nightmare we have imagined while reading the articles and seeing the reports on real life ordeals. The second half of the film is equally fascinating, as we watch young Jack and his sense of wonder and caution at discovering the real world. We also see the psychological trauma that Ma experiences after staying strong for so long. Assimilating into society brings different challenges for both Ma and Jack, plus those of her mother (Joan Allen), her father (William H Macy) and her mom's new beau (Tom McCamus). The film doesn't shy away from their reactions, though some are easier to stomach than others. The different approach is felt immediately as Abrahamson traps us with his two principle characters, Ma and Jack, in tight and sometimes oddly framed closeups. It's a somewhat clumsy execution to show the claustrophobia and intimacy Abrahamson wants to achieve as he uses Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay's faces as blank canvases, but the effect is thoroughly felt, and the film's following 30 minutes remain its best. The photography decides to take a step back, but it continues to catch that raw emotion. Then, in a way, it doesn't go far enough. But it's interesting to watch it play in its happy medium. It does rely on some key contrivances to get there, such as the kidnapper's wonky perception and ultimately not fighting hard enough when he could have, but that doesn't take away from the gripping escape sequence as the orchestra swells and squeezes tears from you whether you like it or not. The only criticism of the directorial style was the lapse in direction that the story was supposed to take towards the end of the film. The entire time the story was told through the eyes of Jack. However, towards the last part of the movie, there was a shift that included some of Ma's point of view. This slightly took away from the ways a five year old would try to explain certain behaviors or actions of adults. Also, for those who have read the book, don't expect the movie to include every aspect of it. Just like every other film based on books, graphic novels, comics, or even true events, only certain aspects can be adapted and some must be altered in order to try and make the best move possible. The performances are superb and so consistent with the storyline, there isn't any pretense that any of this was stage or acted. The relationships are well developed within the timeframe of the movie and are delightfully varied to reveal the breadth of human responses to such a tragedy. Brie Larson had not only shown potential but delivered the goods with 2013's Short Term 12. It's a similar environment here with devoted maternal instincts but this time it's pushed to the brink of her skills as an actress. She's drenched in this exasperation that speaks to years of exhaustion. In the tone of her primal performance, she paints a full rich portrait of Joy's whole life from her carefree teen years to her brutal capture by Old Nick when she was 17, to every little story and lesson she's told Jack. Joy's constantly revising the way she raises Jack and while there's bumps in the road, it's a complete picture of motherhood. She balances resilience and vulnerability, hope and dejection with a fine tooth comb. Most times she commands the screen and offers one of the year's best performances. It's a film about the harsh realities of growing up, operating for both of the main characters, and it's a very sensitive and emotionally potent portrayal. Speaking of which, Jacob Tremblay may be the frontrunner for most supporting actor awards as his performance is better then a lot of child actors. How they got a kid this young to pull off the necessary emotions that few adult can properly show off? I don't know, but this is defiantly his movie. Is perception on the world and the adults around him remind us why we were frightened by the rest of the world as children. When our parents aren't around, we might as well be on an alien planet, stepping around strange sounds and sights. This child made me realize how one can see the world differently at a different age. Joan Allen, as Joy's mother, is heartfelt and shows unconditional love in a wonderfully nuanced way, whereas William H. Macy, Joy's father, is regretfully underused but doing the 'in over his head' thing Macy does best. On the whole, 'Room' is an emotional journey through trauma and discovery with the help of a very strong storytelling and acting. Room fell short in some aspects, though they did not sufficiently diminish the overall experience of the film. It brings different concepts for those to learn from, such as the importance of family, experience, and empathy towards others. If you want to escape the confinements of recent big budget films, or want to experience something moving that you will not forget, go see Room. The film deserves a watch!

It takes a while to grasp the circumstance our lead characters face -- living as prisoners for seven years in a sealed storage shed, a young woman has a child who has never seen the outside. It's horrifying and warmly engaging all at once. And then, in a beautifully suspenseful sequence, it all changes, revealing an entirely new set of challenges. ROOM-2015(R)-Dec. 7.
BY:The Movie Guy.

Inspired by true crime stories, Room is the wrenching story of a young woman (Brie Larson) abducted & held captive for seven years in a backyard shed. It is also the story of a young boy whose whole live has been lived within the confines of that shed coming to experience the real world for the first time. For five-year-old Jack (Jacob Tremblay) the world is only as wide as the one room he & his mother have shared. His concept of reality is the present physical existence as he knows it versus the "not real" portrayed on television. When Ma realizes that Jack's youth & her protection will soon not be enough to safeguard him from their captor Old Nick (Sean Bridgers) Ma devises a plan for Jack's escape. Directed by Lenny Abrahamson from a screenplay written by Emma Donoghue who adapted her best-selling novel of the same name, Room is the intensely emotional story of a mother's love & protection of her child. Just as in her previous performance in Short Term 12, Brie Larson delivers a marvelous performance that is both fierce & heartbreaking. Newcomer Jacob Tremblay gives an outstanding performance in his debut film. The performances from the rest of the cast were fantastic. MUST-SEE FILM OF THE YEAR.

Human exploration of people captive in films is a very interesting subject that Hollywood and independent studios produce.

Movies such as Shawshank Redemption (1994) The Green Mile (1999), Papillon (1973), Rescue Dawn (2006) Empire of The Sun (1987), Unbroken (2014) Misery (1990) and Buried (2010) represents a wide variety of sub plots that goes from: Jails, prisoners of war and actual abduction.

In the film "Room" Director Lenny Abrahmson explore the life of Ma (Brie Larson) and his son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) who are confined in this small room, which contain a rudimentary kitchen, a bed, a toilet, a sink and a skylight. The film starts when Jack is turning 5 and her mom is doing her best effort to celebrate this landmark, by baking a cake. Throughout the film develops, the audience discover that they are locked in this room by a guy called Old Nick (Sean Bridges) who bring them supplies every night and also for sex with Ma. Ma was abducted about eight years ago in the film plot. Jack is living in a reality that is only portrayed in his personal window to the world, the television. Ironically the real window of the world for Ma is the skylight in this room, she can see the seasons and the time of the day, but for Jack is nothing. He don't know how the real world is and his sense of space is limited but the fact that Ma is the only person that he ever interacted. For Jack the room is a confined world but is a world of fantasies, sounds, smells and strange voices ( Old Nick paying a visit to Ma every night for sex)

Ma tries to give Jack some education by making him read books like Alice and Wonderland, but Ma also wants to escape and give Jack the life that he deserve. The process won't be easy...The escape is a beautiful and poetic moment which is also the biggest revelation for Jack been free for the first time. 

The film Room is a very difficult film to watch, is a movie about the love of a mother for his child, the wounds of a person been abducted for years, the adaptation of a little boy to the real world, but also is a movie about justice and human and family values.

Brie Larson is outstanding in this role as well Jacob Tremblay, the film, is really well edited and well directed who carefully crafted with the art direction team the perfect space to make the audience feel locked in that Room.

One of the lack in this movie is the development of Ma's dad Robert Newsome (Willam H Macy) his character become important when a pivotal moment happen in the movie and later vanished from everyone's mind.

Which of the following situations would you find the most traumatic? (1) You are kidnapped, removed from everyone and everything you know and love, never knowing if you will ever be free again. (2) You are born into a captivity in which you know hardly anything about what most people take for granted as "the world" and then are suddenly thrust into that world with almost no understanding of what you're seeing, what to do or how to behave. Stop. Think about it. Either situation would be a horribly upsetting and disorienting to experience. We see both situations play out in the fictional drama "Room" (R, 1:58). Although the film is not based on any specific real-life story, it does have a strong basis in reality - in the cases that we occasionally see on the news or in a true-crime TV drama. A young woman is taken captive by a monstrous person who holds her for years against her will. In some cases, innocent children are born into such situations, knowing nothing but confinement, with only a mother's love to depend on. 

Joy Newsome (Brie Larson) was seventeen when a man who claimed that he needed help with a sick dog abducted Joy and imprisoned her in the garden shed in his back yard. The man (Sean Bridgers), whose name Joy didn't know (simply referring to him as "Old Nick") kept Joy as a sex slave, bringing her just enough food and other essentials to survive. He brought her supplies once a week, but visited her for sex every night. Eventually, Old Nick's ongoing rape of Joy produced a baby boy.  Joy named him Jack. Jack only knows Joy as "Ma". He has never even seen Old Nick. At a set time every night, Joy sends Jack to sleep on the floor of the wardrobe in the corner of the room. Old Nick punches a code into the door's electronic lock. He enters. He does "his business" and leaves. Jack is now free to climb into bed with Ma.

The days belong to Joy and Jack (Jacob Tremblay). He's now five years old. He has never had a haircut, never seen a doctor and never left Room. The wardrobe where he sleeps when Old Nick comes calling, Ma's bed, a toilet, bathtub, sink, toaster oven, small table and old television is all Jack has ever known. As far as he knows, the world he sees on TV is all made up and the small skylight in the roof of the shed is outer space. To Jack, there simply is nothing else but Room, the mysterious voice of Old Nick, and Ma. For her part, Joy does all she can for Jack. She "cooks" the meager rations that Old Nick brings and she breastfeeds Jack. She's his teacher, his playmate, his protector and, basically the only person who exists.

As hard as Joy works to make a life for her and Jack in Room, their situation is starting to change, calling their long-term survival into question. Joy has tried to escape before, but it becomes clear to her that she has to try again. Maybe Jack is now old enough to help - if she can get him to understand her plan. It isn't a spoiler to reveal that Joy's escape plan works, because that is what the second half of this movie is about. Joy is reunited with her mother (Joan Allen) and father (William H. Macy), who are now divorced. Joy and Jack move in with her mother and her mother's boyfriend (Tom McCamus) who do their best to help Joy and Jack adjust to their newfound freedom, with all that means for each of them.

These adjustments aren't be easy. Jack has to learn... everything that you and I take for granted about our world. Joy has to try to get past the emotional trauma of seven years of captivity and having raised a son in that environment. Then, of course, there are certain legal questions that a family lawyer is now there to handle... and the media circus that naturally accompanies such stories in real life. This film doesn't dwell on the legal or public aspects of this case, but those elements are there in the background, even while this dramatically changed family focuses on finding a way to forge fresh bonds and move forward in the most difficult of situations.

"Room" is as remarkable as the story it portrays. Basing the film on the 2010 novel by Emma Donoghue (who also wrote the screenplay) frees the plot to explore a wide variety of issues without being confined to the details of one specific real-life case. Telling the story through Jack's eyes (complete with a judicious use of well-written narration by the boy) helps us to understand the wide ranging implications of such an experience for Jack, his mother and his newfound family. Director Lenny Abrahamson takes full advantage of these story-telling opportunities with his use of camera angles and the markedly different tone in the movie's very different halves. Topping it all off are exceptionally affecting performances by all the main characters - especially Larson and Tremblay. Although the pacing of the film sometimes lags unnecessarily, there is no criticizing this film's emotional impact and the importance of the lessons that it teaches its audience. I have no room to give this film anything less than an "A".

Room is directed by Lenny Abrahamson and stars Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, Joan Allen, Sean Bridgers, and William H. Macy. 
The film is about a woman named Joy "Ma" Newsome who was abducted and held captive in a room for seven years, and her son, Jack who is five years old and has been living inside that particular room his entire life. The film follows their attempt at escaping from that place and as we see through Jack's eyes, his experience of the outside world for the first time in his life.
This is definitely at the top of my best movies of the year, simply because it is incredibly done and perfectly portrayed. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give some of the best performances I've ever seen in my life in any movie what so ever. The kid, Jacob, is phenomenal and surprisingly he carries it all throughout. You'd think that an amazing actress like Brie, and her character would be the center of the movie but that's actually not the case. As she says so in the movie, her kid saves her many times, and that goes to show just how different and amazingly done this movie really is. 
The director (Lenny Abrahamson) also did a very good job here, as he kept us interested and entertained through the first part of the movie when they're in the room. That is really hard to do, considering that there are not much things to do or a lot of different ways to go about it but this director did it. The music composed by Stephen Rennicks is very touching and gives those very much needed and present emotional moments meaning and heart. 
I think that one of the main reasons as to why this movie worked so wonderfully well was the screenplay written by the author of the original book that this movie is based upon, Emma Donoghue. More movies should take notice of this and be loyal to the main source because that's the best way to succeed at making an adaptation.

'Room" is a novel adaptation that follows the story of a mother who was taken captivity as a  young teenager. She gave birth to her son, Jack, and was left with no choice but to raise him in a small, confined room. For five years, all Jack knew was that room, and all he had was his mother. Through life changing events, they soon escape Room and must figure out how to make their way in the real world.

To start out, this movie was amazing. Congratulations to Brie Larson for winning best female actress for her performance here because she truly deserves it. She put on an amazing emotional performance and although she was the star of the film, someone here overtook her spot as best performer in my opinion. With no disrespect, Jacob Tremblay was amazing. He is by far one of the best child actors I've seen in years, and there were more than a few moments where he left my tongue tied. He was so natural for his role and fit perfectly, and at no point did I say "I'm watching actors on screen", rather, I felt as though I was watching real people. Those are really the two primary actors throughout the film and they were both perfect. All of the supporting actors, such as Joan Allen and Tom McCamus, all played their roles well, and impressed in small screen time. You should see this movie for the performances alone.

I really fell for the screenplay and the directing in this movie. I really loved all of the little details and the overall story of "Room", and the writer really knows how to put so much depth into a single story. This child, Jack, is raised in a single room with limited tangible objects, but he is raised to believe that this is the entire world. The Mother, Joy, has lived here for more than half a decade, and is at the point where she's in agony. The only thing she really has left to live for is her son, and throughout the film, you can really see the difficulties that she has to go through. Seeing one character who's mostly content, and another who can barely live makes for two strong parallels within the film. I really loved the psychological impact upon the characters that resulted due to this isolation, and this movie felt so real. 

Ultimately, the movie isn't entirely about the people and their experience in this room, but rather the impact that this had on their lives and their struggle to adapt to the real world. It shows on both characters, especially the son, who must make major leaps at such a young age. The movie hits you at an emotional level, and is an intelligent film in every way.

I actually enjoyed the pacing of this movie, and I felt that it moved at a solid pace. I was always intrigued by the current events on screen and it managed to tell this story in an inspiring way. They spent about the first hour of the movie within Room, and spent the last half of the film outside of Room. Going into the film, I expected the film to stay in Room for less than half of the run time. Although I was interested none the less, I do wish they spent less time in Room and spent more time on the outside so that we could see their struggles just a bit more, but that doesn't damage the experience of watching this movie in the end.

There were also many moments where I was on the verge of tears, and at the very lest, feeling goosebumps up and down my arm. If you think about it, this movie really is dark, but still has an uplifting an inspiring message. For those who really appreciate the art of film making, and for those who want to see amazing screenplays, then watch this film.

There were also a few moments where I saw the awkward adaptation from novel to film. When a book is put on the big screen, there are obvious moments that few eyes can see (eyes who haven't read the book) that make the film feel a bit sloppy. There are just a couple things or moments that feel out of place, and it seems as though the book went more in depth on a few things that the film lacked on.

In the end, "Room" is probably one of my favorite movies of the year. It was an emotional ride that impressed me throughout. However, I do wish they spent less time in Room, because it felt like they were rushing a bit in the second half to cram the story in. There was also one unresolved side plot that was left untouched, and I would've liked to see everything resolved. I still had a great experience with this film, and if it weren't for those flaws I stated above, this movie would've received a perfect rating. However, I still encourage everyone to view this movie.

This is the best movie of the year (so far). Harrowing, heartbreaking, devastating, yet it turns into something that manages to question how we live our lives and ends up being oddly uplifting and life-affirming. Jacob Tremblay is probably the best kid actor I've ever seen.

It's debatable whether or not Room follows a three-act structure. I'd say it does not. I'm a fan of the three-act structure, and generally a detractor of films that abandon it. This is one for which I make exception.

Room is getting all sorts of praise for the acting, and deservedly so, but in my opinion, it is the screenplay that should be most acclaimed. This is a film that shows a lot, but doesn't tell much.

Ultimately, Room somehow manages the task of making unrelatable characters relatable. Though the events in this film are thankfully an outrageously rare real-life occurance, the characters in this film are outrageously real enough to make them someone you can identify with.

It's hard to think of a more emotionally grueling and uplifting movie this year than Room. It drops you right into a scary world and, thanks to its carefully balanced tone, the film eschews sensationalism and gets at the beating heart of its survival story, namely the love and protection of a mother for her son. It is an emotionally powerful story that hits the big moments, the small moments, and everything in between. It left me analyzing it and rethinking it for hours, the repercussions still reverberating through me. 

Ma (Brie Larson) has been held in a single soundproof room for seven years, the captive of an older man who is termed "Old Nick" (Sean Bridgers). Complicating matters is that Ma has a five-year-old son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) born into this captivity. It is the only world he's known. To spare him the full horror of their circumstances, Ma has created an elaborate world for him that only exists in Room. After his fifth birthday, Ma tries speaking honestly to her son, lifting the veil of kind fabrications. Together they will scheme to escape their one-room world, but it comes with tremendous cost. 

It would be easy to fall onto the more seemly elements of this harrowing story and linger on just how bad things are and the horrifying lengths that Ma has to go through to survive. Director Lenny Abrahamson (Frank) doesn't have to wallow in depravity to get its point across. There's a sensitivity that manages to temper some of the abuse in a manner that won't make you run out of the room screaming. When Old Nick enters the room for his special time with Ma, we don't need explicit detail to understand what is happening and what Ma is shielding Jack from by demanding he stay in the closet. The reality of their captivity is enough without underlining the worst of the worst for the lowest common denominator. The emotional weight of everything is clear without having to be bludgeoned. The implications are always just peaking around the corners from the safer version of reality Ma has proposed to protect her child. As the audience, we can see the cracks, we can see her front, and we can see the effort and the toll it's taking on Ma. The stakes are clear as well, and so when Ma is instructing Jack and preparing him on their joint escape plan, you'll start to feel waves of anxiety travel through your body. I was shaking with suspense that something could go wrong but also because Ma and Jack are such vulnerable characters that rely upon one another completely. I knew what was going to happen in broad strokes but I was still on the edge of my seat and that's because the movie made me deeply care about the characters and their plight. The escape scene was on par with some of the better suspense sequences in the equally brilliant Sicario. 

It's not really a spoiler to say that Ma and Jack do get out of their one-room prison because the second half of the film deals with the ongoing consequences and challenges of adjustment. We'd like to think that we can be plugged into our old lives after spending time away, but that's just not how things work, let alone for people who have experienced substantial psychological and physical trauma. Ma is struggling to readjust to her old life under the care of her mother, Nancy (Joan Allen). She looks through old high school pictures and you can tell she laments "what could have been" and even bears some resentment for her old friends who got to live the lives she should have had. Just because she's free doesn't mean she's better. Her father Robert (William H. Macy), since divorced from Ma's mother, can't even look at Jack because of the pain it causes; Jack is a child of rape, but Ma demands he be acknowledged as her flesh-and-blood, and even that can be too much too soon for Robert. He's more about seeking justice through the courts and as a result stays on the peripheral of the story for most of the movie. There is no exact time table for PTSD and Ma goes through highs and lows, none lower than when pressed with the question of why she held onto Jack after he was born. Would he not have had a better life in someone else's care, assuming Old Nick would have abandoned him rather than kill his own blood? It's a hard question and it stings. 

For an obviously punishing story about the worst of humanity, I am not kidding when I say Room is an uplifting film. The darkness is easy to identify and Old Nick is a fearsome and all too real antagonist, one who could roam our very streets in anonymity. However, what stays with me several days after watching Room is not the suffering but the resiliency of spirit, the knack human beings have to persevere amidst the worst. Ma's recovery is rockier but more understandable for us to trace and relate with. Hers is an experience where she can finally begin to focus on something other than her child's safety and deliverance, namely her own well-being. For Jack, there is no playbook. He's spent his entire life inside a small room and never seen the outside world. His sense of understanding has been extremely limited and yet his sense of exploration is alive. Jack slowly and surely builds trusting relationships with Ma's relatives, engaging in other activities, and acclimating to his new surroundings, reforming his sense of the world. It's ultimately Jack who is able to make the greatest breakthrough to his mother, and it's this moment of sacrifice and love that unleashed the last torrent of my tears. Previously I had cried two times over the horrors and Ma's love as her strength, and it was this final moment, this sharing of his "Strong," that let loose the happy tears. 

It should go without saying but Larson gives an exceptionally powerful performance. After 2013's stupendous Short Term 12, I knew this actress was destined for great things, especially the way she can zero in on a character and inhabit them fully. With Ma (she's never given any other name) Larson is able to convey a multitude of emotions, many of which she has to hide from her son out of loving deference. He can't know just how scared and exhausted she is, though these emotions do take over at time. Larson is tremendous as she exhumes maternal might as she does everything in her power to save the two of them. Early on, she's the character we empathize with the most because she's had her world taken from her and hoping to return. She's so resourceful, from the way she's able to answer her son's questions about the world, to the way she's able to practice and drill their escape plan to a child with no concept of "outside," this is a powerful woman driven by the instinct to endure. When Larson's façade breaks down with Jack, that's when the movie started stabbing me like daggers. In the second half, her character has a long road to go to recovery, if that's even an appropriate word, and Larson gives sensitive and empathetic consideration to every exhausted development. She is easily going to be the one to beat this year for the Best Actress Oscar.

Paired with Larson is the remarkably natural child actor Jacob Tremblay, and his performance is worthy of awards consideration itself. At first his worldview is precocious because of how unique it is, which makes him more a figure of fascination than tragedy. He's bright and active with the world around him, turning household items into useful toys and emotional attachments. The film uses parts of his narration to give better insight into just how he's processing the world he knows versus the world as it exists. These bouts of narration never come across as cloying. As the movie continues, he learns more about how his preconceptions of the world are wrong, but he's more intrigued than frightened. During the escape plan, when Jack gets to see the outside world for the first time, it's a transcendent emotional moment. His guarded behavior around others is necessary as Jack builds positive associations with men who are not Old Nick. Tremblay is utterly magnificent; there is no hint of artifice to his performance, which is especially rewarding considering his is a role that could have been suffocated with eccentricities and tics. You feel like you're watching a child grow before you through supportive nurturing. 

Within the first twenty minutes of watching Room I already knew this was one of the best films of 2015. It just connects so vividly and succinctly, effortlessly powerful and yet skillfully avoiding sensationalism and exploitation while telling an entertaining survival story that still resonates with emotional truth. The performances from mother and son are outstanding and Larson and Tremblay form a heroic duo that take hold of your heart. It doesn't mitigate the darkness or the cruel realities of its premise but Room also doesn't dwell in the darkness, castigating its characters as hapless victims forever broken from their incalculable suffering. They are resourceful and resilient and while their trauma is will not be forgotten it is not the one defining moment of their burgeoning lives. It may sound maudlin but it is the power of love that resonates the longest with Room. That love at first is about protecting the innocent, and then it transforms into healing and acceptance. I hope everybody gets a chance to see Room, a remarkable film with two remarkable performances and plenty to say about the humanizing benefit of love.

Following the story and escape of young Jack Newsome and mother Joy Newsome from "Room", the garden shed of a deranged kidnapper, Room is heartfelt and moving, making the audience thankful for what they have in the true spirit of Thanksgiving.

            Room is narrated from the perspective of five-year old Jack, beginning on the morning of his fifth birthday. Following Jack around his tour of the shed, Room immediately gives the audience an idea of the experiences that Jack and his loving "ma" have gone through. Knowing nothing of the outside world, Jack has a limited perception of the world, his only experiences coming from television programs and a limited skylight view of the sky, "Outer Space". Joy, realizing that she and Jack can no longer live in these conditions, decides that Jack is old enough to know that room isn't all the world is. Questioning her proposition of reality beyond room, Jack throws a fit before calming down and accepting the truth. Soon enough, Joy wants more for her son than solely knowledge of the outside world and begins her plans for their escape. Joy, forging a high fever for Jack, heats his forehead with hot towels, hoping to sell the idea to their captor, a middle-aged and scruffy man by the name of "Old Nick". Nick refuses to take Jack to the hospital, instead compromising by bringing antibiotics the next day. Jack and Joy spring to work, coming up with another plan the moment Nick steps out the soundproofed dungeon-like shed. Joy rolls Jack up in a rug, preparing him with the proper instructions for what to do when he is placed in the bed of Nick's truck. Joy sells Nick on the idea that Jack is dead and convinces him to bury Jack somewhere besides his backyard, also forcing Nick to swear that he won't look at Jack's not-so-dead body. Jack follows Joy's instructions carefully and successfully rolls, wiggles, and jumps out of Nick's truck. Jack then bumps into a stranger who calls the cops who then find and free Joy from room and bring the two to a hospital, where they await the arrival of Joy's parents. The remainder of the movie follows Jack and Joy's reintegration into the society they have been held away from for so long, as well as Jack's adaptation to strangers, his family, and the world.

            Though most child actors fail to impress, it would be impossible to overlook the incredible acting of Jacob Tremblay. His portrayal of emotions for such a dark concept is amazing for any actor, but truly marvelous for once so young. As Tremblay ages, one would only hope that he manages to continue to uphold the high standards he has set for himself. Tremblay's performance is truly a spectacle and his mature and emotional acting is sure to catch the eye of the Academy when Oscar season rolls around.

            Danny Cohen, Room's cinematographer, instills meaning in every frame. While still in captivity, Cohen sets the camera just enough off-focus to provide a feeling of subjectivity into the perception of Ma and Jack as captives without detracting audience appeal. Once freed, however, Room's shots flash with brightness before simmering down, showing the journey of Jack as he is thrusted into a bright, sunny, foreign world, a strange reality to him, before he begins to adapt to his new life and new environment. Both beautiful and meaningful, Cohen's cinematography is masterful.

An instant classic, Room is a masterpiece comprised of beautiful cinematography and fantastic acting. My love for Room knows no boundaries.

A tense, well-acted suspense film that opens up and goes unexpected places in the last act.  The first hour is really a showcase for Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay ... the last half hour is really what makes the film.

This is a perfect example of a film that sold me just by its premise: A boy who has been kept in one room his entire life by his mother, begins to wonder what the limits of the world beyond the walls of the enclosed area are.  It's also a film that if you're planning on going to see, you shouldn't watch any of the trailers or even read the IMDB synopsis.  Just go out and see one of the best films of the year.  

Brie Larson, who impresses more and more each film she appears in, plays Joy, mother of Jack.  Larson hides the depths of her character for a good portion of the film, which makes the emotional moments all the more powerful later on.  The story of a mother and son trying to escape this 'room' and their whole emotional journey is what drives Room to greatness.  The film itself has a unique structure in that it seems the film could have ended about 45 minutes before it did, but yet it keeps going.  It's not that that time is wasted, but I think the flow and rhythm of the movie isn't always there.  Which is why the emotional moments midway through are what stick out to me most.

Jacob Tremblay absolutely kills it as Jack.  At 5 years old and an extremely demanding role, it's hard not to think he deserves some awards attention as well.  He pulls off every emotion that is called of him and his chemistry with Brie Larson couldn't be better.  The supporting cast is really good as well, but that can get into spoiler territory so I'll stick with the two leads.  I also should mention Lenny Abrahamson's directing.  I loved the way he chose to unveil why exactly Jack and his mother are stuck in this room and the revelations that follow.  

Room as a whole isn't always as smooth as it wants to be, but the performances are among the years best, and I think the story will take you on an unexpected emotional roller coaster.

+Emotional journey

+Meticulous directing

"Room" is an engaging and moving picture with remarkable performances from its leads. Brie Larson gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Ma, and her connection with Jacob Tremblay absolutely dominates the screen. The film sticks true to the source material, as it focuses more on the psychological ramifications of escaping this scenario, rather than the escape itself. At the heart of this movie isn't the tale of a kidnapping, but a mother trying to raise her son, and how he grows up to view the world through her care.

A shame that most people won't see it......unless it gets multiple Oscar nods, which it should.

Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay play a mother and her young son who were held captive for five years. For the son, the room (hence the title) was the whole world since he's spent his entire life in it. And initially, I was like: 'yeah, I'm not really buying this premise.' But once the two finally escape, that's where the strong screenplay and direction come into play. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay give once in a lifetime performances that feel unbelievably genuine. If Brie Larson doesn't win Best Actress then....well, I would say that the Academy would lose credibility but they already did by not giving an oscar to Leonardo DiCaprio *cough* and for not giving Best Score to John Williams for "Raiders of the Lost Ark." Anyways, whatever faults I found with the film--I'm not even going to bring them up--because they're so miniscule that to do so would just undermine the sheer emotion that the film handles so well. Some of those scenes hit heavy, which only allows Jacob Tremblay's performance to shine through even more. There was one scene where two characters were having an argument and I felt that it could have been written better. The next scene--something happens, no spoilers--and a character yells "call 911," that one phrase was said with such conviction and urgency that for a second, I thought it was real. I actually forgot I was watching a movie. "Room" deals with some some serious drama with right amount of subtlety and pure power. It's a film that I can easily recommend but, at the same time, I know that it won't be a viewing experience that one can just sit back and enjoy (there's a lot to admire and respect, though). Good night, folks.
Terrific movie. The run time was only a tad long for my taste but great nonetheless.

I can't remember the last time I saw that film that made me feel as much or in quite the same way as Room. While the film's premise might sound like it belongs to some god-awful and woefully inelegant made-for-TV movie, this adaptation of Emma Donoghue's 2010 novel is an intimate and emotionally intelligent film that most definitely belongs on the big screen. Directed by Lenny Abrahamson (Frank), the film is as horrifying as it is hopeful, and it is as beautiful as it is devastating. As dark as it often is, Room is just as inspiring as it is tragic, and its combination of tender storytelling and stirring performances makes for an undeniably affecting viewing experience.

Room is one of the most powerful movies I've seen in years. Days later, this movie has stayed with me. It is a story about a mother and her son and their unbreakable bond, but also about what freedom is and what it means. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are fantastic. Best movie of 2015

While the performance by Brie Larson was solid (albeit, not her best by any stretch), this film irked me in a lot of ways. Although it was well written, the boy was a terrible character to focus the story through. I am sure that is why so many people liked the film and book, but I was so much more interested in her story. If they had set up the transition from her story to his story, I would have been okay, considering when you are a parent it is a major life shift from yourself to your kids. But the movie did not do that. I did not care one bit about the boy and because of the lack of depth in her story, I barely cared about the mom. The score did not add a lot to the movie, which is a major flaw.

An engaging, generally suspenseful psychological thriller about the bond between mother and child and the lengths she'll go to in protecting him under trying circumstances. The film's outstanding lead performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay captivate throughout, despite some occasionally uneven pacing (especially in the second hour). As one of the more unusual releases in recent years, this offering won't appeal to everyone, but, for those who appreciate cinematic experiences outside the mainstream, this is one worth screening.

I want to start off by saying I recommend you do not watch the trailer for this film. If you do watch the trailer that's fine, but if you wish to avoid knowing what the "second half" of this film is like then you should avoid it.

That being said, in order to avoid commenting on the second half I am referring to, I'll try to talk about issues explored in the film rather than plot content.
The basic premise is that a woman and her son live in a shed, which they refer to as simply "Room," years after the woman's abduction by an older man. Their names are Joy and Jack, and they are very codependent.

What I did not expect from this film is that it deals with the theme of perception of reality, and how much the environment has an impact on this perception. Jack has only lived in Room his whole life and knows nothing outside of this life. To maintain his innocence, Joy has had to tell stories to build a certain perspective on reality for her son. One of the best scenes of the film is when Joy decides it is better for Jack to know the truth about the world and reality, and Jack's reaction is heartbreaking and played brilliantly by Jacob Tremblay.

I want to say more, but I feel like I would give too much away if I did. In a nutshell, this film deals with issues I never would have imagined to be tackled in a film with this premise. I recommend you see this film unless you find the premise disturbing, though the film is never violent or graphic.
3.5/4.0

An unforgettable film that is so reminiscent of the actual kidnapping of Amanda Berry and her six year old daughter that it seems unbelievable that the fictional book, Room was published months before Michelle Knight, Gina DeJesus, Amanda Berry and her six year old daughter was rescued on May 6, 2013 - just before their horrific story became known.   
	It would take a heart of stone not to shed tears during this movie.  Actress Brie Larson does an amazing job portraying a kidnapped victim who is abducted as a young teenager and made to live in an outbuilding in her captor's backyard.  While held captive, she has a child named Jack.  The two are never allowed to leave the "Room."   The five year old boy is played brilliantly by Jacob Tremblay who deserved an Oscar for his convincing performance.  Jack captures the thoughts and emotions that a young boy must feel when his whole world during the first five years of his life is confined between four walls with only a young mother's love to guide and protect him.  Ma, Jack's mother, captures the boundless love of a young mother who is forced to raise a child alone under horrid conditions.  
	The story is one that seems to touch every emotion one can feel and makes you feel each one with painful honesty and intensity.  It is not an enjoyable experience, but one you will be glad that you experienced.
Out of horrific circumstances, what utter beauty, innocence and humanity. A lesson on perspective and a Mother's pure love for her son. Fantastic!

My mom always forced us to watch movies about motherhood. She did it at least once a week. It was ironic because she would sit there, gushing about how it was so true, that mother hood was such a blessing and the most wonderful thing a woman can do, and then right after she would be back to being her abusive self. 

My mom would hate this movie. 

Not that Joy is an abusive mom in anyway. Quite the opposite. She did everything right, but this movie is extremely real in it's portrayal of such an overwhelming situation. I think this is one of the most honest looks at motherhood I have ever seen. She gets annoyed. She gets tired. She has days when she just needs to be away from him for a little bit. She gets a bit scary at times. She feels inadequate. 
But she loves Jack. She wants to be everything he see's in her through his tiny 5 year old eyes. 

I think this is a near perfect movie. My only real nitpick is that I feel like it couldn't chose a POV. Did it want to be from Joy's POV or from Jack's. But it is a very small nitpick as the movie shows us everything we need to see and nothing more.

A seemingly meek & small film that is bigger and stronger than any I have ever seen. An Oscar-worthy performance by Brie Larson. Jacob Tremblay is marvelous. Abrahamson shines in his direction. An incredibly effecting masterpiece & my favorite film of 2015.

This is one of those films where you will find yourself laughing, crying, scared, nervous, joyous, and wholly engaged in the film. Room to me felt a bit too long but overall a very well made film.

Heartbreaking, heartwarming and heart-stopping, it's one of the best movies of the decade. Room is a sensitive and even uplifting but very realistic psychological drama about abuse, depression, courage, and a lot more, even if the story of its inciting situation is terrifying, especially for women.

Room, a low-budget Canadian-Irish film which won the People's Award at the Toronto International Film Festival, and whose female star is already the bookies' favorite to win the Best Actress Oscar, opens on Ma (Brie Larson) a young mother and her long-haired child living in a small room with a TV and a skylight. They're extremely close. The child is actually a boy. Jack (Jacob Tremblay) is so attached to "room" he addresses pieces of furniture in the second person.  On Jack's fifth birthday Ma decides Jack needs to know there's far more to the only world he's ever known: the inside of a shed. They're captives of Old Nick (Sean Bridgers).  Ma concocts a ruse allowing Jack to escape, whereupon the film's focus shifts to "How will the boy adjust?"  But Jack adapts quickly. It's Ma who has problems: grappling with baggage from her pre-captive life.

An unpleasant movie-going experience, but that's the point. It's hard to say "enjoyable", but it's definitely something you won't forget. A good movie with Oscar worthy performances, but also very difficult film to watch (and stomach) at times.

Does it always go without saying that the book was better?  The movie was good and maintained a lot of the narrative and plotting.  There were a few key points that I thought got missed and the character development suffered a little because you don't get to "hear" their inner voices as much as you do in the book.  You hear Jacks thoughts but not his Moms but Brie Larson does a pretty excellent job of expressing her struggles with depression and parenting I. A world that she isn't quite prepared for.  Worth the watch.
An unforgettable movie that will haunt you long after you leave the theater.

This is the fifth movie that I have watched in the festival. I have been a fan of Brie Larson since Short Term 12 and I was excited to watch this movie just for her.

This movie was intense. Its hard to imagine being locked in a room for many years and trying every day to make everything seem like it's perfect, especially when you have a child. Watching this film just made me think about all those women who have been kidnapped and impregnated by men with no way of escape expected through their own child. You can tell that their children give them the strength for hope. Hope that they will be rescued one day and are able to see their loved ones. I was surprised to see the aftermath of them being rescued. It was interesting because the whole time, we felt as if we were them, either the mother or the child because we don't get to see the outside world until they do.

I can't imagine what it must be like to be a child that hasn't seen the outdoors and hasn't been in contact with anyone apart from your mother. Brie Larson does a terrific job as always and I hope that she gets an Oscar for ether this or any movies she has out in the future which are drama. She is an underrated actor. The little boy in this movie was fantastic. He will definitely get a young Hollywood award.

In the end, I was glad that I did everything in my power to be able to see this because it is a must see.

P.S. If you've never watch Short Term 12, what are you waiting. Get it on DVD, Blu Ray or digital format and watch it now. It's incredible.

An intimate and powerful story about surviving and escaping the trauma of an unimaginable situation, Room is assured to rank as one of the year's most overwhelmingly moving films. Lenny Abrahamson's skilled, deftly-handled direction is matched by its raw, heart-wrenching performances: a star-making turn from Brie Larson and young Jacob Tremblay, who gives one of the most astoundingly strong performances from a child actor in recent memory.

As we get closer to the annual Academy Award and Golden Globe award nominations, "Room" is one powerful film to keep a close eye on. A fascinating drama about a teenage girl abducted and held captive with her son, this movie combines daunting societal isolation with the need for long-term coping mechanisms. The young mother, Joy "Ma" Newsome, raises her 5-year old son Jack in captivity until the time comes to try an escape attempt.

With an extraordinary cast and riveting storyline, "Room" is one of this year's best films. Brie Larson, as Ma, achieves her most profound film endeavor to date-easily the best female lead performance so far in 2015. Additionally, there's no drop-off in talent from the supporting cast members.

Matching Larson's exceptional effort is the work of costar, Jacob Tremblay, who magnificently portrays her 5-year old son, Jack. Look for "Room" to be both Larson's and Tremblay's career ground-breaking moment. Supporting firepower is provided by Academy Award nominees Joan Allen and William H. Macy--both playing Jack's grandparents.

This is a chilling tale because it takes moviegoers behind shocking newspaper headlines. What starts off as a mother and son survival drama methodically transitions into a story of a daughter and grandson attempting to reintegrate into society. Tremblay's impressive depiction of Jack's overstimulation to his surroundings packs an emotional punch.

However, it's Larson's astonishing and heartfelt role that carries this top-shelf film. Larson's amazing transformation from adolescent teen daughter to hostage, and then from young mother to survivor. With stellar acting from both Larson and Tremblay in particular, "Room" captivates and grips the audience. Furthermore, it should also net the pair--and this film--numerous award nominations in the coming months.

Grade: A

Based upon the international best-selling novel "Room" by Emma Donoghue, Ma and Jack must coexist in the only world the young boy knows; a 10-foot by 10-foot windowless shed containing a modest bed, toilet, bathtub and small kitchen under an overhead skylight.

"Room" is an engrossing film that gets stronger and more compelling with each passing minute. Viewers are given a look inside the appalling and cruel circumstances not reported in our 24-hour news cycles. Beyond the shocking living conditions, we find a physically abusive relationship between Ma and her captor--nicknamed Old Nick. Deprived of all but their most basic human needs, Old Nick can't strip away the pair's imagination and hope.

If this movie doesn't move you to think about and appreciate the human experience, you  have no soul.  I kept thinking back to "Life is Beautiful" all throughout the movie and found myself almost in tears, not just for Ma and Jack, but in thinking about my own life and blessings.  What a fantastic film.
Sad, yet hopeful. An immensely satisfying experience even if the ending struggles to be upbeat and in so doing veers dangerously close to sentimentality.

good movie, interesting story, some very intense and emotional scenes. it could have been shorter and was somewhat anticlimactic. great acting across the board. unique and noticeable directing. (1 viewing)

This original story, told from the seemingly narrow, but truthfully abundant and vibrant world of a captive 5 year old, is so intricately woven together with love, and consciousness and motherly protection it is alarming to see the 2nd half of the movie unravel as much as the characters do, during what seems would have been the joyful release of freedom and magical awareness, we struggle to find as much connection and interest as was revealed initially from "room".  It's not so much a disappointment as a draining and sad realization of expectations not living up to reality.
