This knockout of a drama-thriller broke my heart and made me emotional in a way that only a very few films have done in my life. It is one of those rare situations where words simply cannot describe the power and profound messages of the film, and it is best for the audience to experience it. It is an extraordinary piece of filmmaking full of raw emotion and gut-wrenching moments; it is a film that understands the complexities of child psychology, and presents the maternal bond and unconditional love that a mother holds toward her child. Every shot and every second of "Room" is harrowing and intense and compelling and unforgettable and heartbreaking, and through Lenny Abrahamson's sure-handed direction and the two powerhouse performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, it tells an incredibly moving story that will leave you with bruises. "Room" is by far the best movie I've seen all year: An instant classic and one of a kind masterpiece about love, courage, and perseverance.
Saw at the Telluride Film Festival. The best film at the festival, and Brie Larson should win best actress.

+
Joy (Brie Larson) was kidnapped at the age of 17 and 2 years later gave birth to her son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) by her kidnapper Big Nick (Sean Bridgers) where we meet them as Jack celebrates his 5th birthday in the 10 X 10 room, a shed, the only place he has ever known, never going outside. What he knows of the world outside of the shed he has seen on the small TV set they have or been told to him by his mother.

The shed has a small sink, 2 chairs, a tub, a bed, a small table, a toaster oven and a closet where Jacob is put in by his mother every time Big Nick comes to rape her. The room is decorated with drawings by the boy and his imagination sees all the things as his friends and the world visible from the very small, very high skylight unimaginable though his mother teaches him to read and explains all the things he sees on the TV as being real.

We spend the first 50 minutes with mother and son, with short visits by their kidnapper to abuse her, in what could be a claustrophobic segment but we watch the mother use discipline with her son making him exercise, learn to read, follow oral hygiene, break eggs, learn how to cook and use his imagination. Without telling too much one of the most touching scenes for many reasons is when the pair make a cake for his 5th birthday.

The second half of the film deals with their escape--leave logic at the door as it is the only misfire by director Lenny Abrahamson--and what happens to the mother and son coming into the real world.

Based on her book and writing the screenplay Emma Donoghue does a good job holding our interest in both segments but I wish there had been about 5-15 minutes more regarding the relation between Joy, her mother (Joan Allen), her father (Willaim H. Macy) now divorced, and their reaction to getting their daughter back 7 years after she was kidnapped.

Allen does a excellent job, Macy is wasted in no more than a cameo though his reaction is important to his daughter's freedom. Bridgers, looking like your next door neighbor, is menacing in his lack of looking menacing while  Tom McCamus, as the new man in Allen's and now also in the Joy and Jacob's lives is underplayed.

Brie Larson is strong, weak, protective, questioning, as the mother who wonders whether she could have done better by her son after doing all she could while they were prisoners.

Jacob Tremblay is a revelation as 5 year old Jack whether it be using his imagination about the outside world or when he gets there dealing with it. There were a few times he was incomprehensible on the soundtrack where he does some key narration but just by looks and action he carries the scenes whether alone or dealing with the adults.

This sounds like it may be a depressing film and the theme certainly isn't a light one but Jacob Tremblay, at 9 years old, lifts the film up with his acting, his open face and looking at the world with wonder, showing that children can handle life better than most adults.

This movie was just as engrossing as the book - intensely sad, surreal, and yet hopeful and promising all at the same time. Amazing perspective on child development and how normal growth and learning can persevere in the most horrific and restrictive of situations. Excellent acting by both "Ma" and "Jack."
The biggest snubs of the Oscars are, Best Leading Actor for Jacob Tremblay and Best Cinematography. This film did something that no other film has ever done for me, it made me cry with happiness.

"Room" is by all accounts a great movie. The acting is some of the best I've seen all year, the story is compelling, the characters interesting and as you follow their plight it's impossible not to get emotionally invested. I urge you to go see it. With that said, I feel like something was lost in translation. Between this film and the novel by Emma Donoghue (who wrote the screenplay, making me ask once again "What do I know?") something doesn't sit right with me. Curious? Let's dig in!

Joy (Brie Larson) and her five-year-old son Jack (Jacob Tremblay) live in "Room", a space no bigger than a tool shed outfitted with a bed, a television and some living essentials. Its all Jack has ever known. Soon after his fifth birthday Joy informs her son of the truth: there's more to the world than just "Room". The man who supplies them with food and clothing (Sean Bridgers) kidnapped Joy when she was 17 and there's a whole world waiting for them, if they can escape.

If you have seen trailers for this film, you know well ahead what happens in the second half. If you don't I wouldn't say that knowing this gives away so much away that you won't be able to "Room", but go in as cold as possible. If you're already in the know rest assured. The extra information did not diminish my enjoyment of "Room". It's pretty much impossible not to get involved with what's developing on-screen. Your heart breaks at the very thought of a human being held captive and of another never seeing the outside world. When there is a possibility of escape, no matter how small the odds are you scoot to the edge of your seat because if these two innocents can't be freed, then there's no hope in the world. 

This story follows two people being forced against their will to live out a life they have not chosen and making the best of it and about seeing this nightmare through a lens of innocence. If you put two and two together you will quickly realize that there are some pretty unsettling things happening here (we don't actually see Joy get raped, but happening regularly without a doubt). You're getting worried, but hold on. This is not what I would call a depressing movie. Seeing the characters move through this story and getting to know them is a rewarding experience. It's like volunteering at a homeless shelter. You might not be around beauty and the situation is sad, but there's something about being there, holding the hand of someone who is at rock bottom that enriches you. This is particularly true with this Lenny Abrahamson picture because the characters are drawn in such a realistic fashion. Jack is not just a precautious innocent who always behaves and sits idly by while the world moves around. 5 year olds can be sweet. They can also be frustrating and impatient. The key is that when they're being funny or asking an innocuous question they melt your heart and you fall head over heels in love. Joy is no a saint either, despite the fact that she's undeniably a victim and a strong person for holding onto shreds of hope.

There is still hope within Jack and when I saw the bond between him and his mother it more than made up for the discomfort that I felt thinking about everything that this scenario entailed. I could never quite get over it completely, and I don't think you`re supposed to, but by the end of the film I think you'll manage to emerge unscathed. Witnessing the character of Jack really begin to evolve and grow despite everything he's missed out on ignites your own healing process. If anything, it'll inspire you to think of children and of the resiliency of the human spirit in a whole new way.

I do have a criticism which I feel needs to be addressed. Ultimately this movie is about self-discovery and exploration. I don't think it pulls it off 100%. I compare the film to a book that I have not read, but I get the feeling that when you find yourself in Jack's for world the first time, you're not supposed to fully grasp what's happening. Is it a science fiction/fantasy story where the whole world really IS just this tiny? In live action, the illusion is never there. As a person living in the real world, you can immediately tell that there is something wrong. The film is essentially told from Jack's point of view but I never felt like I could truly immerse myself and understand how he thought. Similarly, I think there are missed opportunities with the unique aspects that film can bring to a story. It's not a great example, but I think of Dorothy in "The Wizard of Oz", where the use of actors, music and color made it clear that she is in a new world with new rules. It sucked you into this new place to help you understand how different a life it would be. A life lived in a single room could have been conveyed better.

I do not think that most people will feel the same way I did about the "film" aspect of "Room". Even if you do, there's no denying that it is an emotionally successful and touching account that sucks you in right from the beginning, contains real tension without resorting to any cheap tricks and works as a profound examination of two human beings. Then you've got the performances. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay alone should be enough to compel you to get off your butt and see "Room" the performances are on a higher echelon than in most films. For those reasons and more, I'm certain that this is not the last time you will hear of "Room". (Theatrical version on the big screen, November 10, 2015)

Room is an emotional roller coaster of a film but a really good one. Room is the story of a woman who was kidnapped and had a child by her kidnapper. She has been locked up for 7 years. The room is about 20x20 and very meager. She has raised a well-mannered, smart boy who is now 5. Her captor comes in every night to have sex with her. She places Jack in the closet while her captor is there. They have survived on little food and almost no sunlight. She tells Jack stories to keep him entertained. One day, she comes up with a plan that gets Jack out and eventually leads police to the shed where she has lived for 7 years. The second part of the film is them learning to live again. Such a moving, disturbing film, but so good.

Having read the book, I was more than excited to see its adaptation to the big screen. I could not be happier with the way it came out. Directed by Lenny Abrahamson, for me a newly found director, Room is the story of a women (Brie Larson) who has been held captive in a shed for seven years with her five year old son, Jack (Jacob Tremlay), who was born in that shed. Jack knows nothing of the outside world and as a result, his mother tries to shield him from everything he might not ever experience, and creates a world for him within Room.

The first half of the movie focuses on this aspect. It is absolutely incredible how Abrahamson is able to portray so much in such a little space. Because of this, there are numerous elements in the background and setting that give you clues about the type of life this boy and his mother have, immersing the viewer deeply into the relationship.

The second half of the movie focuses on the reality of adjusting to the outside world after escaping and less on their relationship. It is not as strong as the first half of the movie, however, thanks to the brilliant work from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremlay, Room still manages to engage the viewer in an unforgettable manner.

Overall, Brie Larson and Jacob Tremlay manage to draw you into their own little world, from both perspectives, the mother and the five year old. Their reality becomes yours and the small things in life don't seem as small anymore. With amazing direction, beautiful cinematography and set design, and breath taking acting, Room's originality succeeds in every aspect.
Room was beautiful yet heartbreakingly dark.  The emotion in this film is so strong and deep. I cried many times throughout. Jacob Tremblay was fantastic as well as Brie Larson. Go and see this film!

Based on the best-selling book of the same title, by Emma Donoghue, "Room" tells the harrowing tale of one woman's survival through abduction, imprisonment, rape, motherhood and post-traumatic stress. Sound grim? Well, it is, but it is also beautifully life-affirming. As played by the marvelous young actress Brie Larson ("Short Term 12"), Ma - the only name by which we know her, spoken by her 5-year-old son, Jack - is a model of strength and resilience, though prone to occasional (and very understandable) fits of despair. Her universe is limited to a single room, which she shares with Jack - played by the extremely talented (and relative newcomer) Jacob Tremblay - through whose point of view the book is told, a device mostly replicated in the film (for which Donoghue also wrote the script). The first images we see are from Jack's perspective: abstract close-ups of furniture and other objects in the tiny space, which slowly morph into shots of Ma. This is the only world that Jack has ever known, and curious sort that he is, he makes the most of it with his imagination. Mother and son have a deeply intimate bond, soon to be tested. We sense, from the opening, that we are in for a riveting and overwhelming experience, a promise to which Room more than lives up.

The director, Lenny Abrahamson, last made a movie about a man trapped by his own psychoses, "Frank." There, the self-imposed prison was a papier-mâché head, inside of which actor Michael Fassbender spent most of the movie. Here, the jail may offer more room to maneuver, but it's far more solid. What are the effects of a seven-year kidnapping? How does one cope without hope? Jack, an originally unwanted product of violent sexual assault, is now far less albatross than life preserver. With him, Ma's life has structure and meaning. Without him, she might possibly have long ago surrendered to defeat. In this way, Donoghue weaves a complex tale where good can come from bad, and bad from good. If it comes, the long hoped-for liberation may joyfully unlock one set of doors, only to lead Ma and Jack into a new form of captivity.

I haven't read the book, so a great surprise for me was how the film doesn't end where you'd expect it to. In fact, what starts out feeling like the third act turns out to be but an extension of the central conflict. It's a tribute to both author and director that they never allow their story a pure happy end. That would be disrespectful to the experience. True, most wounds heal over time, but some leave deep scars. Both Ma and Jack will forever be marked by their years in "room" (that's how they refer to their space), no matter what good comes later. The film does leave us with a strong sense of mother-child love, which overrides most of the horrors. And thanks to the exceptional performances from Larson and Tremblay - and other members of a fine ensemble cast that includes Joan Allen ("Georgia O'Keeffe") and William H. Macy ("The Sessions") - the bond between Ma and Jack is a beautiful salve that can, at least, heal the wounds we suffer while watching their plight.
If this movie doesn't break your heart by the end of it, then you're guaranteed to be a sociopath.

Room is fine movie for reasons that have been adequately discussed. What's disappointing about it, however, is that I don't think it succeeds in suggesting a broader meaning to the highly unusual story it recounts, which seems to be drawn from real life. It's not enough to make us feel sorry for the victims of bizarrely horrible circumstances: a narrative has to make us feel that these experiences relate to us as well. Also, I don't see the point of keeping us in the dark for so long about why the mother and child are in the room. There are times when mystery is pointless.

Most of the film is a two person show between Brie Larson and child actor Jacob Tremblay. Both of them give absolutely amazing performances. Tremblay is perfect. Every reaction is spot on, every behavior, every spat with his mother... it's just perfect. Never overdone, never annoying. Kudos to him. 

If Larson hit a home run with Short Term 12, she hit a Grand Slam with this one. She's vulnerable, in one of the most extreme positions of weakness imaginable (she's been locked in a garden shed for 7 years. Tremblay is 5. You do the math), yet the love and warmth she brings to her relationship with Tremblay are just too powerful to ignore. This is just a fantastic performance from Larson. 

If the film has any flaws, it's that it plays its high cards way too soon. The film is neatly cut in two halves, the first half showing Larson and Tremblay's imprisonment and the second showing their difficulty in returning to normalcy, particularly for Tremblay. Poor kid has never known any life other than that garden shed. Unfortunately, the second half isn't as powerful as the first. The rescue of Larson and Tremblay plays like it's the climax of the film, so when it happens, we as the audience are ready at the point to go "They're safe. Movie over". Yes, we want to know Larson and Tremblay are going to be okay, but couldn't we just have someone like a doctor or one of Larson's parents say there's going to be an awkward transition period?

Even though the second half isn't as great as the first, that does not diminish Larson or Tremblay. Their chemistry and their performances are fantastic and worth the price of admission. No Tommy Wiseau in this one, sadly.

Stunning and Heartbreaking. Give Brie Larson and this kid Jacob Tremblay the oscar know. Both give the best performances of the year. Room is a tough watch, but at the end it was an emotional and rewarding experience. See Room the second you can!!!!

Room

A five year-old boy and his mother must adapt to normal life after escaping a "room" in which they've been held captive his entire life. 

Had a good cry lately? This emotional juggernaut has two main components: before and after the main characters' liberation. And while the escape sequence is a white-knuckler, it's the two parts' duality acting that drives this film to greatness. Brie Larson gives her finest as the mother but it's the performance of young Jacob Tremblay, who plays the son, that will linger long after the projector stops. 

One of my favorite films of the year. 

Grade:  A+

Big Al says see Room in the theatre.

In what can only be described as one of the best movies I have ever seen, based on the book by Emma Donoghue, Room is a highly emotional tale about a mother, who having been kidnapped 7 years earlier, finally finds a way to escape 'Room', and give her son a life in a world he had never known had even even existed. 

This hard-hitting, dramatic tear jerker is told through  the eyes of 5-year old Jack (Jacob Tremblay), the son of kidnapper and rapist 'old man Nick' who abducted, raped and locked away his Ma (Brie Larson) in what they call 'Room', a shed in the Old Man Nick's garden.

After concocting and rehearsing their plan, 5-year old Jack manages to escape and relay a brief and sparse description of where he and his had been held. The highly astute police officer manages to narrow the location down and successfully finds his mum, Joy Newsome.

This extraordinary story is a tale about discovery and freedom, a luxury Jack has never known. We see how he discovers the outside world in ways he could never have imagined, as he relishes in the adventure and the excitement we see how he and his Ma adapt back into society and into a life a life that had so far only been a figment of his imagination.
A good Canadian movie for sure ... Well done ...

"Flashbacks and dream sequences are traded for raw, uninterrupted life in the room that boldly encapsulates 94 of the film's 188-minute runtime. The shed's cold interior is wearied on the eyes, Jack and Joy's various crafts applying faint signs of life, and as we are left to witness a darkly beautiful incubated snapshot of a mother-son relationship; the anger, the amendments, the curiosity, the tears, the laughs. And surrounding it all are four unforgiving walls, which, once knocked down, the simplest joys of a boy and a dog, bedrooms, family dinners make for some of the most uniquely liberating cinematic moments of recent memory."

Simple yet profound, small yet grande, "Room" is one of the most complex and thought-provoking films I have seen in a very long time. Maybe not complex to everyone, if you look at the imagery, camerawork, and script choices, there really is something incredible here. After being raised in a room for five years, with no outdoor contact, Jack and his Ma Joy escape and see daylight for the first in a long time. Told through the perspective of the child, he is seeing the world, people, objects, and nature, all for the first time. The emotional impact that has on the story is breathtaking. Brie Larson gives a gut-wrenching performance and I believed every single scene she was in. Starting from a confined room, you really begin to see what the world is truly like and how we take everything for granted that is in it. I loved "Room" from start to finish. Although I believe this is a brilliant film overall, I have to complain about the way they were able to escape. It felt a little too easy and then that tension was gone throughout the rest of the film in order to focus on the emotional heft, i.e. the family. In the end, "Room" has a very raw and true screenplay, incredible performances, inspiring visuals, and a story that is once in a generation, and we do not get many of those. I wish it did not have an easy way out in the opening act, but overall, I feel I can still give it a perfect score. See this film!

Do you want to watch a movie that will leave you speechless for a good amount of hours? How about a movie that youâ??ll probably never forget due to its poignant, painful story and heartbreaking performances? Room is that movie. Directed by Lenny Abrahamson and written by Emma Donoghue, based on her novel of the same name, Room follows the story of Jack and his mother, whose whole world resides in the inside of a shed; a soundproof, locked shed in the backyard of a creep who has held them captive for years. However, the instinct of survival, and the hope that there is something or some place better on the other side of the wall, is not something that you can lock up by walls, nor shush with sound-proof foams, and it can make a difference.

First and foremost, I would like to start off by praising the PHENOMENAL performances in Room. It is unfathomable that the performances in this film are in fact performances. The emotional strength in them is mostly what makes this film strike us, and let me tell you, it will hit you hard. Brie Larson delivers a courageous and heartbreaking performance as Jackâ??s mom. Torn apart by the traumatic events that found their way into her life, but simultaneously trying to keep her composure to make sure her son is safe, Larson gives her character so much spirit and resilience. Honestly, I canâ??t find an adjective that does justice to the power of Brie Larsonâ??s performance. Definitely one of the best performances Iâ??ve seen this year.

Same goes for Jacob Tremblay, who is just nothing short of sensational. I mean, his performance is probably the best performance Iâ??ve seen from a child actor ever, on par with Anna Paquin in The Piano (1993) and Haley Joel Osment in The Sixth Sense (1999). He superbly portrayed a boy whose world shifted from being confined to the walls of a shed, to the infinity of the world, showing at the same time the inherent, cross-generational desire of human survival. His performance is strong, naive, and smart, but also fearless. He embodied a boy who does not yet comprehend the things that happened to him; being in such an early stage of development does not allow him to make sense of the circumstances he is in. Tremblay portrays that inability to fathom what was happening perfectly. Both Larson and Tremblay SHOULD get nominated for an Academy Award. It would be an understatement to say that I will be very pissed if either of them donâ??t get the nomination.

In terms of Roomâ??s style, its cinematography is beautiful and amazing; it immerses the audience into Jackâ??s claustrophobic and subjective little world, which makes the movie almost like a full sensory experience; a textured experience where we would feel everything that Jack felt, whether it be despair, happiness, and fear or the texture of the rug in Room. The score by Stephen Rennicks is quite compelling as well, which was a beautiful complement to this moving story. Also, the production design is horrifyingly great given the circumstances of the story. That shed would definitely be in every personâ??s nightmare about being held captive by a creep.

Room is the most powerful film Iâ??ve seen this year, hands down. It showcases not only the problem of people being held hostage and deprived from their freedom, but also the psychological effects that that ignites in social, familial and interpersonal relationships.  Now I feel really stupid about caring a lot about Matt Damonâ??s character in The Martian. If you cared about him getting out of Mars and surviving, wait until you see Room. Then you will see what caring for a characterâ??s survival intrinsically really feels like (I still love The Martian, it was just the most recent example I could think of). Honestly, this could be my favorite film of the year. Embark on this emotional and heartbreaking journey and see for yourself the power of a great story.

I enjoyed this film. It is very much a dramatic thriller that explores some dark morose subject matter. Yet the film's main character "Jack" reflects child like eyes and wonderment that gives the entire film, the bright light that only the purity of a child's soul can illuminate in the darkness. 'Room' is an emotional experience like no other in movies! This is not for the weak of heart for the opening hour is very strong! For the patient viewer, 'Room', is extremely rewarding. Brie Larson's is one of the strongest performances of this or any other year, raw, brave, touching. Jacob Tremblay's performance is astonishing! The best child performance I have ever seen, mature beyond his years and remarkably brave and strong! Lenny Abrahamson has made a powerful, beautiful, gut wrenching but life affirming movie about the strong bond between mother and son, even in extreme pain, hardship and heartbreak! There is not one false shot, word or moment! This is one of the most beautiful movies I have seen and two of the best performances I have ever experienced! There will not be a movie better than 'Room' this year! The best movie of the decade so far and sure to make my top 100 movies of all time list!

Room is a film that gets it. Telling the story of a young woman's abduction and abuse from the perspective of her son means the story can be told without exploitation. The moment that Jack first views the world is one of the most expansive and freeing in cinema thanks to the wonderful direction of Penny Abrahamson. Brie Larson is well deserving of all the praise she has gotten from the role and I just hope it doesn't ruin her career like similar breaks have for other actresses. Jacob Tremblay handles a difficult part with intellegence beyond his years. All together, Room is one of the best films to deal with the abduction and captivity of women (there are more than you think) and one of the best films of the year.

A thrilling, heart breaking, and ultimately life affirming film, that calls out as awards season's most selfless entree. Adapted from Emma Donoghue's novel (who also supplied the screenplay), Room tells a shocking story, but with a respectful amount of restraint. While necessarily tense throughout, Room finds levity in its central theme regarding a mother-and-child's bonding. Brie Larson gives another seamless performance (she may very well be the best duogenarian actress working in Hollywood), and the 9-year old Jacob Tremblay should be very proud of how powerful his delivery is, as the story is touchingly told through his young character's perspective. If there's one disappointment to Room, it's that the second half doesn't quite measure up to the first. The film's first 40 minutes are the most mesmerizing in terms of cinematography and narrative, before it adopts a more conventional yet still compelling approach. Regardless, Room is a must-see if ever there was one, and a very welcome change of pace for director Lenny Abrahamson, after last year's Frank.

A movie of this subject matter and with this level of apparent truth is very difficult to judge. This was a horrible thing to have happened and it's virtually impossible to imagine oneself in that scenario. And as a film, this is the first of it's kind. I'm not sure that many movie makers would have the confidence/courage to take on this type of challenge and I really commend those that did. For that reason, I think this movie deserves a positive review. 

What I can't say, though, is that I had an experience similar to that which I gather from other reviews and ratings. The movie had its moments, it really did, and those moments did move me for brief periods of time. Just not in a sustainable way. I couldn't help but leave the theater thinking that there was just something missing. And I can't quite figure out what it is.
Not subtle or sophisticated enough for my taste, "Room" is nevertheless moving and well-acted.
Bring tissues and preferably, a friend.
Roller coaster of emotion. Incredibly smart and insightful. Brie Larson has yet to disappoint me as an actor, Mr. Jacob Tremblay has an bright future. I decide for both of them.
Beautiful story and wonderfully well made.

Room is one of the best movies of 2015. The acting was outstanding especially from Brie Larson and Joan Allen. The tone of the movie, while depressing at times, made for some very emotional moments that will quite possibly have you in tears. I recommend Room to almost anyone who is willing to cry in a movie theater.

Room is one of the greatest movies I've ever seen. There. I said it. That's a big statement but it's true. The movie is heartbreaking but completely uplifting. My eyes were watery the entire time. It's hard to imagine Brie Larson and 9 year old Jacob Tremblay not getting Oscars for their performances. Larson is so convincing you forget she's acting. Tremblay gives one of the best child performances I've ever seen in a film. Unbelievable. SO UNBELIEVABLE!!!

I could rave about this all day. Let's also not forget Joan Allen who's wonderful in a supporting role. The heartbreak of Room comes from the horror of being kidnapped for 7 years and the guilt Larson's character feels for her son being raised as a victim. Then the movie moves you by showing the world through Tremblay's eyes after he and his mother escape their abductor. It's so real. So powerful. This is the best movie of the year.

Room reads almost like a thriller that cares about its main characters; the tone is intense, haunting, and somehow still ultimately loving and beautiful. As a study of its characters, Room is a triumph. Its plot may admittedly suffer from a certain brand of nostalgia in its direction.  Additionally; its dialogue can feel a little convenient at times. As a whole, it is an exceptionally well-crafted, well-acted, and impactful film.

I'm honestly at a loss to describe why I liked this, so I'm just going to keep it simple. Brie Larson is outstanding as the kidnapped mother of young Jack (Jacob Tremblay, also really good), who has raised him to believe the entire world is the room where she's held captive, until she uses him as a means of escape, and then simply how they both react to being in the world -- her coping with changes since she's been gone, and him for the first time. I have a few issues with the story, mainly how we never learn much about the grandmother, her boyfriend, or the severely underutilized William H Macy as the grandfather. However, since it's mostly from Jack's viewpoint those would have been difficult to explore anyway. Definitely worth checking out for the performances alone.
Muy buena se las recomiendo / highly recommended

When I saw Short Term 12, I told everyone to keep an eye out for Brie Larson. After watching ROOM, I will make sure people will know who Brie Larson is. Larson gives the performance of the year as a woman trapped in a windowless room for seven years with her five-year old son. The first act is harrowing and unsettling and you can feel the dread of the two. As good as Larson is, Jacob Tremblay who plays her son gives one of the best performances from a child actor I have seen in a long time. Both should be mentioned come awards season. The movie is about the love of a mother and child and the innocence of that child who has been hidden from the world his entire life. One of the best films of the year. 

Grade: A

STUCK HOME SYNDROME - My Review of ROOM (4 Stars)

Don't let the bright wonderment of the poster fool you, ROOM is one of the most emotionally devastating films of the year, anchored by beyond stellar performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay, a young Canadian actor whose focus and range rivals that of Tatum O'Neal in PAPER MOON.  Prepare to be gutted.  

It's almost impossible to describe this film without spoilers, but I'll do just that.  If you've read Emma Donoghue's novel, of which she adapted for the screen, then you already know the basic premise of a mother (Larson) raising her 5-year-old son, Jack (Tremblay) in a tiny room.  Shielding him from the world for reasons that become clear upon viewing, he doesn't know that any type of life exists beyond his four walls.  Think of this as a much more emotionally vibrant and more honest sister film to LIFE IS BEAUTIFUL, which also explored the lengths a parent will go to in order to protect their child.  

Much of the first half of this film is fraught with unbearable suspense, with the mother doing everything she can to resolve their situation.  Danny King, whose work on LES MISERABLES did not make me a fan, employs a live camera and a lot of shallow focus to put the point of view squarely on the shoulders of our two protagonists.  Yes, it's a claustrophobic experience, but to feel otherwise would be doing the subject matter a disservice.  Director Lenny Abrahamson has made an intimate film about big ideas, and there's very smart economy in its storytelling.  It's overlong by at least 20-30 minutes, however, and with such a generous running time of almost two hours, you would expect a little more to William H. Macy's lightly sketched in, barely there character.   It's not that he's incapable, but he's given way too little to work with here. Not so of Joan Allen, who digs deep with limited screen time as well.  Also tremendously effective in supporting roles are Sean Bridgers, who has a knack for keeping an audience on edge, Wendy Crewson as a journalist who prods just a little bit too much, and Amanda Brugel, as a woman who has to assert herself in order to cut through the muck.  

I could have done without the tin can-style of recording the voiceover, which certainly feels unsettling, but was truly difficult to comprehend at times.  The score by Stephen Rennicks is certainly beautiful and heartfelt, but he could have dialed it back a hair with the final music cue.    There was so much sap in it, I was tempted to call the film MUSHROOM!  Far from it, this is a challenging experience, often seen through tears, and not an easy sit for any parent who worries about their child.  Larson and Tremblay should be firmly in the mix come Awards season.  Larson continually surprises me with her performances.  Looking like Reese Witherspoon's sister, I keep expecting her to act goofy and self-conscious, yet her instincts are so vibrantly attuned to the material, she seems incapable of making a false move.  Whether he has natural abilities or was heavily directed, Tremblay is a highly sympathetic actor whose ability to annoy, infuriate and warm an audience's heart, sometimes within the same scene, is something special to behold.  ROOM is very dark, sad, and sometimes without a shred of hope, yet this tale of a Herculean bond between mother and son is well worth all the sobbing you'll likely find yourself doing afterwards.
So good. Sooooo sad. Acting was on point. Horrific story. Just awful.

"Room" | C+ |  During the first half, Larson and Tremblay's smoldering chemistry is beyond Oscar-worthy.  The atmosphere is breathtaking and the suspense is brilliant.  Things slow the moment the kidnapping sex offender appears on screen.  Then, sadly, the film's momentum comes to a screeching halt at the moment the villain reaches a stop sign (unfortunate irony!) and what should've been the most dramatic cinematic moment of the year, fizzles out.  The movie falls off a cliff. The second half is chemistry-free with poorly written, cartoon character subplots unworthy of a bad Lifetime TV movie.  I pray Larson & Tremblay receive the nominations they deserve, but the writer and director need a remedial course in "Choices Filmmakers Should Avoid At All Costs!"

This film has stayed with me a long time, Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are incredibly in character.  Never  did I see them as actors in their roles.  The story is believable though difficult.  Spoiler alert, it ends well, otherwise I couldn't recommend it.
A must-see for everybody. So so good!!!
Its not the Tommy Wiseau one.

I'm generally skeptical of child actors, but Jacob Tremblay...wow an incredible performance- subtle and refined. Brie Larson's acting is believable without seeming overdone. The movie critically examines the theme of freedom- what is it? at what cost? how does it change you? - ironically, through claustrophobic and rather myopic storytelling.

There are indeed scenes that pack a wallop, but the feelings are earned organically as the chronicle progresses. I was tearing up at various points throughout, almost sobbing at one point because the intensity of what was happening was too much to bear. As the narrative develops there's suspense, excitement, tears and joy. I haven't even revealed a major component of the story. I admire the production's finely crafted restraint and have acted in kind. However know this, happiness and terror exist side by side. Author Emma Donoghue has found a unique way to detail the tender bond between a mother and her son. Room's exploration of love is so heartbreakingly original, it's cathartic.

fastfilmreviews.com

Genuinely one of the most moving films I've seen in recent memory.  A film that proves that there are still original stories to be told. You absolutely have to go and see this at your first opportunity!  It's heavy and harrowing and, ultimately, a deeply affecting emotional experience.  Not a light "popcorn movie" night out. But so worth it.
Special props to the cinematographer who managed to trick the eye and give the illusion of space through the eyes of a child. Breathtaking end.

Could possibly be the most unsettling movie I watched in 2015. "Room" makes you feel all the right emotions at all the right moments, and even keeps its momentum after its major tone shift halfway through.
Hard to describe, amazing film, amazing acting, intriguing.

It was hard for me to imagine how this could live up to the book, but it probably helped that the author wrote the screenplay... and that the acting by the two main leads was excellent.  Still, you should read the book first.

Terrific performances highlight what is a wrenching and very emotional film. The filmmakers do a good job of having the film be almost entirely from the young boys point of view... and that technique makes the film even more suspenseful as we experience things along with him.

Best performance by an actress in 2015.  Brie Larson is a rising star and the best performance from a child in recent memory.  This movie will take you in , shove you into a few places you weren't expecting and hang with you.  There are few better movies made.

An emotional gut punch. Hard to shake after you leave the theater. Definitely deserves all the recognition.
Brie Larson & Jacob Tremblay give some of the best performances of 2015. Full review on DCFilmGirl.com.

I'm a sucker for emotional dramas, and even more so if they deal with difficult and/or sensitive subject matter. ROOM is both of those things and does so in a tasteful fashion. I also haven't been so emotionally invested in a film since probably PRISONERS. The story revolves around and Ma (Brie Larson) and Jack (Jacob Tremblay). Ma (whose real name is Joy) was abducted as a teenager and lives in a garden shed, affectionately (or not so, depending on how you interpret it) referred to as 'Room,' with her now-five-year-old son, Jack. When the opportunity arises, Jack escapes and the real meat of the story begins. First off, I was very impressed with performances in the film. Brie Larson does excellent work, but I was even more surprised by Jacob Tremblay. Even though he's quite young, he was able to convey a dramatic range that, although suiting the role in particular, sometimes isn't achieved by older actors. Playing someone who's spent his entire life in captivity, he portrayed the wide-eyed curiosity required as well as the confusion in someone whose perspective on the world is fundamentally changed. There were a number of intense and/or emotional scenes, and he nailed every single one. I also liked how, even though the story deals with women who have been abducted, there was a bit more going on under the surface. Separating the narrative from the obviously horrible situation in which a woman is raped repeatedly, you can see the film also dealing with the psychological effect when a woman has motherhood thrust upon them, the culture shock when someone who has lived in isolation comes into contact with the "real world," etc. There was a lot going on than a simple escape from captivity, in other words. The only issue I could possibly come up with is that the second half of the film doesn't quite live up to the suspenseful first half. Once mother and son are freed, the narrative drive is somewhat lost, or at least goes into a holding pattern for a while. The difference in pacing is noticeable, although I wasn't terribly bothered by it. And, the film wraps up in a satisfying way anyway. All things considered, ROOM is an extremely compelling story that will have some people reaching for a tissue. It has great performances, cinematography, score, etc., and is certainly one of the best films of 2015.
It's been a while since I've been able to cry. I cried.

Not a dry eye in the crowd for the special preview. Jacob Tremblay's performance is amazing, as is Brie Larson's. It opens with mystery, builds the story, throws in drama, and melts your iciest heart along the way. This is original storytelling as it should be.
Great performances by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay. Wonderful script by  Emma Donoghue and direction by Lenny Abrahamson.

This was absolutely incredible. Before you read on, or read any other reviews, or watch a trailer go see this. Absolutely amazing is all I can say. This story is so riveting. The cinematography was immaculate  The acting, the acting is out of this world! Jacob Trembly has such a bright future, his performance was amazing. All I have to say is this is undoubtably one of the best films of this year, and very well could be the best.

A rare find these days, Room is a film that beautifully captures the wonder & emotions of the central characters, not only with its dialogue and narrative but more importantly the facial expressions and incredible acting of everyone in the film. Do yourself a favor, don't read or listen to any discussion about it..., just go see it as soon as you possibly can. If you were ever a child or if you ever had a mother, this one will tug at heartstrings. I truly hope that it gets recognition come awards season.

insanely powerful movie, make sure you bring some Kleenex with you when you see it, everybody should see this movie, too bad is a very limited release. the performances all across are just ... (no words to describe it)
Damn man. Like In America meets Martha Marcy May Marlene meets Prisoners. Dope.
Just fantastic!  It is hard to imagine seeing a better movie this year - or for several years!!
Such a powerful and beautiful movie.  It is difficult to watch at times, but worth it.  Excellent.  I expect/hope this gets some Oscar nominations.
It was great. Well acted. Tight script.  Suspenseful. well worth seeing
Suspenseful, gut-wrenching, emotionally rich. My favorite film of the year.
exceptional performances and effective direction elevate this film to a top 10 contender for the year.

Oh man. I think Brie Larson may be my frontrunner for Best Actress. It's brilliant actually. Since the movie (and the book that it's based off of) is from the son's point of view, Larson got the chance to just go for it. There was no show boating, Oscar bait acting, she killed it. And actually, I would venture to say that Jacob Tremblay, who plays Jack, was snubbed. He has a very bright career ahead of him. What I will say is, damn, don't watch this if you're having a bad day, because this is heavy. This gives the few moments of lightness more gravity, but still, this is a lot for two hours. What makes it better is that a lot of the truly awful things are implied. A lot of directors nowadays would go for the shock/in your face factor. But Abrahamson instead took the opposite approach, giving us the puzzle pieces and letting our imaginations put them together. (Another advantage of having it from Jack's perspective) Brilliant work all around, and a brilliant movie.
Great adaptation from the book. Yay Canada (and Ireland).  The chemistry between the two leads was amazing.  Such a sad, but amazing story. I am so glad I saw this movie. I highly recommend!!
It's about a son and his mother in a small room. That's all you should know before seeing it.
Jacob Tremblay has my heart, Brie Larson has my perpetuous admiration and 	Lenny Abrahamson can expect me to see all hist adaptations from now on.
Very good story and great performances.

A quietly beautiful film. Wonderful work from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay whom the film relied upon. They had a beautiful connection and made their mother/son relationship in a horrid and unique situation seem normal. The film felt incredibly authentic; in particular the fight scene between Brie Larson and Joan Allen felt so real and was so powerful because of it.

Brie Larson is starting to make herself into one of the finest actors working right now and with Room it seems as if she's made perhaps her biggest statement, even more so than her outstanding work in Short Term 12. Larson her isn't so much in top form as she is at her most vulnerable, emotionally wracking, and jaw-droppingly good as she'll ever be, a performance that rocks the year so far for being one of the best acting performances we'll see all of 2015. It's the kind of role you lose yourself in, scene after scene of heartbreak and difficulty. Her role of Joy is one of the most emotionally demanding roles one could ask for and Larson delivers with astounding results. While her performance is part of what makes the film, the film itself doesn't suffer from relying on a single aspect, but is a richly emotional journey about a subject not always explored in film. Jacob Trembly is also particularly good as her son Jack, raised in the most unusual and disturbing of circumstances, a performance that was either made by the actor, the director, or the editor, it doesn't matter as it's incredibly convincing, the perfect balance to Larson's Ma/Joy that creates an unbreakable mother/son dynamic. The script, surprisingly written by the author who shows a surprising amount of screenwriting intelligence, has made a wholly convincing script grounded in reality and humanity along with a director with an eye for realism while remaining in the art of filmmaking. Room is a great film, maybe one of the best so far this year, a richly emotional film of sorrow and heart in the end. Someone may find it hard to watch, but it's also impossible to wrench your eyes away
Tour de force for Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay (he's only 9). Such an intense, dark, but beautiful film
A dark grim yet enthralling story. Very emotional, well acted, and a movie that will stick with you for a while. Not always easy to watch. The story sucked me right in.
Very moving and emotional. A must see!
Don't go see this without making sure all of your therapy bills are paid up. It's intense, realistic and frightening.

Belíssimo filme, ótimo roteiro e ótimas atuações. O direitor fez uma escolha sóbria, sem melodrama ou apelos fáceis de qualquer tipo. 
É uma história que se sustenta pela consistência do roteiro e pelas interpretações.

Simultaneously one of the scariest, most moving, realistic, intriguing, and thought-provoking movies I've ever seen. No qualifiers, this isn't one of the best dramas I've ever seen, or one of the best movies from 2015, this is simply one of the best movies I've ever seen.
This movie was superb intense.   Freaking aweeesome.

Definitely deserved the Oscar nomination. This film is intense, sad, and sometimes difficult to watch. Brie Larson is incredible as always. I don't think I ever want to see this again, but I have a lot of respect for this movie. Thoroughly well made...

There's a good chance that Room is among the finest films I have ever seen. It is truly harrowing to watch, but fiercely intelligent at everything it attempts. I don't understand how the world can ignore stories of this nature - is it because they're 'hard to watch'? And yet everyone loves having a good cry at, say, Inside Out? This stuff *really happens*. Charles Lake, Jaycee Lee Dugard, the Toybox Killer? These aren't even isolated incidents. It's not fantasy, and yet is treated like it does not exist in the interest of 'escapism'. Like Spotlight (but even better), Room is a gorgeous look at the ugliest part of the human soul - and a somewhat life changing film, in total.

Led by the masterful work of Brie Larson and (newcomer) Jacob Tremblay, gut retching dialogue, and an emotionally raw story, Room is beautiful in every sense of the word. It is without a doubt a modern day masterpiece.

Lenny Abrahamson and Emma Donoghue certainly deserve applause for the tense direction and haunting, gut-punching script that gives Room its foundation. But the beautiful, heartbreaking performances from Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay make Room unforgettable. They are absolutely marvelous together.
Excelente y fuerte película! Papelon de Brie Larson y su hijo... Imperdible!
A mesmerizing tale of hope, survival and (if we're going to get all fancy about it) the sheer resilience of the human spirit.

Room's wonderful performances and excellent direction are backed by a screenplay that's filled with subtlety, intelligence, and heart. Though Room has a few minor errors, such as a final act that feels like it could have benefitted from an additional scene or two of development, there are very few films that have had me as emotionally invested in a story as Room, making it one of the best movies of the year. And if that isn't enough, one sequence in the film had me on the edge of my seat more than any sequence in a film this year.
I hope the awards don't overlook Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, and Joan Allen. Simply fantastic.
Brilliant!  Much, much better than the book!

'Room' is profoundly moving - it transforms what is essentially a terrifying situation into a fairy tale about the love between a mother and her child. The kid, Jacob Tremblay, is a revelation... and Brie Larson is outstanding as well.
That kid was awesome!

A taut and tense first half leads to a much looser, weaker, at times infuriating 2nd --- including a "primetime TV' interviewer who posed the most stupid and insensitive questions that no network primetime TV show would ever ask --  and without any protest from the interviewee's party. I avoided seeing Room for the longest time, due to the intense subject matter. It was incredibly moving and powerful. Brie Larson's portrayal as Ma is bar-none the best female performance this year. Jacob Tremblay is impressive as the curious Jack. I was on the verge of tears throughout the whole film. The audience feels for these characters, and their situation. Ultimately, Room is a movie that will be awfully difficult to forget.

Laura's Grade: A

A young mother and her son are locked up in a room with no windows but only a skylight. We soon found out why they are there and they hatch a plan to escape. Part tense thriller and part PTSD the movie, the most intriguing aspect of this emotional film however is that it was told all through the child's point of view. This fresh approach manages to find the humanity and even the humour in the cruel and inhuman situation they found themselves in. A pair of great performances by Brie Larson and the very natural Jacob Tremblay is simply the icing on the cake.
everyday leaves a mark.

"Room is a near-perfect movie, it's one of the best movies of the year"
Movie Review: Room
Date Viewed: November 17 2015
Directed By Lenny Abrahamson
Screenplay By Emma Donoghue, Based on her novel
Starring: Brie Larson, Jacob Tremblay, Sean Bridgers, Joan Allen, William H. Macy, Megan Park, Cas Anvar, Amanda Brugel, 
Joe Pingue, Tom McCamus and Wendy Crewson.

"Room" is an emotional powerhouse of a movie. Brie Larson and newcomer Jacob Tremblay both give fantastic performances in director Lenny Abrahamson's powerful tale about a mother and her boundless love with her son. It is mostly set in one small location, a room with no windows, just a skylight in the ceiling. Brie Larson has done good work before but this little gem is her best work yet. She's right now, the frontrunner to win Best Actress at the Oscars next February.

"Room" is based on a great novel by Emma Donoghue and she also wrote the screenplay which is an excellent one. "Room" is a near-perfect movie, it's one of the best movies of the year. As I said before, "Room" mostly takes place in a small room with a closet, a bathroom, a bed, a toilet and a kitchen with limited food and supplies. Joy Newsome (Larson) has been captive in this room for seven years now and she has a five-year-old son named Jack (Tremblay). They are prisoners of a man named Old Nick (Sean Bridgers).

Also known as Ma, Joy has protected his son from the realities of their situation but when Jack turns five, she enlists a plan for them to escape. Jack has never known much about the outside world, his whole life has been surrounded in this dark room. After the escape plan becomes successful, Old Nick is now behind bars and Joy gets reunited with her parents. Robert and Nancy Newsome (William H. Macy and Joan Allen) have since separated and Joy has a long road ahead of her if she wants to get back to real life. Joy is also doing the best she can to bring her son to a normal life after horrific circumstances.

Tremblay is absolutely incredible in this movie. Since he has long hair, you might think Jack is a girl but he's not because he was held captive in a small room for five years, that's the reason why he didn't get a haircut. We are immediately captivated by him as he makes the difficult journey from a small room to the outside world. Larson has never been better, she truly deserves the Oscar for Best Actress. She's that good. If the Academy fails to nominate her, they would have to retire that category. Joan Allen, William H. Macy (in a very brief role) and Tom McCamus provide comfort and support as Joy's family members.

Proving that she's still one of our very best actresses working today, Joan Allen also gives an Oscar-worthy performance as Joy's mother. This movie is sad and devastating but it is truly worth your time. Please seek out "Room" if it's playing in your theater, it's an unforgettable experience.
A deeply moving and sentimental picture that touched me personally. The bond between a mother and her kin is truly stronger than anything in this world.

I saw "Room" at the Landmark Theater in West LA on Saturday, January 23rd.  It was outstanding!  Very believable.  

here are eight (8) pictures nominated for Best Picture:  "The Big Short", "Bridge of Spies", "Brooklyn", "Mad Max -- Fury Road", "The Martian", "The Revenant", "Room" and "Spotlight".  I've seen all but "Mad Max" and "Room" may be the best.

an exuberant piece of cinema and immensely heartbreaking
Brie Larson is a gem and newcomer Jacob Tremblay is the heart and soul of the movie
how does a mother survive with her child being in a room for 10 years? the best she knows how by teaching her son a certain mentality about the inside world and the outside; nothing else exists but them, nothing is real, nothing is safe
Lenny Abrahamson makes the movie work in such a confined space for a large portion of the narrative because this mother and son depend only on one another to stay positive and sane and by the time they leave the 'room' it's all about taking that perspective and learning to expand on it in a much larger setting
Ma and Jacob struggle to re-attach themselves with the rest of everyone else
the grandparents by Joan Allen and William H. Macy are really good too, considering they have gone through their own hell as much as Ma and Jacob they try to sew back what was torn from them
the world is big and small, always changing, scary but still good
any 'room' big or small is our own
Focuses on making you get all the feels. All of them.
Astonishing performances. Best movie of the year.
Best movie of the year. Brie Larson deserves an Oscar, and Jacob Tremblay is absolutely amazing. Intense, powerful movie. Whew!

"Room" is one of the most emotionally impactful films of 2015. The way the great cast, terrific direction, and incredible writing work to bring you such an impactful adventure is truly remarkable. The cast shines in every direction, with Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay giving two of the best performances in 2015 and Joan Allen having a surprisingly terrific turn in a supporting role. The direction is impeccable, infusing so many of the scenes in this film with heart pounding intensity or incredible amounts of emotion, or both at the same time. The writing is phenomenal, and it makes a movie where you spend nearly half of it in a room with two people one of the most interesting peaces of cinema that 2015 had to offer. Everything works so well and it all comes together to make a truly unforgettable experience that will have you on the edge of your seat and in tears at the same time. It's an absolute must-see and is worth all of the praise and Oscar nominations it got.

Room is the wonderful and emotional tale of a young boy going into the outside world for the first time due to being held captive in a 'room' his entire life alongside his mother, joy, who will have to cope with the pressure. I tell you what, Lenny Abrahamson has absolutely done it again. Room is a masterpiece of character development, drama and suspense. You really care about everyone in this movie apart from the captor. It is truly great emotional dialogue and film work that moves you so much and changes your perspective on how our world would work to that of, essentially, an alien. It's not completely perfect per say...the first few scenes set up this child to be annoying and thank god that the opposite happened.  Apart from that, pure rich dramatic cinema.
I felt every fiber of emotion. Superb acting all around!

I watched this movie before I began my "Oscar Watch". What I do (because my opinion matters) lol. I watch all the movies to see if I agree with the nominations and winners. This year along with that there was some controversey about a snub toward Black movies and actor. Creed, Straight Out of Compton, Concussion, Chiraq and Beasts of No Nation with actors and actresses in those movies as well being snubbed. I was going to watch those movies anyway (except Chiraq I am still on the fence about watching that). I had already watched SOC. I havent watched Concussion, but I doubt seeing it would change my opinion..laughing at myself cuz people really care what I think..
 I read the book first. I honestly did not care for the book very much.  The movie was ok. I actually wish I would have just saw the movie and never read the book, I am sure I would I have liked the movie so much more.  Watching the movie and seeing so much left out and changed effected my opinion of the movie, but I love Brie Larson and that little boy was super adorable so that made up for it. 
 As far as deserving a best picture nomination, I think it was chosen because of the story not the movie. It was more enjoyable than Brookyln..but it really wasn't written near as well as the other movies in this category, now was the acting half as good. Honestly Beasts of No Nation was a more interesting story and Abraham Attah out acted Brie and Jacob..so there is a snub here as far as Best Picture nomination goes.
 As far as the best actress win..as I said I love Brie and I am happy she won..BUT I think Cate should have gotten I mean if we talking about pure acting skills in these two particular movies..but what else would one expect from Cate?
I definitely want to see this. The book was awesome.

Oh sweet Jesus.  Not since Short Term 12 (ironically also starring Brie Larson) have I seen a movie as visceral as this. Brie Larson does a superb job, but it's really the impeccable Jacob Tremblay that carries this incredible story.  The direction was gorgeous and Emma Donoghue's screenplay was expertly crafted.  Harrowing and torturous, yet hopeful, this is a film that I will not forget for a long time, but it will be a long time before I can watch it again.
Great story, great acting, great all around movie.
Tema muy fuerte pero llena de esperanza. una actuacion bellisima de Jacob tremblay.
Heavy film. I was choked up & near tears the entire film!
A complete original. Emotionally insightful and features the best child performance I've ever seen.

A gripping, heart wrenching tale of a mother and son reconnecting and for one connecting for the first time to reality after a horror of a life. Brie Larson, who I have been a big champion of with 21 Jump Street, Don Jon, Short Term 12, Trainwreck, and her great TV role on United States of Tara, is amazing as a woman that was kidnapped and imprisoned in a shed for 7 years of her life. It is just unimaginable the torment of being in the same room for 7 years with little supplies and obviously the sexual torment of the kidnapper that led to the birth of Jacob Tremblay's character. Jacob Tremblay is great here and there is a lot of buzz about both actors getting award recognition which is warranted but if Jacob is nominated as a Supporting Actor as he is being campaigned for, that will be singlehandedly the biggest Oscar crime in the history of the show as Tremblay is the commanding force of the movie being in almost every scene and even narrating the movie. But I digress. What it so great about his performance is the factor of only knowing what the world looks like assuming it is this room he is in. He has never seen cars, a fast food restaurant, a hospital, or other people for that matter. The scenes of him just discovering the world for the first time are really powerful stuff that makes you think about how you would have dealt with such a scenario. Joan Allen is really powerful as Larson's mom with this dynamite confrontation between her and Larson but equally powerful with the bonding between her in Jacob. William H. Macy is so great as an actor that he was only in a scene within seconds and broke my heart immediately to the point I was seconds away from crying. That happened twice in the movie, that scene and when Larson finally gets out of the room which I don't think is a spoiler if you've seen the trailer and or realize the inclusion of many other characters. The set decorator and production designer did a great job designing Room making it look very possible to live in but still a small living space as the work of the cinematography enhances. There are some really wonderful moments cinematography wise like the first time Jacob sees the sky in the back of a truck and some of the subtle things that happen in Room. That's what I enjoyed about this movie the most, it could have been an over the top hostage movie but it had so much subtly to most scenes and it was quite nuanced than other movies of the same topic. The wiring is excellent, the direction is superb, the score is powerful though was a bit impeding during some scenes, and a great ensemble. My two quarrels with the movie would have to lie with William H. Macy's character and this unexplained hostility that happens during a dinner scene. It just felt in the end odd placement and even odder that it was never explained why it was such a hostile moment. I would have liked more of Macy and maybe a few more scenes of Jacob discovering the world for the first time. Other than that, this is a harrowing but powerful movie that is a must see.

Simple.
Original.
Singular.
Powerful.
Smart.
Freaking thoughtful...
Incisive look at PTSD with outstanding performances from absolutely everyone involved. Larson and Tremblay create a world of their own and their adjustment to a new one is an acting tour-de-force.

A brilliant film with a fairly straightforward story and an incredible chemistry between its two leads, Room is a heart-wrenching film told from the perspective of 5-year-old Jack, and his contrasting experiences in and outside of Room. The art direction from Lenny Abramson is exceptional. Room is a grand-scale epic, in small amounts. It's as much of a sci-fi movie as 2001: A Space Odyssey or Star Wars is.

Room is something of a spectacle. The simplicity of the story matches the complex emotions that run inside us as we watch Brie Larson and Jacob tremblay dazzle us with their career changing performances. The film deserves a lot of credit for being unique and for being real. Rarely will you ever see such moving performances that make you so grateful for having a normal life. This picture brought a lump to my throat, and rarely can s movie do that. Truly a wonderful experience

At the start of Room, a young woman and her five-year-old son are living in the titular edifice, a backyard shed. The woman (Brie Larson) has always told Jack (Jacob Tremblay) that "outer space" is all that exists outside Room; as far as Jack is concerned, this is the gospel truth and the universe consists of Room and Room alone.

It is not giving anything away to note that Ma and Jack escape Room, as the movie is more about the ability of each to cope with the outside world. For Jack, every step and every breath outside is a wholly new experience. Ma, despite having lived for 17 years before coming to Room, encounters different obstacles - the world has moved on, and she doubts her own ability as a mother to Jack.

I had been expecting a suspenseful drama-thriller about a daring escape, given the various synopses I'd read. (The movie is based on a novel by Emma Donoghue, which is itself loosely based on real events.) Much of the first half of the film, though, concentrates on life inside Room for Ma and Jack. Ma uses her strong will and infinite patience to convince Jack for five years that all is well and that what they have is a normal life, that what they see on television is not real, but everything from the single bed to the lidless toilet tank is definitely real. Ma sacrifices as much as she can to keep Jack happy and (relatively) safe, even to the point of giving herself over to her captor on a regular basis in exchange for food and other items for Jack and herself.

To say that this first half moves slowly would be to understate things. We don't just get a slice of the life that the duo leads; we get the entire pie, and most of it just isn't all that exciting or intriguing. We do get to see a little into the characters of the characters, pardon the phrasing. We see that Jack doesn't like to not get his way or to have his worldview challenged. Then again, who does at age 5? We see that Ma is often calm but firm with her young charge. It's a small Room, after all; no need to go nuclear when there's really no point to it. In any event, much time is spent watching their everyday sheltered lives. Because the general plot involved their lives beyond Room, I began to grow impatient: Were they going to spend the entire movie in Room, only to escape in the final minutes? Why wouldn't anything happen? The fact that Ma and Jack would eventually escape left the first half of the movie perfectly devoid of suspense. Although still waters do often run deep, I didn't really feel like I was getting a lot out of watching a whole lot of nothing.

Once they do escape, though, things pick up. The focus quickly shifts from a struggle for survival to a struggle to understand. Ma's parents, played by Joan Allen and William H. Macy, have different reactions to the return of their daughter and the arrival of their new (to them) grandson. In the five years since Ma's abduction, her parents have separated; her dad lives on the other side of the country now, and her mom lives with her friend Leo (Tom McCamus). With Ma's return, there's a lot of media hype, and lawyers, atop a potent array of stress factors. Escaping may have been the easy part.

The acting is uniformly terrific. Larson's work is powerful, evocative, and heart-wrenching, and it's definitely award worthy. Allen and Macy also excel with perhaps the best work in their respective careers, and that's saying something. Young Tremblay is also very good - as is his character, a plucky, long-haired cherub who's more at home in Room than in the outside world (and with good reason).

But the acting cannot overcome what's basically a very turgid script. Room is punchless at its core, and it would be a total waste if it weren't for the Herculean efforts of its talented cast. When there is no action, I look for meaning. When there is no meaning or action, I look for the exit. Room suffers from spending too much time contemplating things and not enough time doing them - or at least discussing them. Forget the action, I wouldn't have minded seeing more reaction. The first half of the movie could have been subtitled "A Series of Plodding Events." The second half goes a long way toward saving the first, thanks in part to additional characters and a fresh setting, but it's not enough to save the entire movie.
An Oscar-worthy performance from Brie Larson, amazing cinematography and some of the best child acting I've ever seen from Jacob Tremblay make this an almost perfect movie.
This is a very good movie (evidenced by the critics reviews) but just lacking something to make it great.

Room is a good film, filled with gut wrenching moments and powerful emotion. Larson and Tremblay are as fantastic as reported and failure to garner Oscar nominations would only make the Academy look dumber than it already is. However, call me cynical and bloodthirsty, but I got the feeling that Room played it a bit too safe and ended a little too lightly. Ma's suicide attempt was awful glossy, as was the interview, while other topics were barely addressed at all. I get that this is a tough topic and I'm at as much of a loss on how to address it as anyone but I wish that Abrahamson had cut a little deeper on this one. You get the feeling that there isn't anything wrong with Room as is but what it could have been might have really been something else. Regardless, the film is still moving, still powerful and still worth watching. Larson is a lock for a best actress nod in my mind.

Emotionally gripping and gut wrenching, Room portrays the beautiful innocence of a child's mind and fantasy, surrounded by devastation. You will go on an emotional, at times suffocating, rollercoaster. This is due to beautiful camerawork, direction and incredible performances by Jacob Tremblay en Brie Larson. The latter again proving why she is one of the greatest actresses of her generation.

Flawless storytelling with a mesmerizing performance from Larson, Room is easily the most heartfelt and emotionally riveting film of the year, the real star however is Tremblay, whose performance is out of this world phenomenal.

Nature vs Nurture

What if you grew up in a prison, and all you knew were the 4 walls surrounding you? Would you go crazy? 

In Room, Joy(Brie Larsen) is kidnapped and enclosed in a shed where she has taken care of her kid, Jack(played amazingly by Jacob Tromblay) for the past 7 years. All he knows is the skylight, the tub, Sunday treats. In order to survive Ma sets up rules. Since its told from Jacks perspective the emotional underpinning of what's real outside of Room and breaking the set rules are huge showcases for the actors to stretch. 

But the movie doesn't end there. It turns into another different type of movie. It is kinda like Prisoners. Ma gets imprisoned by her family and her emotions, jack gets imprisoned by freedom, grandma gets imprisoned by grandpa. The build to breaking out of all these prisons are amazing and fulfilling. This is an emotional powerhouse of a movie that will leave you in tears and yearning to call your loved ones and hod them close.

Was kinda emotionally tired after it to be honest. Everything was amazing from the script to the acting, the chemistry between everyone but especially Brie and Jacob, the music, the direction, just everything.

This movie was as beautiful as it was emotionally draining. Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay seemed so natural together. It was interesting to go through this experience  through the eyes of a child. A must see!!!!

I haven't read the book, but it seems like "Room" is a nearly perfect adaptation. The reason being is it manages to pull you into every single emotion that's unraveled throughout the transformation of the story and characters, which is a lot, without ever feeling overwhelming or bogged down with details the book offers. It's concise enough to be the narrative of a film, while containing all the emotion, it seems, the book would give you. And besides that, Brie Larson and Jason Tremblay are both nothing but greatness all the way through. My favorite film of 2015 thus far.

Room touches on the subject stockholm syndrome in a horrific and realistic way, but the film main triumph was director Lenny Abrahamson created a truthfulness in his visual storytelling  that gives Ma to wrap a bubble of love that the idea of hellish prison into a universe of possibilities and fantasies to protect Jack. Two central lead by Brie Larson and Jacob Tremblay are just absolutely splendid as caring and often heartbreaking performance.

Bigger than an empty space

Room is a fantastic character study. The film, which rides on its two leads, is powerful and engaging, making the audience feel isolated and scared. Out of all the elements and effort that was put into this film it is really the acting, specifically Larson and Trembly who this film would not work without.

Room is a very well rounded film. It is solid on all fronts including direction, writing, cinematography, and above all acting. It is a very small film with a very small budget. This makes the film even more reliant on storytelling and character development. These two both have very emotional and realistic character arcs, with very talented rising stars to portray them. Larson and Trembly are both in the race for best actress and best supporting actor, but it is definitely Larson who will get much awards praise.

Room, though well rounded, is an imperfect film. The suspense does peak and reach its height at the end of its first act. There is nothing much it except one other scene later on in the film. After the peak, it becomes less interesting, but still entertaining and powerful. Another problem is the character of William H. Macy, who is obviously the most recognizable actor in the whole film. His character arc feels unfinished and feels as if he was only available for one or two days on set, which resulted in less appearances by what could've been a very intriguing arc.

Overall the film delivers on its promises, a suspenseful film with a glimmer of hope. With great performances and inspiring storytelling, though imperfect, manages to join many in the race for best picture. 

Rating: 8.3 (A-)
